Posted: December 11, 2016
												I want to reccomend this game, ..But a year ago, I reported a major game breaking bug, that -several- people were encountering,Mission 4, If you kill a production unit, while it is just about, or even finishing a unit, it will create an un-killable unit, that you can not hurt, can not interact with, and your own vehicles can't run into it, -however- the game thinks it is alive, and therefore you -can not beat the mission- and yet, Here it is a year later, and apparently the bug was never fixed, and people are -still- encountering the very bug that I posted a year ago, even in the same place and circumstances..... So I think the company kind of sold this and then left it...without fixes to game breaking bugs.I have seen reports of similar bugs appearing also on MIssion 5, and other levels it seems.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												I really wanted to love this game, I've tried so hard but it's just not quite there.The story is great, the homeworld(ish) feel is just right, the graphics and visuals are top notch and the missions are varied.BUT, there just isn't enough variety in the unit types and abilities in an age of Starcraft's and total war's.  All the factions are essentially the same with different appearances and the gameplay is heavily scripted [/spoiler] where the AI always throws endless units at you forever until you complete the objectives[/spoiler].  Couple that with annoying oddities that still aren't fixed: bombers that don't bomb first strafe so get shot down, units taking weird paths and dying, the tactical view doesn't perfectly represent the actual map, it's hard to tell if a unit can shoot or not though some weapons can fire through hills and structures (sometimes), etc, etc and it leaves me frustrated.There was so much potential and I hope they give it another go as the fan base is loyal and keen and judging by the reviews, very forgiving.  Bring on Homeworld 3!

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
 Deserts of Kharak is a well made sequel to Homeworld - tactic and RTS fans get their money's worth. Since I was fortunate enough to participate in the beta test I have played long enough to give you my review.StoryThe story is actually a prequel to Homeworld 1. In part 1 the intro reveals that alien artifacts have been found within the desert of Kharak which made the construction of a mighty spaceship possible.And the latest part Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak tells you the story about the search and excavation of the artifacts on the planet Kharak.GameplayYou control some sort of rolling aircraft carrier called Kapisi (your mobile HQ) through the life-threatening world of the planet Kharak. Kapisi allows you to store resources, research technologies, and the production of units. Although Kapisi has the functionality of a base, its mobility helps to set it apart from traditional RTS games. Thus a proper base building does not exist. You're looking for a suitable location and gather resources to enlarge your fleet and to research new technologies.Above everything else it's a strategy game. You can use the units from previous missions in upcoming ones, therefore you should keenly collect all resources and build units before moving on to the next mission.A unit limit prohibits you from taking too many units to the next mission. Grr. The roughly 15 hour long singleplayer campaign is tactically rather moderate and not very rapid. Most importantly you must take over good positions step by step to intercept your enemy, gather artifacts and finally destroy the enemy. In the online mode and skirmish battles everything's much more rapid, there are also 3 different win conditions in the skirmish gamemode.Otherwise one notices the well executed control system, the fitting sound, the good lighting effects and the breathtaking graphics within the gameplay. In terms of gameplay it's a well made game, though the shortness of the singleplayer campaign and the Interface, which needs getting used to, disturb a bit in the beginning. Pros: Breathtaking graphics and great effects thanks to the Unity engineSound &. Music fit the game very well and sound greatEasily learned and uncomplicated unit controlsGood animations and short video sequences with real actors in between missionsWell done and very innovative multiplayer mode. Expect tense fights with differing win conditions, like for example destroying the main base, total destruction or the hunt for artifacts (a kind of Capture the Flag)Good physics and you can use the terrain to your advantageSteam Achievements & SteamcloudNeutral: The AI is not completely stupid, but currently only hardly reacts to areal attacks and it's easy to properly position oneself, trick the AI and intercept the constantly reocurring attack pattern.There is no minimap but a tactical interface."Only" 13 singleplayer story missions which are beaten within 12-15 hours on medium difficultyCons: Newcomers to the Homeworld Series are left with unanswered questions regarding the storyInterface and construction menu requires getting used toThere is a pretty generous unit limitConclusion:Someone who likes RTS should take a closer look at this innovative, graphically well done game, but only if one's not only keen on a singleplayer campaign, but also enjoys a few skirmishes or playing online.This review was written as a valuation inside of its own genre.Total rating: 8/10If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

content:
Posted: December 3, 2016
												SUMMARY: It's Broke Jim! Beautiful music & visuals, but game-breaking bug destroyed it all.---UPDATE Jan 3 2017: See comments for workaround to Mission 4 "destroy remaining forces" bug. I've decided to keep my "not recommended" rating, because the bug is still present after a year and I believe consumers deserve a minimum level of quality for their money - you shouldn't have to research and follow precise instructions from other consumers to work around an otherwise-blocking bug just to be able to play your purchase.---I had such high hopes - I loved Homeworld's story and I knew I'd love a prequel story. However, a few hours into playing this game, I encountered a game-breaking bug that prevented me from progressing past Mission 4 (Kalash Site). I've tried multiple times with different strategies and it's just stuck. Some people say I just have to delete & reinstall and play from the very beginning because the save file is corrupt. I played Homeworld when I was a kid with plenty of time. As an adult, my gaming time is very rare. I don't have the time to replay it all because of a bug.The internet shows this is a very well known and common bug, known in January 2016 and still unfixed after nearly a year in December 2016. They have good engineers... so a year without a fix makes it clear that this game is simply not receiving investment.For whatever portion of this game you do manage to play, you'll enjoy the gameplay, especially the beautiful visuals and soundtrack! I look forward to the day when my children, or perhaps my grand children, can download a patch and experience Missions 5+. Until then, I just can't recommend wasting valuable gaming time.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												I don't usually write reviews, but for this one I just felt I have to. First of all let me super straight - the game brought a lot of positive memories from my past when I spent dozens of hours playing Homeworld, then Homeworld 2 and then the Complex fan-based modification. The graphics, the music, the gameplay, the story, the general vibe of a Homeworld game - it's all there. Unfortunately there're a lot of other issues with the game that I found rather disappointing. All of them seem to align with what other not-so-excited reviewers are writing. First, campaign length. I've spent about 10 hours playing campaign only. I've tried to obtain every resource available on *all* 13 missions and it only took me less than 10 hours to get this done. I felt quite disappointed when I realised this is it. Second, the AI is just, well, dumb. There's no real challenge here. Just built dozens of AA units and fear that AI will send ground units only? Don't worry, they'll keep on sending those fighters. Worry an enemy AA unit will rush to help his friends being bombarded 100 meters away? Don't worry, the AA battery will just nicely sit there, waiting to be eliminated by your ground troops once you clear the area around using air units. I haven't lost a single mission in this game. Hell, it was more of a... cakewalk. Third, just five maps in skirmish mode? Really? So tl;dr;. Would I spend €46 for this game knowing how short my satisfaction would be? Probably not. Would I recommend it to a die-hard Homeworld fan? Probably yes, but only if you're really willing to spend this amount of cash for a game so short.

number of helpful: 89 of 108 people (82%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak, the fourth game of the homeworld franchise and its first non-spacial RTS. In short words: Worth every single cent you put on it.Warning: I never played any other homeworld game, I didn't know its story nor had read about it before playing this game. But I'm an RTS Veteran, I've been playing RTSes since WarCraft 2, going through all games from the C&C Franchise, AoE and AoM Franchises, StarCraft 1, BW and 2, Company of Heroes 2, Grey Goo and many others.Singleplayer: I started playing the campaign, hoping for a few hours of good story telling, that is not what I got. I got an outstanding, catchy story that made me complete forget about my schedule and keep playing, the famous "one more mission, just one, I want to know what happens". Solid storyline, characters development is there, and as the story goes, you get to know more of each one, including side characters.Playthrough is not repetitive, levels have good variety and there is replayability for its campaign. It mays sound odd, playing the campaign again, despite being the same missions, the combination of reactive army + RNG makes the singleplayer extremely interesting to play over and over again. What do I mean with reactive army? the opponent's composition is based on yours, even on easy difficulty, imagine now in the hardest one.The whole game is beautiful, and it has in-game scripted moments, that gives youa feel that what you play is what you watch (the player never feels dislocated like watching a movie instead of playing the game). Immersive, if you want a "gamer like" word.Multiplayer:I bought it when patch 1.0.1 was live. It had its flaws, won't go easy on this point, netcode was unstable, we had no replays, and just 2 factions, that was back in February 20th. Now we are in the version 1.2.1 (June 24th), after patches 1.0.2, 1.0.3, 1.1, 1.1.1 and 1.2! And  A LOT HAS CHANGED, AND FOR BETTER! Replay system was implemented, new maps were added, netcode was fixed, tweaks in-game made the user experience a lot better. Two more sub factions were released as paid DLCs (worth the cost, they are cheap and add a lot of diversity to the game), and a new future DLC was hinted (no official word about it but other players and I speculate a singleplayer DLC is coming).Balance has been tweaked a lot to the point that DoK is one of the few RTSes in which you don't have to tech up to get imbalanced units, or do timings following a strict and 100% effective micro/macro management. No, the game is fluid, it allows you to set your pace and fight your opponent based on your rhythm. It is most important "feature", the thing that you should master to be good in DoK's multiplayer, is Game knowledge combined Map awareness. Positional play is the key, to the point you can turn the tide of a Battle if you know how and where to place your army. But it is not restricted and mandatory like Company of Heroes 2, where you must secure territories in order to have fuel and ammunition.There are strong units, but everything has a counter. There are "super weapons" that, despite the name I gave them, can't win the game, and it ends up falling into the player hands the  responsibility to use such weapon as a tide turning tool combined with his army in order to win the game.Development:As I said, in 4 months 6 patches were released, 7 if you consider that 1.0.1 was released in early February. Blackbird Interactive is a small studio when compared with other companies, and yet they are able to consistently update the game, deliver content (paid and for free), hear feedback from the community and answer to it.Here it is a little something that may sound as me using my "bragging rights": During a chat in one of the communities hub (the most active Discord server[discord.gg] related to homeworld franchise) I mentioned that would be cool to race a "random" faction, so I could enjoy the game at its fullest by just having the faction selected by the game (I play as random in pretty much every other RTS). A few weeks later, this feature was implemented. By no means I'm saying it was because of me, but one thing is for sure: Devs listen, acknowledge, and if it is reasonable, they implement it.And just recently they added support to OS X! You have an PC and a Mac? No problem, the game you bought back in Feb is now compatible with both platforms!I have a lot of faith in these guys, and I hope that with them DoK only has one future: a brighter one.Extras:Expedition Guide: If you're like me, a complete newbie to the homeworld universe, the expedition guide is an excellent acquisition. I read it after finishing the SP by the first time and I was in a awe with the amount of backstory they developed for this game. I only felt like this with a game once: When I was a little boy and had bought StarCraft 1 that came with a huge manual telling the lore of each from beginning of time. If you're a Lore lover, expedition guide is a must.Soundtrack: Love good songs? like a desert kind soundtrack with plus of mysticism, technology and apocalyptic aura? DoK gives you 111 tracks of it, in FLAC!  Instabuy for me, it may be for you too.Soban and Khaaneph Fleet packs: here is where things get tricky. In a DLC filled world, adding factions to a game as paid DLC could be called Pay2Win, and that could not be more far from true with DoK.DoK Factions introduce, by a small fee, changes in the factions, adding new mechanics, new skins to existent units, and new ways to play it. As I said before, nothing is OP,  and that is also valid to the expansion Fleets. Does it worth? yes, $7 is more than fair for a whole new way to play a game that I enjoyed.Want an example? Khanneph Baserunner (scout unit) can create a blast drone, a fast little bugger that explodes dealing massive amount of damage. Sounds quite OP right? not really, while it is fast and has a lot of damage, when spotted, it can be taken out by the most basic unit such as sandskimmer and LAVs.PROS: Immersive Singlplayer with incredible in-game scripted scenes, good dialogues and excellent audio work (voice and soundtrack) Replayability with an combination of RNG and player's choice (you can challenge yourself by putting your army in a bad spot); Involving Multiplayer that does not make you feel overwhelmed with its micro/macro intensity like StarCraft/Company of Heroes, but it is not simplistic enough to make you bored after a few hours; Hardware requirements are not extreme - despite what is said by other players I've been running it in a 2 yo computer with everything on ultra and at 60 FPS, if I disable AA, Vsync and anisotropic I can reach 150FPS easily. Extremely hardworking development team, keeping the game fresh and updated; All DLCs have a good price tag for what they add to your game experience.CONS: Due to its small playerbase you may feel "alone", but there is a community behind this game; Despite everything it still lacks a few basic features that I would like to see added such as: A more complete replay system, an observer mode, a few tweaks here and there; It is not exactly a con, but I would love to have more content.Personal rating? I bought this game out of the sale, paid full price for it and all DLCs. And I would do it again. 10 out of 10, best RTS of 2016 imho.Update: This game still is one of the best around.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Positives:- Wonderful audio- Gameplay is very fun- Art Design and Graphics are good, the game looks very good overall- The story is fantastic, especially for a RTS. If you liked the old homeworld games lore, get this one asap. Interesting characters, well written story and dialogue. Did I just write that for a RTS game... Yup lol. Best writing in a RTS since World in Conflict.- The Atmosphere is very well done, it feels like Homeworld, oozes the whole feel perfectlyNegatives Or Things that can be improved:- The AI needs some work- More maps would be nice (I have seen today the devs announced free maps are on the way down the road)If you prefer a slower RTS, over say Starcraft 2 or if you want a RTS with a great campaign that is well written and  a blast to play, pick this up. Not perfect, but quite a good addition to the RTS genre, especially at a time when RTS games rarely come out and if they do they are usually multiplayer focused, nice to have one doing a good job with the campaign, story and atmosphere. Not as fast paced or twitchy as the popular starcraft2, but at the same time, the multiplayer in starcraft 2 has alot more options.I will post more impressions and thoughts late on when I have more hours on the game. So far it is very good though! Very Immersive, audio rocks, it looks nice and it is fun to play, despiate the ai issues and lack of maps for multi on launch.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												I love this game. It doesn't mean I would tell someone to buy it.Just finished the game.  Classic Difficulty.  I had a blast playing it as an old homeworld fan. Won't lie was hoping for something that was more Homeworld: Cataclysm then the other two games.   It feels and plays like a Homeworld game. Each unit has a purpose and excells in that roll, but as far as the campaign is concenred there is a certain point in which anyhting smaller then a Cruiser becomes useless. This is very much Homeworld 2 over the previous games which might turn some off. The hard part though.  Would I tell someone to spend 50$+ on this?  As the game is right now no.  Unless that person is a major homeworld and rts fan there is really no reason to buy this. Even then it is a hard sell.  The campaign is 13 missions long which is fine, but the skirmish and multiplayer as others have said before is where an RTS survives.  The fact the game shipped with 5 maps and a barebones AI which you will notice in the campaign really makes me worry about the longterm survival of this game. That and the lack of marketing on gearbox's front makes me worry that gearbox doesn't expect this to live long either.Edit:2/1/2016There are now 6 multiplayer maps.  Multiplayer is reciving balance so meta is a bit better now. Ai is still braindead.

												Deserts of Kharak is an amazing RTS game and my most played game of 2016.With a solid narrative Campaign tying into the original Homeworld series and dynamic fast paced Multiplayer it has alot to offer.If you are looking for just the single player experience you should be able to get around 10 hours game time.If you want multiplayer you will find a sparce but dedicated community, I highly recommend you look into the community group Legacy of Sajuuk as well as the Discord Homeworld Universe.Otherwise you are just going to be put off by empty server lists.Anyone who reads this review and is convinced to try, feel free to message me or send a friend request, I'll happily introduce you to the existing community and help get you accustom to the MP.DoK is an amazing game which with more players could grow into something truly spectacular

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												This is a true spiritual successor to the Homeworld series.  Every little touch that made Homeworld so memorable is in this game.  Unfortunately, for a $55 dollar price tag this game is woefully lacking in content.  I completed the 13 mission campaign in under 10 hours of playtime.  Whats there to do after that? Not much.  Theres a skirmish mode against an absolutely horrid AI, even on the hardest difficulty.  There is also a multiplayer but the map pool is so tiny (5 maps total? only two of them are for the most played online mode 1v1)  Just bare bones content wise all around.  This is why i cant really recomment this game for this high of a price tag.  There is zero replayability in the campaign, its a once and done kind of thing and the multiplayer is just barren.  Get this if you absolutely need a homeworld fix, but personally id avoid this until it goes on sale for at least 50% off. Just nothing to do in this game.

Real shame, because it's the best multiplayer experience I had in years. Can't really recommend.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												The best RTS Ive played in a long time, hands down.The campaign is an absolute masterpiece. Great atmosphere, immersion, visual style and music. SUPERB mission design. Every mission is very different without being gimmicky, and offers a wide variety of strategic play. The game favors strategy and tactical control over twitch micro, much like previous Homeworld games. 10/10While somewhat slim on multiplayer features at release, DoK has already had 3 major patches, with a fourth coming this month. The developers continue to support this game with new maps, multiplayer features and balance changes, and DLC. The MP community is rather small, but very friendly and welcoming to new players.If I had to find fault with the game, its the occasional bugs in the Public Lobby for custom games. Sometimes there are issues with p2p connectivity, but you can generally resolve them with a restart. If you like RTS, Homeworld, or Sci-Fi, buy this game.

number of helpful: 79 of 102 people (77%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												A quite awesome addition to the dying RTS genre, Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak done a prequel story perfectly: setting up story points that were kinda "out there" in the originals, turning the game into a well made "new first game" of the series (chronologically speaking). There are obvious problems, especially when it comes to the braindead AI in multiplayer, but if you're someone who's more into singleplayer RTS games, this one is just right for you.I do have to say that it seemed like I found the exact opposite what everyone else was talking about regarding the campaign, including TotalBiscuit. They said the campaign is very easy, there are too many resources, you get unit types out of the blue without explanation, etc. I found all this to be false, as I had a rough time on Normal difficulty, I was always out of resources, and every single unit type you get is explained. So that particular criticism is weird for me. But maybe it's just me.So yeah. I'd recommend this game to RTS fans, and especially those who were fans of the original Homeworld games. It's rare if we get RTS games nowadays, so this is definitely one shining diamond.(One more note: The game is called -Deserts- of Kharak. So don't be surprised if all the maps are set in a desert.)

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
Hello everybody.About myself: RTS player, usually oriented on competetive multiplayer experience (CoH, SupCom, MoW:AS), have limited experience with Homeworld franchise overall but definitely a persone interested in lore.In short: Game is great. It has some issues, but there is no core flaws which can make a game unplayable or effect its replayability. Game core mechanics are pretty deep, It has rich solo experience and well thought-out competetive oriented multiplayer. It is defenitely a Homeworld game from Homeworld developers. You can feel the soul of game universe while playing this game thats for sure. Amount of work those guys put in lore, game details and gameplay is huge and you can be sure that project not gonna be droped like some random moneygrab. Get this game and invest in quality game development.Core mechanicsGame is defenitely self sufficient as Homeworld game and as real time strategy. There are multiple gameplay layers from terrain to unit active abilities and veterancy system. Solid groundbased strategy overall which can be compared to original Company of heroes.Solo campaignStory is rich, gameplay is really immersive. You have great wrighting, voice acting, awesome cutscenes\videos, unit persistance with veterancy system and pretty intence atmosphere overall. Expedition Guide adds alot for lore guys like me. All you need is a bit of imagination and good headset to dive into desert. On the other side difficulty even on classic is not that hard, but game do not hold your hand all the time like TotalBiscuit tells you. MultiplayerInformation about multiplayer was limited before release to say at least and this part of the game come out as a great surprise. You can clearly feel that original Shipbreackers project was oriented on multiplayer. You have 1v1, 2v2 3v3 ladder system with matchmaking and skill tiers. Artifact retreaval game mode in ranked saves this game from passive camping of original annihialtion gamemode of Homeworld multiplayer. Belance is pretty good for a fact that there were no closed\open beta for multyplayer. You can play 2 factions with really good diversity, dont listen to those who tells you that they are all the same. There is no identical units at all and there are huge core differencies in strategy\abilities\unit compositions etc. With great game core mechanics this game have a possibility to became a noticable RTS game like CoH or SupCom. There is no replay and observers system which are essential to form a competetive community around the game. And 5 maps are not enought thats for sure. Devs have a lot of work here if they want to bring this game to competetive standarts.You can look at competetive part of the game here - "First Ever Shoutcast! Pro 1v1" from well known Company of Heroes commentators

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												This will be my final write up on this review, as I have now completed the campaign and because of that alone my opinion is now a very, VERY cautious recommendation IF all you are after is the prequel story in a rushed format. If you're after replayability, hours of skirmishing etc, then go play Homeworld Remastered/ClassicsI've played the Classics since I was a kid back on a 98 os system (all the way through xp and windows 7, I've probably put over a 1000 hours into each) and I've put well over a 100 hours into remastered just so you know that this is an opinion on the game from someone who has been tainted with the previous Homeworlds. A new fans opinion may obviously vary from mine.I'll start off with the positive:	 The art style of the cutscenes is fantastic, it's actually something I wish other media would uptake it's so pretty. The music is classic Homeworld, desperate and dramatic tones of orchestra, it's great. There's more dynamic battlechatter (for example when an enemy is detected but not seen units will report they have signals but no visual conformation) which is a very nice touch Guard formations are back, (took us this long to get that back?) Atmosphere and story is very homeworld, a desperate struggle against a formiddable enemy Love the fact Rachel is a unit, any game which lets you some way have a badass chick is usually good in my books Artifact recovery is a fun little thing to do, and it's a great asset, they offer great strengthening factors to your fleet The prequel story is very compelling, not to spoil anything but after the end of this I immediately went and started playing Homeworld 1 againNow the negative: The game looks like♥♥♥♥♥♥when compared to remastered, even on ultra, ship textures are okay and the explosions are....okay, but the other FX look pretty poor and the sand textures look extremely lat and lifeless, to the point where I look at the screenshots above and scoff. Combat has a serious lack of individual unit importance, the only way you can win is mostly by unit spam, you'll throw a lot of the starting units straight to the winds There's no ballistics, at least from what I can tell, rail gun hits seem to be RNG and everything else is just falsely animated when compared to what's actually shooting and what's actually taking damage No docking? No harvester drop off animations? What? TERRIBLE unit clipping, like half the stuff on the surface doesn't actually exist, I've got scavengers just driving through the wreck of the Kalash like it's nobodies business Very little unit variation both in each race and between the two races, one race hovers and the other doesn't but in terms of combat they are identical Only 5 maps for Skirmish/Online The controls are pretty butchered, unnecessary button changes to a system that was well understood and well loved, and you can't even get that system back because the controls are NOT-REBINDABLE  No ALT focusing, making trying to keep an eye on your units in combat even more difficult without them clipping through sand, mountains, bigger units and resources Unit target priority is very odd, rail guns will try to shoot tiny fast LAV's while another railgun is killing them, it's like they just defend themselves from what they see first which will ALWAYS be the LAV's I know this is precise but, the support carriers guns will all fire when in combat, even if not all of them are on target, so you get bullets just flying off the thing in random directions for no reason Missiles and bombs have very random velocities, they'll launch/drop at reasonable speeds but as soon as they get close to a target they'll accelerate to ridiculous speeds and perform seriously unbelieveable changes in direction. I understand a bit of smudging to make stuff like that hit but, this is immersion breaking I find very few of the scenarious in the campaign to be imaginative, you've got your standard first mission of testing resourcing, production and the like and from there's it's just been engage and destroy the enemy mostly (as well as the aforementioned artifacts to recover) Skirmish AI is both useless and a dirty cheater at harvesting resources much faster than you ever could Camera gets stuck at certain zooms sometimes Sometimes turret animations will simply fail and rounds will come out the back of them instead of through the barrelOf course some of this can be fixed in patches, we NEED Alt focusing again and we DEFINITELY need rebindable controls, as well as a fix for the buggy clipping, certain odd unit behaviour and some busted animationsMy final word is that I really want to say I enjoyed this, hell I probably did, the campaign (as un-imaginative as it is) is enough to make you want to complete it, but that's pretty much all you're getting. If you're a die-hard Homeworld fan and you want to experience this epic journey of the great expedition then be prepared to experience the feeling of a very rushed game along with it. Buggy animations, unit clipping, fairly certain I've mentioned it all. And it will ruin the immersive moments, even the end of the game was almost ruined for me, as the final scene plays and the beautiful animation style shows us the sky of Kharak, Rachel was saying her piece and was interrupted twice by the blockhead Intel Officer saying "Galsien fighters approaching" even after I'd killed every single last one of them.I just chose to ignore him (the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥)

number of helpful: 28 of 29 people (97%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												Full disclosure: I'm one of those people... a 90's PC gamer that was blown away by the first Homeworld. It's been propped up in my mind as one of the greatest strategy games of all time. I've gone back and played it ad nauseum... yadda yadda yadda. I'm one of those types.People like me will tell you that Deserts of Kharak has mighty big shoes to fill. And... It doesn't quite live up to it. How could it? Homeworld is more or less an 'ideal' at this point. But I'll also tell you in the same breath that Kharak is a game worth playing. The art is stylish. The graphics retain that sense of scale that made the original so impressive. The story is decent; more about representing a sense of place than of character development (very sci fi). Most importantly, it feels like a Homeworld game.Like I said though, it falls short. The game is over much too quickly, and the pacing is inconsistent. Kharak is a road trip game, but its jerky flow makes it seem like you're missing out of huge swaths of the game's story.The gameplay is flashy and nice. The vehicles are awesome but you'll find yourself falling into a successful routine and ignoring the game mechanics that are introduced later in-game. There's just not enough space to breathe and explore these new styles of play. Kharak lacks the replay value of the previous games.While I honestly can't see myself revisiting the game on it's current merits, I feel Blackbird took a step in the right direction. It ain't a retread. Ground-based combat was refreshing. It opens up new avenues in the future.Luckily for us Homeworld fans, Deserts of Kharak sold well enough. That's the takeaway for me. The game is a servicable successor, but most importantly, I haven't been more excited about the future of the franchise in a very long time.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
 An (awesome) indie game with the price of an AAA game First of all, I feel bad for not recommend this game, the game is great, RTS at its finest, complex, hard, offers variety of strategic... is the best RTS I've played since Supreme Commander. The campaign (isn’t mind-blowing anyway) has a great atmosphere, the feeling of being on an expedition in the middle of nowhere, with everything against you. That sense of rush while you're collecting resources for example, not knowing when an enemy patrol may appear through the dunes. Had a great narrative, a superb missions design, the video sequences have a magnificent design (like drawn with a brush, a speed painting between 2D and 3D), an incredible soundtrack... And an interesting plot.So why i cannot recommend it? Like the title said, is an indie game (sometimes even one on early access) overpriced. There's a important lack of content for the price its cost. You can beat the awesome campaign in less than 8 hours... and there's no more to do. There's not many units (and not very different aesthetically), only one campaign, the scenarios are incredible (but are similar, ok, a vast desert, you know), the HUD is an schematic and insipid 2D (you don't need to see how the pilots move inside their vehicle like on Starcraft 2 of course, but it makes it quite clear what kind of game it is), the units doesn't speak too much sometimes... Of course you got the skirmish and multiplayer (in fact you just need to look the achievements of the game to see it is the main feature), but only two factions, well, to be fair they're the same with different skins... less than 9 maps and of course only 4 game modes (almost identical)... and by the way, the online mode is dead.And well... now, they just released a DLC...6.99 to add 4 vehicles to the online mode... well 4 skins more or less. So... again a very overpriced stuff. This is not the correct way to make better the game, or even to bring back a game focused on the online mode. The game need new campaigns, offline campaign.The game is great, if you like the original Homeworld you will love this (the game is a mix between Supreme Comander and Ground Control with the Homeworld greatness), if you are a fan of real RTS you will love it too, I do. But the game is not worth that price (25-30 is recommended price, IMO), if you only can buy a game... look for another or wait for a discount (a big one), if you don't care about overpriced games, go for it.

content:
Posted: February 24
												I wanted to give this a good review, but the developers failed so entirely, that it just isn't justified.  At the core of it, this is your basic desert themed RTS.  The only features to set it apart from C&C or the "Craft" games, are persistent units across missions, and the fact that your base is mobile.  These two gimmicks are really all that sets this game apart from the herd, and, if executed well, they'd be enough.  The problem is, the developers have shown NO concern with fixing launch day issues.  I waited a year before writting this review, hoping they'd finally fix them, but there are still glitches, identifed within the first week after launch back in January of 2016, (search "mission 4 sandskimmer bug" in the forums,) that were acknowledged over a year ago by the developers, but were NEVER fixed.  Oh, sure, they'll spew out overpriced DLC that offers next to no content, but they won't fix game locking issues, issues that force entire mission restarts.  Do to the nature of this one bug in particular, if you're unlucky, you could end up restarting and playing through the same mission fifteen times, and hit the same snag every single time.  It makes the mission simply impossible to beat, since there is an enemy unit spawned that counts as an objective unit, but has no health bar, cannot be damaged and cannot be targeted.  You can park your entire army on top of it, you can force fire at the unit, doesn't matter, it's invincible.  Or, you could get lucky, and play the entire campaign without ever experiencing it.Now, again, by itself, thats just a bit of bad programming.  It happens.  The problem is, that they've known about this bug for OVER A YEAR, and done nothing to fix it.  Bugs are acceptable.  Refusing to FIX indentified bugs, after over a year, isn't.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												The story behind Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak’s development is a bit of a strange one. It started as a Homeworld-inspired project being developed by ex-devs of the original games, with the obvious difference of it being a ground-based RTS instead of a 4x space-strategy title. Yet events conspired to land the Homeworld license in Blackbird Interactive's hands, and instead of starting on a new project, they opted to retroactively fit their existing title into the universe as a prequel. What they have created feels surprisingly authentic, with gameplay mechanics and atmosphere that emulate the lonely, haunting, vaguely middle-eastern experience that characterizes the series.Continue Reading [www.newgamenetwork.com]

												As I eagerly launched this title. I had a nostalgia hit me from the series.It felt like a Homeworld game and sounded like one with the superb voice acting, Excellent music and accompanied by beautiful cutscenes. The only downside however was the uninteresting backstory lore of the game and lack of depth in strategy from the opponent. The game is fun and the multiplayer works however there is a shortage of good maps seen. The game is as good as a Homeworld game can get as player control Rachel S'jett along with the coalition to battle the Galsien empire to reach the anomaly before they do on the dying world of Kharakcont... Video Review 


YouTube™ Video: Homeworld Desert of Kharak 

			Views: 593		

			I beaten it, was it worth it? Kinda it felt like homeworld in terms of storytelling but the game was just decent. I expect better and a sequel to homeworld in the future.		

 Pros + Great soundtrack as always from the Homeworld series along with top notch voice acting+ Battlechatters between units and acknowledgments as the battle wages between two factions the Coalition and the Galsien on the dying planet of Kharak.+ Graphics looks good and not too overly done, the game runs really well and feels optimized. Though the texture could use more work but overall the environment of the world of the dieing planet Kharak is full of sand, dunes, tornadoes, and sand storms adding the feeling of immersion.+ Units animations such as leaving sand dust when they speed up or blowing up leaving debris and black sand is enjoyable to watch when zoomed in or when units jump over giant dunes.+ Cutscenes are beautiful and top notch with cinematic watercoloring type of art along with in game cutscene that adds to the storytelling.+ Easy to understand unit counters accompanied by a great tutorial that explains how to play the game and use the camera+ Good ui and not overly cluttered along with easily understandable hotkeys.+ Multiplayer matches are fun and easy to understand in two modes, carrier destruction or capture the artifact. Cons  - Story was uninteresting and left new players left out on the lore without much proper explanation of the situation one has to be a fan to understand what exactly is going on.- Ai in campaign does not respond to your units engagement types and literally cannot counter you, They are also set on predetermined pathing so if you die a mission, you can reload and test yourself and see that they will always go in the same directions or send the same units for situation even on the hardest difficulty. Not entirely dumb but needs rework.- Hardest difficulty beaten in seven and a half hours. Without rushing and played by veterans.- Cannot bind your keys though will not be a problem for those familiar with strategy games and can learn, the issue will be for left handers and others who cannot put up with the control ( THIS IS A SITUATION THAT CAN BE PATCHED!)- No units formations like in the original Homeworld series. (ie no formations at all so your support units can end up in the front and or too far from range to heal your units which sucks. You'll have to manually set them up in position.- Multiplayer is very lacking only 5 maps total to fight against your friends/enemy. Hopefully more will be added or a map editor of sort so that we'll have more maps.- Lack of strategy depth for unitsIn conclusion for those of you who are Homeworld fans you'll like the game, it is good but its not great. I am awaiting a sequel and hopefully see more improvements to Homeworld itself. It is a fun casual game to play online as well as an enjoyable narrative game with a short campaign without overly complex units and strategies. At best it is up to the multiplayer if this game will continue on living but even then the lack of multiplayer modes and map is undesirable and only time will tell if the game will withstand the test of time. There aren't many strategy game these days but this definitely isn't the worst. Hopefully future patches will improve it. Wait for a price drop or get it if you are eager to just play something.

number of helpful: 58 of 89 people (65%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Firstly you will note that I've chosen not to recommend this game so I will briefly summarise why that is the case.As a prequel for the Homeworld series this game does live up to its predecessor in relation to the campaign and overall presentation. The story flows well, the cut-scenes are well done, and the tasks in the missions offer some variety. The story itself, as you may no doubt have guessed, follows the progress of the 'Expedition' refrenced in the very first opening sequence of the original Homeworld game. This game wasn't developed by Relic but that certainly doesn't show, at least when it comes to the single player campaign polish.Other than the single player campaign, the rest of the game leaves a hell of a lot to be desired. The fact that the campaign is only 13 missions long, the first practically being another training mission, in-and-of-itself, doesn't help. Regarding the multiplayer side there are only 6 maps at present to play skirmish games on. When it comes to skirmishes against the computer, the AI in this game is very underwealming and not challenging at all. As for playing against other human opponents there doesn't appear to have been much uptake of this game from other players from a multiplayer perspective as I have searched for nearly an hour trying to find a ranked game, and public lobby games are few and far between.All in all, if you're a fan of the Homeworld series I wold recommend waiting until this game is on sale at at least half the price. As things stand its not worth the money for a single player campaign with barely any multiplayer support or community,

Posted: December 27, 2016
												If you're a fan of the Homeworld series and don't care about multiplayer, get this game.   Granted the multiplayer exists; it is dead and I have never seen more than about 10 players online at a time.  Local skirmishes are decent.That said, this may be my favorite RTS single player campaign ever.  While the story is so-so, the voice acting, missions, graphics, and gameplay are outstanding.  You will catch yourself staring at your pack of LAVs bouncing over dunes just for how good it looks.  Little things like panicking chatter on the radio during a battle and the eerie music add to the experience.  It is very rock-paper-scissors as far as unit balance goes, but IMO anything much more complex balance-wise and you're into a StarCraft II RTS sort of game (which is very good in its own right).Some other reviews talk about a "game-killing" bug in the 4th mission, I have played through it three times and not had a problem.  Perhaps the devs fixed it.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Don't usually do extensive reviews, but thought i would do one since i have a great feeling for this game. This will be short, but certainly will update as i progress more into the game. Thumbs down, Thumbs up or skip as you please after reading, no hard feelings here. First and foremost i personally think this game is amazing! I am having a blast with the campaign and the story is actually really fun & exciting. Even the 'cutscenes' are great to watch.. it's like a mini movie getting you pumped before the mission, feeding you with emotions so that you try your best to save 'X' people and do 'X' mission. I will not get to much into the graphics because im not fussy with them. - Graphically, the game is stunning..   i am playing  1920x1080 with all graphical settings set to Ultra, and i must say i am blown away with the amount of detail they have put into the maps, terrain, units and just everything! Even when you zoom down and you can see your units up close and personal, you notice the small details and just appreciate the work they have put into each and every object to make it look very realistic and sophisticated. Ahh.. The lighting and shadows are spot on! It gives you that extra 'real life' feeling to it, i can't explain it much more than that, but everythings looks great so far. My PC specifications for those wondering: 

Processor:-    Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-2600 CPU @ 3.40GHz
Video Card:-   NVIDIA GeForce GTX 780 Ti
Memory:-       16 GB Ram
Resolution:-    1920 x 1080
Operating System:-   Microsoft Windows 10 (build 10240), 64-bitCampaign/Story - The story so far is actually exciting, and for me that's hard to find in a game. Truth be told, i don't tend to finish many campaings on any game i play.. Usually i just jump straight into Multiplayer and later on try the campaing, don't like it and just go back to playing the Multiplayer section, but 'Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak' has already gotten me hooked.. I for the first time in a long time have just enjoyed playing the campaign and not even thinking of joining an online game. Why? the story line.. like i have said, it's amazing and really fun with some awesome mission, some are simple and some are hard. Also i do suggest giving the tutorial a go for new players, if no you'll have a hard time adjusting to the game when either playing the campaign or multiplayer.Another thing for now that i shall mention, terrain. It's great to see an RTS game add realistic areas(I'm not saying other games have not done so in the past), for example.. If you are planning to attack a target, you can't just select your units and tell them to attack 'X' units.. Sometimes you have to put them on higher grounds because the terrain isn't always  flat.  Even the smallest hill will make your units just shoot into the sand and do nothing, thus why having to put them onto the perfect location so they can fire and hit their target and have an advantage, and at the same time getting a little cover. This really does give the maps/game the complexity that games like this need. Another thing i love, is with certain heavy tanks you can now 'smoke screen' an area to cut off long ranged attackers hitting your units, this means the enemy has to bring the heavy tanks closer and will make them vulnerable to attack, or make them wait out the smoke and that will mean they're useless for that short battle! Simple things like this make you think!  it's great. Like i said, ill keep updating this review.. but for now this is all i have. Hope this does help for anyone thinking of buying the game - This is more so the positives of the game, because i have not encountered any big negatives thus far.. so i suggest reading other reviews if this has not satisfied you. Some Gameplay of the first two missions, thought this would also help to choose if you like this sort of game style or not. Mission One:

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												I don't usually write reviews, but this game disappointed me so much I couldn't help it.So let's get right to it.Campaign: The only thing positive I have to say about the campaign is that I liked the art style and feel of the cutscenes. They are a mix of the lineart Homeworld cutscenes and A Scanner Darkly. Very imaginative and unique.The rest of the campaign is trash. The voice acting is atrocious. Whoever voiced Rachel sounds bored, even when finding the most amazing technologies ever seen by man. The writing is just bad and gave me no feel for the characters or the mission itself. Actually, when the game ended, I wasn't even expecting it. It was a bland.."that's it?". Not even Homeworld 2 was this bad.Music: Probably the best part of the game.Gameplay: Ohhh boy. This is not Homeworld guys. This is generic ground RTS. You have the standard rock paper scissors gameplay, your airstrikes, and some abilities. That's it. Unit variety is nonexistent. The game is about unit positioning and "the high ground" but everything moves so slow the battles are usually over before you manage a move command. Then there's the fact that there are no unit formations whatsoever. So, pray tell, what's the point? The entire mechanic seems half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and incompleted.And it's buggy. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥is it buggy. I had my carrier launched into the stratosphere because it couldn't fit a path not once, not twice, but thrice. To see a billion ton piece of metal flipping through the air is comical and rage inducing. Units that clip through the ground, never to be seen again, dunes that sometimes block shots but sometimes let them inexplicably through. What the hell is this?I didn't get to play the multiplayer part. I'm just to disappointed to try it. Forget it.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Great game, especially for fans of the original 3 games. I strongly recommend it if you like RTS campaigns or mature sci-fi stories.+ Good story. Playing this after LotV reminded me that RTS campaigns don't actually have to have garbage plot and characters.+ Excellent music and audio, especially the dynamic unit chatter. Why can't all sci-fi strategy games do this?+ Excellent art design as one would expect from this series. Nice graphics overall, once I figured out I needed to manually tell NVIDIA to activate my video card (the game defaulted to integrated graphics)+ Comes with HW and HW2 remastered for free!+ Solid gameplay. Compared to HW2, elevation and line of sight partially make up for the loss of the z-axis. Heavy units aren't as overpowered as in HW2, while turrets and motherships are far more interesting.- Poor long-term value. I would have liked a longer campaign with more factions and the skirmish mode is bare bones with few options or maps. Devs have promised more content for free, we shall see.- No in-game pause, only pause to menu.- No official modding support as of yet.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												Those that experienced the original Homeworld game back in 1999 were in for a real treat, with the epic story much like the modern Battlestar Galactica series. A slower paced RTS game with intriguing reverse difficulty and epic lengthy capital ship battles. Whatever you complete your mission with is what you start with in the next mission. And Homeworld was purely in space, and it had some control issues as it wasn't common to play an RTS game in pure 3D space.This new Homeworld prequel is a fantastic experience, but plays just like the original -- except everything is on land, thus 2D and easier to control. I recommend playing on hard, for the full experience. I would have to frequently reload an old save if I made a major tactical. But as a fellow game developer with a lot of RTS experience, BBI have done a most impressive job using the Unity engine and putting together the complete package. It performed well with max settings at 2560x1600 resolution.

number of helpful: 61 of 101 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak takes the classic space RTS gameplay of the original Homeworld games and brings it down to the ground. Namely, the endless desert of Kharak. The result is a refreshing take on the RTS formula with superb art direction.I really love the way this game looks. The mix of the rugged industrial motifs of the ships traveling through the desert and the naval iconography of the aircraft carrier on wheels (which is an idea I just love!) works supremely well. I specifically really adore the fact that the UI is modeled to look exactly like what you would imagine the characters in the game would be looking at on their computer screens. Art and design on this game is top notch and make this game stand out from other RTSs, while still hearkening back to what made the art of the original Homeworld games special.I also very much like the combat. The two factions in the game are similar enough that you can pick up the other pretty quickly if you've learned one, but also different in very cool ways. The Coalition is great at defending particular locations; they can build turrets and must build stationary logistics modules to increase their fleet. The Gaalsien, in contrast, are all about mobility and covering the map. They can produce units from multiple locations simultaneously and their units generally are quicker and more mobile. They also do not need static logistics beacons because they upgrade their fleet capacity as research on the carrier.All of these factors and the "Battlestar Galactica"-esque campaign make for a great complete package. I think this is going to be one of the strategy games we talk about for years.See more about the game and my opinions in this pre-release video:


Getting Started in Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak 
A Video of Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak
By: Vickriman

			In this video, we are going into the basics of Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak. This is part tutorial, part first look at this new RTS, set to release on January 20th.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
Product received for free
												This review is spoiler free.  However, it is only a review of the campaign game.  The game wasn't interesting enough to explore the other factions after finishing the campaign and the multiplayer is dead.  I will disclose that I recieved this game as a gift.  I probably wouldn't pay more than $20 for it myself given the content.Overall Score:  5/10  average, or 6/10 slightly better than average for homeworld fansNutshell:Homeworld: DoK has interesting setup and lore, but is overall too short with an unsatsifying, rushed ending.  Its gameplay is fairly average and uninspired with only one or two unique features, playing like an offshoot of C&C that wants to be a Homeworld game.  Its not bad though, just average.Full:Overall, I got about 11 hours of gameplay in, and that was on medium difficulty with a few failed missions and sometimes really drawing out missions to get resources.  I'd say the actual campaign time was at most 8 hours.Campaign:Story is pretty entertaining, but many things are left unexplained.  It feels like the developers set up this rich world with rich culture, but we're never really able to explore it.  Regardless, the game ropes you in with the supposed promises of lore.  Entertaining that is, up until the second to last mission, where everything accelerates to light speed and things are over before you can even blink, leaving a LOT of unexplained lore.  A very rushed ending, but up until that point the game was pretty cool.Another irritating part of the campaign is that when all objectives are completed, the mission immediately ends, giving you no chance for fleet maintanence or post-objective resourcing (there is no autocollection like in Homeworld 2, thank goodness).  This was largely the most irritating part of the campaign.Lore wise, the Galsien where pretty cool, and I loved their deification of the antagonist of Homeworld; very neat lore trick.  Another neat thing is how they consider the sands so sacred that they never set foot on them.  All their units hover... hell their religious leader isn't even allowed to stand and constantly sits on a suspended hammock.  They're cool!I also loved the reflection of the Kushan in the unit design of the Coalition.  Very slick.The cinematic artstyle was also.. amazing.  I really wish there was more of it.  I really do... its a shame that the campaign cuts off so suddenly.Gameplay:Gameplay is kind of bland, feels like a clone of Command and Conquer with very similar units and system, but there are no buildings like in homeworld.  If you've played a C&C title or something like it, there isn't much different here.  From here on out, I outline specifics of the unit system.  On the whole, the gameplay feels lacking in many departments, because there really isn't much going on beyond the C&C copying and the sensors manager.I didn't like how weak the resource operations were, but thats a split off from homeworld 2.  There was also a distinct lack of fast hit and run units (only 1) and capital ships (only 3, 2 of which are super-specialized), which is unusual for a Homeworld title.  The rock paper scissors between units was... too simple.  Light swarm vehicle beats artillery, artillery beats vehicles, flak vehicles beat light swarm; aircraft beats everything, with some resistance from anti-air; everything on the ground kills anti-air.  You have a choice of either smaller heavy vehicles or capital ships for the flak and artillery roles.  There aren't a lot of ships, and they are all super specialized except for the hit and run cruiser, which is the most balanced unit in the game in terms of what it can do.  There are no units specialized in taking out carriers, which is again unusual for a homeworld game.  They are absurdly powerful, requiring entire armies pushing everything they have against the things, and given the mechanics the carriers are very powerful on offense and defense.  Another irritating mechanic is that unlike in previous Homeworld games you cannot store your troops in your carrier.However, I did like how you could customize the power systems of your carrier; that was a neat mechanic and fun to play around with.  Baserunners were also the coolest unit in the game, and it shows, but they're not distinctly ground breaking.Research was broken; without a tree to visualize what you are doing and with SO MANY THINGS to research, its very irritating to maintain.  There are like, 4 or 5 different research techs for every single unit.From what I can tell, Galsien faction (enemy) has stronger ground units and ground production facilities.  However, Coalition has much stronger aircraft and have access to baserunner abilities (probes, sensors, etc).  To give the game credit, they're actually more differentiated than the Kushan / Hiigaran and Taiidan / Vaygr in Homeworld 1 and 2.Sound:Soundtrack was varied and great, evocative of the Homeworld games.  Fit nicely, however none of the tracks really stood out to me.  Unit sounds are largely satisfying.  Unit chatter has a lot of depth and is fun to listen to, and I don't think I ever listened to all of the different chatter samples throughout the entire game.  They gave much needed depth to the lore and unit cohesion, but alas the game was still lacking in the lore.Bugs:The only major bug I came across is that occasionally when there are too many units on the screen the unit AI will completely stop working, requiring a load to a save.

number of helpful: 13 of 16 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												A true, modern Homeworld experience, BBI did a great job.The campaign, though only moderately lengthy, is fantastic. Great cutscenes, story and progression. The whole way through the singleplayer is a blast.The combat in Kharak is simplistic but well refined, and follows basic unit-counter mechanics alongside the strategic use of the terrain itself (line of sight and height advantages). It's also awesome to watch a clash of assorted dune-machines blast away at each other, presentation is top notch. The atmosphere this game has with its audio is also second-to-none in the RTS department.Unfortunately the multiplayer community took a large and rather devastating explosive warhead on launch when the game was tied to Steam region-based matchmaking servers. This region-locked the community, and alongside a few multiplayer connection bugs that prevented games starting in the first place the online playerbase plummeted, you couldn't reliably find and play a game. A shame this is, as Kharak's multiplayer is actually really good. It's a fast paced, skillful and sleek tactical RTS arena. Due to the (now fixed) initial multiplayer launch issues and resultant lack of players, if you want to have a multiplayer game you'll need to go hunting for people in the forums or on steam etc. I have accumulated a small bunch of Steam friends who I can play a game with on a regular basis, but you need to go hunting, trying to search solo will net negative results. Ultimately I would recommend Deserts of Kharak to any fan of the Homeworld series or RTS genre, although perhaps not at full price. A game you should pick up during a sale without hesitation.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Well I played the original Homeworld back in 199something! I haven't played any others since, though I was most pleased that I decided to pre-order at the last minute before launch to pick up the Homeworld Remastered (plus originals). Kudos to Blackbird Interactive for following their hearts and kudos to Gearbox for picking up the whole franchise in the first place (I'm glad someone there saw the potential).I'll keep this review short and sweet. I'm not a huge RTS player, though I used to enjoy the C&C series (last one being C&C generals). This is Homeworld, without a doubt, The story is great, the camapign is well designed, the art style is spot on, the sound sfx and voice acting are solid. The music perfectly retains the music of Homeworld while placing you neatly into location - The Deserts of Kharak. Pro tip for campaign; play on classic and keep your fleet persistance!The Good:Campaign, story, cutscenes, everything about it screams Homeworld, I loved every minute of it!ArtSoundMusicGameplayLoreMultiplayer: Artifact mode is a nice twist, plenty of maps (11 so far), good skirmish options such as 1 vs 3 AI etc, Co-op vs AI.Subfaction DLC's are amazing worth buying.Game replays.Great development team behind the title very responsive to feedback!The bad: No mod tools or Steam Workshop as of yet (still early days)If you're a fan of the franchise and/or RTS genre in general, I don't think you'll be dissapointed.

number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Take Homeworld's fleet management, combine it with Ground Control's tactical use of terrain and unit abilities, and you've got Deserts of Kharak. Set in the period of time leading up to the rediscovery of the Hyperspace Core, it acts as a prequel to the original Homeworld, and has all the atmosphere you'd expect from a Homeworld title.While the campaign is short (I finished in approximately 14 hours, in no particular hurry), the plot is enjoyable and did manage to spring a surprise on me, and the missions throw you the occasional curveball, such as commanding a team operating independently of the main body, with no production facilities. Overall the gameplay is fun and engaging, although I cannot comment on multiplayer as I'm terrible at RTS and just stomp computers while watching pretty explosions.Unit designs and animations are generally quite good: enemy units explode most satisfyingly, Light Attack Vehicles catch air off the tops of dunes when using speed boost, Baserunners open hatches to drop turrets and sensors, and the carrier launch and recovery sequences have an intricate detail that I just can't help but zoom in to watch. This does make the lack of resource harvesting animations a bit disappointing, however.Sound design is superb, especially the chatter. During a slow period in an early mission I heard the engineering crew of one vehicle have a friendly argument with their commander.My only real complaint is that the main camera doesn't let me zoom out as far as I'd like, so I spent much of the game in sensor view rather than enjoying the desert landscapes, but the developers appear to be taking an active interest in feedback and player suggestions, so there's a good chance this may be fixed.If you liked Homeworld and/or Ground Control, you should buy this game.

number of helpful: 12 of 15 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16
Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is the latest installment in the Homeworld franchise, albeit a prequel to the story of Homeworld, and in my honest opinion it is indeed a game worthy of the title. The graphics are astonishing all thanks to the Unity Engine and, even though I'm not the biggest fan of Unity, in this title it really holds strong and you wouldn't notice at first that it's being used. The story is great with a couple of twists and turns but I wish the ending would be a little longer. Still, diving right into the first Homeworld after playing this one is recommended. Sound design is also a big plus mainly due to the original composer, Paul Ruskay, being back to record.A special acknowledgment goes to the cutscenes which fit in perfectly. Real live people and, what looks like, hand drawn pictures combined with 3D renders really give the game a certain natural feel.That being said the game is far from perfect and has quite a few bugs and issues and some experience them more than others.Even though no updates have been posted for months (though BBI have been teasing for something at the beginning of 2017, perhaps an expansion? ) this still feels great and as a fan of RTS I certainly had my fun.What I liked:- Great story - Amazing graphics (Unity is much greater than I though in the right hands)- Excellent sound design and music Neutral about it:- Campaign was not very long.- Ending felt a bit short, would love some sort of expansionWhat I disliked: - A few annoying bugs (here's hoping they get fixed in the next update, whenever that occurs)- Multiplayer issues- In some regards it feels unfinished and unpolished- Some performance issuesI'm really hopeful that this game won't be abandoned for good, because with a few updates (and maybe an expansion) this could become as great as the original Homeworld games.  Final Rating 8/10

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												Deserts of Kharak is probably one of the best RTS games I've ever played. You woudn't think the Homeworld formula would survive the transition from space to land, but somehow BBI pulled it off. What's left is an ingenious mix of Homewords 1 and 2, Ground Control, and some SupCom. This is defintely a great Multiplayer RTS.Combat has some rock paper scisors elements, but empthasises micro. Almost every unit has a special ability, which if used correctly can greatly augment its ability to do damage, take it, or support other units. Managing your fleet over the course of an engagement is a rapid fire exercise in getting your positioning right to ensure your damage potential is maxed, managing said abilities, deciding which tech to pursue, and reacting to the enemy. Central to all this is your Carrier. IMHO the DOK Carriers are the best 'player' unit I've ever seen in a game. Not only do they manage research and production like the HW Mothership, they're also an extremely viable combat unit if upgraded throughout a match and paired with a good support fleet. They also act as a resource dropoff and the hangar for your air force, so positioning them is critical as well, in fact you'll probably roam your carrier quite a bit. It's always a sign of a fun and even DOK match when you can end with a carrier showdown. Or with careful placement of artillery and railguns you can snipe them from range, but this requires time and resources.Singleplayer is good. The story is well told and the cutscene art is beautiful, but it's short. If you're familiar with HW lore or at least the first game, you'll enjoy it. If not, then some of the impact of events can be confusing. The Expedition guide (sold as DLC) can expand on the lore greatly, but I'd only reccomend that for diehard fans who love the fluff. Other than that, there's skirmish with the AI. AI got patched recently so that it's not just a poor cheating system, so that can be a good introduction to gameplay. Skirmishing has questionable longevity though.Let's talk other content: The number of maps has gone up since launch, but there is still only 1 3v3 map. If you're playing MP, most of your matches will be on it. BBI is working on new maps and other content, but until that changes don't buy if you like map variety. I can live with it because I love the gameplay, but YMMV. There are 2 factions: Coalition and Gaalsien. Coalition are hard hitting, Gaalsien are fast and can build units quicker since they use crusiers for production. Both are fun to play, but most people play Coalition. Both have different versions of similar units, all with different abilities. There's also the Soban fleet pack now, which is based on the Coalition, and a potential future pack which could be  Gaalsien based. Finally, you can't rebind keys, which may be a deal breaker for some (theres talk about fixing that, however).Overall, I'd reccomend DOK to anyone looking for an RTS that differs from the usual formula. If you like Homeworld, you've probably already bought DOK. The community isn't large, but there are more than enough people who play regularly to get a full match going. I've had immense amounts of fun with the game as it is, more than enough to justify the purchase, and future patches and expansions will only make the game better! But if you're still worried about the amount of maps or any missing features (Spectating, Keybinding, Etc.), I'd reccomend keeping an eye on the game and holding off for a future sale. If you love RTS, you owe it to yourself to go carrier hunting sometime in your life!
