number of helpful: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												How Homeworld Deserts of Kharak Solved StarcraftIt's becoming more difficult to spot a really good game. Some studios have such sprawling resources and can afford to crank such incredible amounts of content into a game that it's easy to overlook quality in the absense of quantity. I think this is abundantly the case with Homeworld: Deserts, which seems to get a bad wrap for a short campaign and a comparably thin assortment of units. I can't say with any certainty that I would have given it a fair chance myself if not for the fact that Homeworld and I go way, way back. But I've enjoyed it immensely well after 100 hours in, and the best way I can think of to explain why is to compare the game with the analogue in RTS that I know the most about: Starcraft... or perhaps more specifically, Starcraft II.I've already harped on the thing that puts Deserts at a disadvantage to Starcraft - it simply doesn't have as much content. There are 4 factions in the game now, 2 of which are DLC, but besides that it is tough to in any way construe that there is more of anything in Deserts than there is in Starcraft. Of course, what I really want to focus on are the things that Deserts has done that more than make up for this. In order to do that I'm going to have to point out some of what I consider to be major weaknesses (or developer blindspots) of Starcraft II:1. "The Death Ball"This term is probably ubiquitous among people who have played Starcraft II, and likely many others among the ground-based RTS genre. It's that tendency for your army to get hodge-podged into a non-descript blob of units all occupying the exact same point on the map. Starcraft has great capacity for micro-management, but anyone I've ever seen get into the late-game ends up with a blob... and ususally what decides the game is both players sending their blobs at each other and seeing whose comes out on top. Top-tier people may know how to avoid this, but admittedly that's not me. It's incredibly easy to get roped into Death Ball tactics in Starcraft for two reasons that I can see... first, that the collision meshes seem to be so supportive of it with many, many units, and secondly, that there really isn't much insentive to learn how to keep your units spread out. If anything the opposite is true... Starcraft units take up a lot of screenspace and the units in general don't have the attack range to make up for it, meaning that in order to get everything into weapons range, they almost have to be clustered, especially with all the RAMPS in the game. Now the flipside... Deserts. This game WILL teach you to array your forces in logical patterns rather than keeping them all so tightly pressed together that no one - not even you - are really all that sure what you're lobbing into the fray. Major reasons why: 1. SERIOUS AOE, 2. ranged units. As to the area-of-effect, sure there are some weapons like this in Starcraft, but they are slaps on the wrist in comparison to the ones in Deserts. If you had all of your things in tight formation and you come across an enemy gunship, artillery cruiser, or Honor Guard cruiser, it will in all likelyhood be too late for you to do anything but regret your decision, because their AOE damage is both devastating and wide enough to punch whole armies at a time. Starcraft AOE usually only punched widely enough to damage a couple of units unless the targets in question were extremely small, and few punched with the ferocity of Deserts AOE. Then you have your ranged units. Range is serious business in Deserts, with some units being able to reach considerably farther than the size of your screen in top-down view. But the premier ranged unit - Rail Guns - are so incredibly fragile that merely parking tanks in their midst is usually not enough to avoid taking losses. You want tanks or light attack vehicles out in front where they can sweep would-be counter attacks, and moreover, you NEED them there, because the sensors range of rail guns doesn't even begin to reveal the distance that they are able to shoot. Ranged units are only at their best when they have a line of forward units to spot for them. And because of the various iterations of AOE mentioned earlier (many are ranged attacks as well), you're even better advised to deploy your ranged units with a wide berth from each other. The result is intense micro and positional tactics, both of which are reinforced by several other game mechanics as well.2. ScaleStarcraft is sufficiently fun that it's easy to forgive their wildly impressionistic and cartoonish sense of scale. If they didn't have the incredible cutscenes to remind you of the real size of things you might never think of it. But the thing that's impressive by contrast about Deserts is that it proves there is no need to fudge size and physics to have a good strategy game. Your production vessels are actually capable of nesting the units they build and you get to see them come down exit ramps/landing strips and everything. This concrete sense of scale and adherence to physics (you will see great execution of physics in hit effects and pathing [watching a baserunner make a reverse two-point turn is a thing of beauty]) makes you feel like you're conducting real battles rather than just abstractions of them; you're assured that the cutscene world (which is actually the more impressionistic of the two) and the gameplay world are one and the same.3. Chokepoints and TerrainI mentioned SC ramps eariler. Choke points are one thing... SC's ramps keep you down to like 2 units astride. This is but another thing that causes the game to always gravitate toward a Death Ball (or in this case, kind of a Death Snake(?) I guess). And these ramps are everywhere. I can't even think of a map where your base is not on a raised platform or in a valley or in some spot reached only by ramp. This is getting stuck in your ways. Deserts started out with a very narrow assortment of maps, but it has grown into a wonderful selection, and each is a distinct experience in some way... they all manage to create their own challenges. Rather than always giving you the benefit of a chokepoint entry to your base, Deserts has all kinds of starting locations, including some that give substantial advantage to the attacker. Terrain is much more dynamic in general and their are gradations in topography rather than walls everywhere (there are walls too, but bear with me). These wispy hills are a major part of the gameplay, as height can afford an attacker greater DPS ("I have the high ground!"). More importantly, units behind hills lose line-of-sight and can't shoot units on the other side (unless they are artillery ships). This allows the game to create a seemingly endless array of challenges and experiences by simply playing with the shape of the map. Using the terrain to your advantage can be absolutely huge and is a considerably more gradated art of strategy than in SC.4. AtmosphereNo review of Deserts would be complete without mention of this aspect. The music, while not the best in the series, dynamically shifts based on what is happening at any given moment, becoming ambient in moments of respite and urgent during battles, and this happens seemlessly enough that you often don't notice... it's the best execution of dynamic game music that I've ever heard. The sound effects are great and filtered magnificently to reinforce the idea that you're viewing the battle from a considerable distance, as you often are. Of course if you have the camera in tight (and you are easily able to do this), sounds seem more clear and present as well. The designs of the craft are outstanding in general... they convey a sense of real-world utilitarianism and never get overly 'sci-fi-magicy'.  All these elements together are exceptionallycohesive.Out of typing space. But in conclusion: even in the long and rich tradition of Dune-Buggy-Prequels, this game is a standout!

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Deserts of Kharak is not as gorgeous and rich as Company of Heroes or even Starcraft, but still it's a charmingly looking one. Being a prequel to original Homeworld, the game tells a story of battle between two clans (Coalition and Gaalsien) that hunt some very old and powerful knowledge, hidden in a deadly desert. Not only a story connects these Homeworlds, Deserts of Kharak also descends a wonderful tribal music and stylish movies from origins. But as a game, the new Homeworld part is not about big skirmishes - it’s tidily made RTS that carefully combines different approaches and features from well-known strategy games of past. Imagine if you would play Ground Control 1 in a very lovely Dune-like desert, where Commander APC does unit production/research work and harvesters collect minerals. It's a tactical RTS with some unit heritage from original Homeworlds, where gameplay is about small armies and squads - and this will be a full description of DoK. If you are ok with it - play it immediately!P.S. Another Ground Control feature - Coalition looks like Crayven Corporation and uses wheel and crawler terradins, on the contrary while vicious red hoverdines of Gaalsien came directly from Order of the New Dawn.

												A beautiful looker for an RTS with solid mechanics and balanced Rock-Paper-Scissor-mechanics. Some flaws remain though , which are a matter of personal preferences and taste. On the good side:Balanced factions, meaningful units, beautiful terrain (even though its mainly dessert), great explosions. However, it seems to lack in content where it really matters: The campaign and the multiplayer maps. There are only FIVE maps, which is unacceptable for any multiplayer focused game. The campaign can be busted through rather easily, at least on normal. Not very punishing, little room to tackle problems your way and, truth be told, missions are not long enough to do experimenting or exploration. Hard to get your moneys worth on singleplayer alone, at least in this state.

												A solid game!I was a pretty good high-master league starcraft player.What i like about the game so far?1. It punishes hard macro early in the game, you can straight up lose if your opponent does a push2. Knowing the army composition of your opponent is vital, just massing low tier units will get absolutly rekted against a few armored vehicles. This adds a great dynamic.3. The multiplayer is brutal and unforgiving, if you ♥♥♥♥ up, you lose.Its just really solid, i don't care if its not innovative, its a great competitive game with alot of depth. Artifact retrieval, which to me just sounded annoying at first is actually a great deal of fun. The game encourages players to be active all the time, just turtling to the lategame is not an option!I've seen some reviewers note that the game is not worth the money because of its lack of innovation, hell, i don't need flashy new weird gameplay mechanics, i just want a solid competitive game that is brutal and punishes mistakes, this one does it, i hope the competitive scene will keep expanding in the coming months.The only major negative point is, if one player has a bad connection, it will pause the game every few seconds without dropping him from the game. I really hope they solve this, some matches are unplayable because of it.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												OK. I've played through mission 5. No plot related spoilers ahead, but I like the game and the background story a lot so far.First, the desert environment is beautiful-- dangerous, also, since the enemy AI seems to like to have swarms of a half-dozen units each patrolling around. Recon in force works better than sending out smaller groups to scout.Rachel is in the game as a "Baserunner", which is an engineering unit, but hers can capture enemy units like salvage corvettes used to. The generic baserunners can also build turrets for ground and anti-air, as well as mines and sensors. Rachel can make sensors, but her mines can be manually triggered or used to demolish structures for salvage.There's LAVs, which are light scouts; there's tanks (AAVs-- armored assault vehicles?), there's long-range sniper units called railguns, there's support cruisers which repair others and act as the delivery point for resource collectors. There are likely to be bigger attack-oriented cruiser types coming, but I'm just now getting some air units.Combat is fun and reminds me a lot of Ground Control, which is a pretty good thing. I think I'd like a bit more variety of units, but I'm only a third of the way in. Micro matters a little-- not so much in big battles, since unit AI chooses reasonable targets by itself-- but if you have a railgun plinking away at you from max range, having your LAVs use their speed boost ability can end the threat more quickly.The camera is great and you can zoom way in if you like; focusing on a unit works better than in Homeworld-- perhaps the ground helps give a more familiar perspective when comparing tiny LAVs to the huge carrier. For that matter, the zoom out to tactical map showing the landscape in 3D with your units having a glowing blue sensor in taken directly from HW also (including the sound effects). Seems to work pretty OK.

They look like live action, but heavily stylized to look hand drawn. But I'm not sure. Either way they are fantastic. They tried a couple times to get a "tatooine sunset" shots though... which was awkward with only one sun. But the effort was noted.The story hold similarities to Homeworld. Everything goes to hell, out in a hostile environment, isolated from back up, against impossible odds. Classic underdog story.Your units chatter back and forth about if whether or not "the storm is interfering with the infrared dynamic sensors" during lulls in the combat.Game looks and plays fantastic, I don't need to say anything else. Pretty much a classic right here.

number of helpful: 15 of 23 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												I was a huge fan of the Homeworld games back in the day, it blew my mind. While I can't say this game blew my mind, it was great to play. The controls and gameplay were solid, and having played Homeworld and Homeworld 2, despite it being on a flat plan this go round, I eased right into these controls in a heartbeat. There were a few moments where I got frustrated that ships would venture off faster than their battle group, and thus wind up in situations where they were essentially screwed and I had to bite the loss, but it wasn't an issue often. It looks breathtaking, if such a word can be used for desert landscapes, but I feel in this instance it can. I ran the game full bore, and it was smooth, no noticable drops in FPS, and at lulls in battles or resource gathering, I found myself just panning around and moving the camera just to take in the landscape. It is a beautiful game. I think the only let down was the story, and only in it's length. I threw the difficulty up to the hardest, which in this game is labeled classic, and got through it in about 16 hours. Granted, I spent the extra time gathering resources, anticipating a potential nasty and gritty pitched battle later (experience early in the game taught me to be prepared), so that adds considerable time to my play, but it still felt short as campaigns go, despite some great missions. Of note was a mission where you have to defend an ally, and I was on the edge of my seat sending support flights over to attack enemy positions and repair ships to keep my allies in the fight. Plot wise though, it was exciting to play through the prequel to Homeworld, and feel the race-against-time tension that the story exhibits. It's entertaining and fun to see the Homeworld universe lore expand through this game, and I can see them adding DLC or another game playing out the political landscape of Kharak more. One thing of note: Multiplayer. I gave it a shot...but, and this could just be it's a Saturday night, no one was on. I mean no one. I could not find a game to save my life. I hope this is just a fluke, because it would be exciting to play online, but that was my experience. We'll see.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												This game in it's current state I can not reccomend under any citcumstances for a price of 45€!Why? It does not meet the standards of modern RTS games in any way. Let me give you a list of missing features that make this game absolutely annoying:-- first and foremost, no remappable keys!! I gather from the forum these have been requested like 5 month ago and not implemented yet. This is MOST BASIC STANDARD as default controls are spread all across the keyboard and you ned like 3 hands to play the game properly.-- Not possible to skip the cutscenes. This becomes utterly annoying when you play at hard and have to replay missions...-- NO MINIMAP??? You have to toggle some sort of overview hitting space bar!-- AI is nonexistant, difference between hard/easy are just endless waves of enemies who obviously need no ressource managment.-- Also AI can pass impassable terrain. You set up a proper devensive position and then a scripted attack comes trough a Mountain behind you... just incredibly dumb!--Ingame menu is hidden on top left image, NOT on ESC button like on 99,999999% of all other games!! Who designed this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ UI?!-- No updates ever, as far as I have seen??-- Missions are incredibly small maps, short and easy even on hard difficulty, due the the nonexistant AI. You just need to set up long range railgun devense with several of repair and none ever comes even remotely close to you.-- very small unit variety (like only 10 diff. units) and the other faction has exactly the same ones with different names... very uncreative!pros:+ Nice graphics when you put everthing to max+ Storyline seems ok+ persistant units from mossino to mission (makes it extremely easy tho!)All in all the gaps and missing features one would expect for a game of 2016 are way too big. So I really can not recommend this game even I a really would have loved too, since there ain't many good RTS games around anymore.I guess this is the first game I will send in for refund, since I'm still below 2hrs, and I don't suppose it's getting any better from what I read in the forums.*update:====== well seems you can only return games below 2hrs gameplay AND within 14 days and I'm above that. So I guess I have too keep it. Nevertheless I would not recommend to buy it unless it's like ~5€Having it played trough now I can say it's extremely short, easy, with small maps and super dumb endless scripted AI waves. They just stop once you reach the assigned goal. Bevore that wave after wave gets pured out of the enemy ships... and reked on my already elite devenders, since you take them with you from mission to mission.Graphic designers did a sweet job, programmers were lazy f*cks and completely failed in like anything... totally not worth carrying the brand "Homeworld"They spent way too much time and effort into the 50 Steam achievements than in making a proper game for 2016.Also reading trough the comments I guess lots of them are nonsense and look like fake/bought ones to push the games status. Sadly only the negative ones really reflect the shallow and totally lacking gameplay...

number of helpful: 17 of 27 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												I had a great discussion with a good buddy of mine, a real proper journalist that writes about games for living. Can you imagine, a person like that managing to survive in Bosnia? We both do gaming reviews and he told me once I've might be suffering from something called "honeymoon period". I've googled it and discovered about specific type of behavior that happens in the first few days / weeks / months of owning something / being in relationship with someone and thinking that your new object of desire is perfect.Although I've tried to discredit his opinion and argument my way out of it, I've managed to notice real proper example of honeymooning while playing Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak. For the first two hours, everything seemed perfect. Two hours later, I've noticed a few distinctive problems. By the end of the tenth hour, I was thinking to myself - how much love do I really feel for this game?Many, many moons ago, I've played Homeworld. It wasn't a religious devotion at any length, let me assure you, but I've enjoyed it because it gave me another, new and fresh perspective on strategy genre. Remastered collection appeared, but I was a bit too busy getting it (and a bit lazy, let's be honest). It was really exciting to find out about new Homeworld title, a prequel of sort that was in the works. Although they've grounded it to desert planet of Kharak, I didn't mind at all. Every race (and story) needs a planet to lift off from. The very first thing I thought to myself looking at all those screenshots: it smells like Spice. It is soooo Dunish.And yes it is. Homeworld: Desert of Kharak screams Dune in a particular way that could appear obvious only to fans of Herbert's epic masterpiece, although there are no sandworms around. Maybe it's just all this sand that gets into your eyes and laser rifles. Campaign mode is the heart of new Homeworld title. Main storyline is enjoyable, well thought out, segmented in nice chunks that keep your attention. It also respects the legacy of Homeworld titles, but doesn't provide player with any additional information (which is fine, google it or play other Homeworld games). The voice acting delivery helps boosting the atmosphere even higher, it's AAA quality and you can't really complain about anything in that domain. I've played the campaign on medium difficulty and it proved to be JUST RIGHT for someone like me. But does that mean it's good enough for RTS fans? Nope. Although I do love RTS games, I consider myself to be a complete newbie in the genre that I've been playing for more than two decades. That being said, it would probably be wise to say Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak AI will satisfy undemanding players, but if you know every single nook and cranny in RTS genre, you should seek revolutionary challenge somewhere else.Difference between Homeworld: DoK and most other RTS titles is the fact that there's no real base building. Your Kapisi base is what Mothership used to be in original Homeworld titles. It is a moving, shooting and self-repairing giant. The whole campaign mode, this traversing the desert reminded me of latest Mad Max movie. Although I like to basebuild my way to victory, traveling, always-on-the-move base Kapisi has its own purpose. The concept of 'base on wheels' has been delivered thoughtfully. You'll be running with Coalition and be able to pick antagonists Gaalsien in Skirmish and Multiplayer modes. Although two factions in the game don't differ two much from each other and number of units is not that big, all the units are useful and most of these have additional abilities that expand their usefulness. You will unlock units while playing campaign. This way, you'll learn your way through the game without a hitch. Some people consider number of units to be a bad thing. I don't have any problem with it. Beside campaign that's done really well, additional options are skirmish and multiplayer. As for multiplayer, I've played press review and just as other reviewers, I didn't get chance to play multiplayer. What all of us could see is that game offers unranked and ranked matches, but how many gamers will compete in DoK, remains to be seen. Skirmish could in a way represent what multiplayer will offer to players. You get a chance to pick your side (Coalition or Gaalsien), your team colors, pick a map and off you go. Now, few thoughts on a skirmish. Five maps available - unimpressive number that needs to grow as soon as possible if devs really want to kickstart the multiplayer. If BBI and Gearbox can't deliver, they should release the modding tool and let people take care of lack of maps via Steam workshop. AI isn't that good, but it isn't bad either. I could easily call it lukewarm. Just like in campaign, normal difficulty suits RTS beginners like me. I would call it an entry level AI that makes you think RTS. It makes you learn the genre in a way.How much strategy is there in a game? Well, it's hard to say. Maybe it was the space, but I feel original Homeworld titles had more freedom. Truth be told, DoK offers a relatively standards RTS experience. Elevated shooting and domination from above? Seen. Hiding behind the covers? Seen. Only two scavengers per resource? Horrible designing decision."But it's all desert! What's impressive about that?" - this could be a valid question about graphic quality of the game. Well, I do think that Homeworld: DoK delivers graphically in every single way. It's dirty, sandy, it makes you believe in desperation of your convoy trying to locate its salvation. Beside already mentioned voice acting, SFX and music are spot on.To thumb it up or down, that is the question. I'll say yes because of the story and overall Dune feeling that I felt while playing. Mind that you might not get it at all because Coalition and Gaalsien socio-political relations are not nearly as complicated as those of Dune's characters. This is a solid strategy game that managed to elevate itself in several important aspects to match the name it's proudly wearing on its digital sleeve. But getting it for full price just for the sake of campaign and ocassional skirmish and multiplayer is a bit over the top. Let's all be rational here and admit none of us will get hooked on Homeworld skirmish and multiplayer longtime. Don't let me tell you what you should spend your money on, but I personally think this price tag is currently attached to trademark, not the content. If it wasn't for word Homeworld in title, most people would just glance over it in the store, laugh the price off and pass. We've seen enough high quality indie games to dissaprove with almost 50€ price tag. When it goes at least 50% off, grab it. EDIT: The review has been edited to correct few severe grammar mistakes... no matter how many times I read it...***Hey, you've liked this review? Hated it? It made you buy the game / abandon the idea of buying this game? Super awesome! Share the love and join the group here: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/libereviews Follow the curator's page here: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10953338/

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Totally brilliant, not perfect by any means, but very enjoyable. A good old fashioned homeworld story, great visuals and audio and a compelling narrative make it a lovely way to spend a day or two.If I was going to criticise I would say it's nuts and bolts are somewhat lacking, I wouldn't have complained if this was a couple of years after homeworld 2 came out, but it's not and all the bugs and not quite there yet features just aren't as acceptable. One notably annoying missing feature is the lack of formations and positioning that was in homeworld and would have made a big difference in a land based strategy game. And the UI while joyfully reminiscent of the original could have done with a bit more updating and making it really pop and could do with better group management tools to let palyers access abilities easier, that being said it doesn't really get in the way too much so that is a plus.The balance is ok, very homeworld 2 rather than 1, it would have been nicer to have a bit more nuance rather than the simplistic rock paper scissors that leave you mashing cruisers at the end. The best of the old homeworld mods that kept the game alive all added depth and complexity making even smaller units useful all the way through the game. It would have been nice for the devs to take some of that onboard with the new game.Overall its well worth a buy on it's own merit, better than any of the RTS games last year other than the homeworld remasters. I'm pretty happy with it as I would have bought it anyway just to increase the chances we get a third homeworld game, that it's actualy fun is a real plus.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												I do not recommend this at all for the price of the game there is NO WHERE NEAR ENOUGH content for the price. Cities skylines was like $30 and had $60 worth of content for this i would pay $30 no more. Now to give out the pros and the cons.Pros:1. They kept to the old ways of Homeworld story telling if not better in the animated art so kudos to that2. I like the concept of ground RTS different for homeworld Space 3d play3. Graphics about the same if not better than homeworld 2 remastered4. Great sound quality and music score for the desert enviroment not to mention a lot of voice chatter which makes it more lively.Cons:1. Styory is nice and all but still feels as though they are lacking depth to it even though if you have played the past homeworld you know the future outcome but there is not much telling of the history or about what goes on much.2. Content Biggest peice right here. Lack of unit types and use of said units. The coalition seems to have fewer units than the oposition and lack futher potential of other units. You notice if you get this the main units you will mainly use are armored assault units and rails mainly combined with air units and thats it. Railguns are really the most affective against everything except lack armor and affectivness against light combat units3. Campaign is short if played correctly seen people beat it less than the time it took me which was roughly 8 hrs. Won't spoil what happens but mainly just grinding through enemy forces.4. Higher ground includes Defense bonus too? higher ground grants damage bonus but should not in any way grant a armor bonus if anything should be less since you are a bigger target.5. Lack of multiplayer maps to 5? Really you launch the game that is a RTS with only 5 maps?6. Hud interface of Old homeworld to ground RTS bad match up why? the game controls and hud set-up is great for the space one and using arrows is good for that but would recommend WASD for scrolling on a ground rts. This makes the game a bit more difficult to play with this kind of interface for a ground rts not to mention having the right mouse button to pan the camera everywhere can get annoying when sometimes it gets stuck.7. Cannot skip a cutscene in game at all everytime i am in the mist of doing something cutscene happens and i lose units or have no control which is very frustrating in a campaign mission.8. Controling air-units is abysmal. Why? because you cannot have them all fly to one location to select them all because once they get there and there is no target they auto-return to land then you have to wait until they land and re-launch. This makes them rather difficult to control and grabing them while on the move can be hard sometimes exspecially if you don't want to grab other units while your at it.9. Gaalsien have a better tactical and more diverse units than the coalition hands down campaign and multiplayer which makes it unbalanced.Now don't get me wrong but the Concept of it is great and all but how this was excuteted is abysmal Wish i could get my refund but steams policy says over 2hrs play and no refund but if it was gamestop they would let you beat the game and bring it back and get full refund so thats a shock right there.I have played the past 3 homeworld games and yes there is 3 and this by far is the worst of them. If you really want this game i would suggest waiting until they drop the price because it is not worth $50.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Be forewarned, if you find sand to be coarse and rough and irritating and think it gets everywhere, this is not the game for you. There is sand, and more sand, and even more sand. sometimes the sand is broken up by an occasional crashed spaceship or a rock. I didn't know what to expect when I purchased H:DoK. I knew that the game started off under another name by the same people that made the original Homeworld games so that made me excited, however it also is a ground based game and not space.Overall though it FEELS like a Homeworld game throughout the camaign. It's difficulty is well done, I often felt pressed by the challenges in the campaign without becoming overwhelmed or feeling it was unfair, the story was engaging and because of it, I lost three days to beat the game because I kept coming back to it. The only thing that didn't feel like a Homeworld game to me was the manic pace the game plays at. I found myself operating three different task forces at times each needing my attention to activate abilities, optimize engagement range, and deciding whether or not I needed to drop the nuke hammer to save my forces or not.I was initially disapointed with the lack of unit variety, however the number of abilities and upgrades you can grant each unit more than makes up for it. between setting up mine fields and having a flotilla of support cruisers playing freeze tag with the enemy fleet I had a manic grin on my face the whole time. Well until I got cocky, and sent the Kapisi off by herself and she ran smack into two battlecruisers supported by repair cruisers. Imagine my surprise when the damage klaxon went off in my face and by time I scrolled over she was down to half health!Without giving away the plot or the ending, I was very happy to have purchased it. It's a must buy for any fan of the original game, and it's just fun to play.  Every unit has a counter and abilities to minimize how hard they get countered to make for a really good game of shifting tactics, much like the sands you play on.

number of helpful: 30 of 53 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												First of all I will preface this by saying I love all the Homeworld games and bought/played them when they first released all those many years ago.  I also own the remastered editions and enjoy those as well.  I also wish this review system allowed more than just a Up or Down ... but since it does I have to give it a Down because I WOULDN'T recommend this game for its full price.  So let's start off with the good.  The graphics are great.  They aren't taxing or mind-blowingly realistic, but for Homeworld they really fit.  The cinematics in the game fit well, and are a step up from the previous games.  They feature actual animation and fit in very well to the atmosphere of the game and the setting.  The music is very solid and has the normal Homeworld vibe to it.  The Rock/Paper/Scissor system used for the units is a bit standard but at the same time the units offer some more advanced options for abilities that allows greater strategic uses of unit.  Nothing crazy in-depth or complicated, but enough that you can do things like hit and run with some units.  The amount of units comes off as a bit limited at first but eventually you unlock a few more through gameplay, very similar to the other Homeworld games.  The carriers themselves are great additions to the game.  They're more than just your base of operations, they are slowly moving super units in and of themselves.  There's a system for changing up what you want your carrier to do by diverting limited power to weapons or repair systems, ect.  Still, it's a nice change from Homeworld where the mothership was little more than an anchor around your fleet's legs.  So why the "No" recommendation?  Sadly it comes down to the amount of playability I got out of it.  For $50 I kind of expected more than a 9 hour campaign.  Now I know you can play multiplayer but that's not really my thing.  I bought this game today and finished it by tonight.  I didn't rush through anything, either.  I'm fairly meticulous when it comes to the Homeworld games, to the point that I NEED to get every resource before I leave to the next level.  So my 9 hours could quite easily be closer to 7 for the non-OCD types.The game was great except for that.  I enjoyed the story, although I already knew the end (duh) and it was a bit predictable.  There just wasn't enough meat in this sandwich to garner the $50 tag.  TL;DR:  I recommend putting this on your wishlist for a sale.  I'd say a $25 to $30 price point is fair for this game.  I'll amend my review if it comes out with more content, but I really doubt that's going to happen.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Surprisingly good.Didn't expect much after the last couple games published by gearbox, but I'm too much of a consumer ♥♥♥♥♥ to not buy something with the homeworld brand and art style. I didn't think the story would work well, given what we knew from the homeworld 1 manual, etc, and the plot retcons between 1 and 2, but they definately pulled it off.Gameplay-wise, it's a nice translation of the mechanics of the older homeworld games to a 2d plane. outside of some little turrets and sensor posts, there are no structures, everything is built, upgraded, lauched, etc. from a vehicle. Units now have toggleable abilities, which I'm not actively opposed to. It's more micromanagement, but clever use of them can  make a huge difference I'm sure.The art direction is rock solid. The Galsians, especially, look fantastic. The environments are as grand as you'd expect from a homeworld game, even if they're on the ground. The sound and music fit well too.It's kind of weird that they have cool mythical sounding place names for every dang mountain and valley and sand dune when they've never been there and probably only have known about them since they launched a satellite to map the planet.Anyway, it's bretty good, would buy again.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												It was always going to be a tough act to follow the massively successful Homeworld franchise yet Deserts of Kharak copes admirably. Set on Kharak - the HW series planet of origin, the latest installment is an excellent prequel to the events of the homeworld series. Set on the harsh desert world of Kharak, the sands of said planet are in a very odd and unexpected way interchangable with the cold vacum of space from the original games; both are hostile environments inhospitable to man. This is why Deserts works so well, it retains the feel and massive scale of the homeworld universe, the art style, the lore and backstory but fleshes it out for ground combat. Would recommend for anyone who enjoyed the original HW games or to anyone who enjoyed Dune in its many multmedia guises, similarily if anyone was thinking about buying HW remastered start instead with Deserts of Kharak, then migrate into space - the RTS equivelant of doing ME 1, ME 2 and then ME 3 and keeping the same character throughout!

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Welcome to Kharak, maggots! Here you have sand, more sand, and even more sand. And luddite desert nomads trying to kill you in the name of their God.That out of the way...This game is a pretty interesting look at Kharak's past, and the events leading up to the chronicle of Homeworld as we know it. The RTS aspect is pretty good, though some may still feel it's a case of "Been There, Done That".Probably the nicest thing is that it goves some faces you can relate to. The Homeworld series is known for being pretty impersonal - not many unique characters to latch on to or to personify. This game does that by giving you quite an ensemble to relate to, and makes them, well, more human - closer to home.All in all, it's something Die-Hard fans of the Homeworld series shouldn't miss, and which newcomers to the series absolutely should play to give somebackground to the star spanning saga they will encounter.9/10 would recommend to everyone to give it a try.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												If you played and liked homeworld you will love this.If you Have not played homeworld this is the place to start. Most negative reviews seem to center around the price.Everyone has a different value for money so its hard to speak for everyone.Personally i think the game is well worth it. The production value of the campaign and the game as a whole is better then most AAA titles. IF they can charge 30 pounds for the remastered edition then surely 30 pound for a new game made from scratch is not too much to ask.The music, the speech, the graphics, and general theme of the game is outstanding.I really appreciate a game that is well polished and this is it, the little touches are what made me love homeworld and the same effort has been put into this.Just for an example the unit speech when you issue commands. Sounds like a small thing but when you are selecting and moving units constantly an annoying sounding unit can become grading. With homeworld: Deserts of Kharak you never get tired of hearing the units give out scan readings and comfirmations. Even while idle the units talk to each other, one will talk of a local reading and ask another to confirm it which they do. You will be told when enemy units are spotted when a unit dies, everything, but it doesnt feel like too much. It feels like a real warzone with alot of information being relayed.Things like that remind of command and conquer, dawn of war and some of the other best strategy games ive played.I was never one for multiplayer strategy games so i cannot speak for that. I prefer campaigns and this one is great. The cutscenes are not quite starcraft 2 but have their own charm. They create a sense of atmosphere that i have only encountered in homeworld itself. The idea of scale, discovering a large thing out in the desert and seeing one of your tiny light attack vehicle next to it. As for the actual gameplay, its smart. Homeworld had a unique style to it and this follows that path and i love it. You dont control a base as such, you dont build buildings. Instead you have a convoy. One main cruiser which produces your troops and handles research. Then other support vehicles can be built. All of your resources collected, units built, research carries over to the next mission. So you get this feeling that you are literally a convoy moving towards the main objective of the campaign, getting bigger along the way. The missions are fun, each one has a twist, starcraft 2 had a similar method which made me enjoy it so much. The mission is never just kill the enemy. You have to scan things, protect things and such. They add things like tornadoes to the mix to keep you on your toes.If you want multiplayer this might not be for you, ive heard theres not much going on with it. If you like campaigns then i would highly recommend. Its worth a try you will learn quickly if you like the style of gameplay. PLus if you enjoy it you have homeworld 1 and 2 to play.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												When I played Homeworld 2, I was peeved at the storyline and plotholes in it, compared to the first game, Cata, and my own developed headcanon.  I was also overwhelmed with so many things, so many options, but it still felt like a Homeworld game.Deserts of Kharak also feels like a Homeworld game, but as opposed to 2, I do not feel overwhelmed with options and the need to multitask so many things, and most importantly, I am enjoying the retcons and changes to the story. "The Clans were United, and an Expedition was Sent", from the original opening can gloss over so much. A few changes along the timeline to make the Northern/Southern war at the same time of the Expedition really is fine by me.The unit chatter is back and better than ever, I like how the game encourages you to conserve units, and having a Concordat Cycle that helps but does not fully hinder if you get it wrong is a bonus. Terrain for combat is starting to get interesting, although I feel this system and engine would be better served if licensed and adapted to another setting that has way more map and terrain variety.I have yet to complete this game, but it's become a very nice routine thus far to play a mission or two before getting ready and departing for work. Having no interest in playing multiplayer, the weak AI complaints fall upon deaf ears here.Of course, I'm playing on the lowest difficulty and getting my♥♥♥♥♥♥kicked at times. It's been a long while since I tried to play an RTS straight, having been over on Paradox games for the longest time. Tactical isn't my forte, Strategic is - yet Deserts of Kharak is fun and enjoyable, and unlike other games it feels like it's helping me learn how to properly use units and tactics. The missions might be getting harder, but I feel that I'm getting better as well.I don't think I've any complaints for this game at all.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												As a Homeworld fan I can tell you that this game is in line with the lore and gamplay it is a wonderfull adaptation from 3d of the space strategy to 2d.The storyline is something that a lot of RTS games would be jealous of with intrigue, deception and all out rivalry.For RTS fans this should a must have as the strategy in this game can go very far.There are some controle issue, as example your weaker units tend to go up front which means they get damaged very quick. This needs some micromanagment. As a folowup of that your support/repair vessel is all the way in the back so you have to command them closer.The origenal homeworld games had the possibility to assign groups of ships a certain setup ( Cap ships in front, Fighter screen, frigate line or cruiser line ) which can help a lot in soaking damage, next to that the setups would imrpove effeciency of the selected ship setup.This comes back to the controle issues as it would help a lot!Everything accounted for, I would still 100% recomend this as a buy, especially for an RTS fan.

												~Ground based version of the original Homeworld game.~Great graphics and overall performance at max settings.~One of the best Storys in an RTS I have seen in a long time, lots of attention to detail etc.~Great Gameplay  mechanics.~Fast learning curve, espesially for avid RTS playersThere are really only a few cons I can think of an they are pretty minor.~Game needs some Optimization in reguards to the graphics engine, slowdowns are frequent even on my FX-8370 and R9-390X with 8GB of ram all paired with a SSD.~Wished there were more missions, seemed a tad shorter then expected, none the less it was good.Other then those minor gripes I really didn't see much that bothered me while playing, they really did a fantastic job keeping the *Homeworld* feel with this game.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Definitely a fun game and worth the price of admission, manages to bring a remarkable amount of Homeworldlyness to a land-based game which is definitely nice although it does seem a bit forced at times.Gameplay is solid, though a touch shallow in terms of depth, the tendency towards the 'big ships steamroller' is still present and could stand to be toned down a bit in terms of the ease of aquisition. Given the 'all deserts all the time' asthetic I would have liked to see some more environmental hazards, sand storms that take big chunks of the map and reduce visibility and do some damage, steeper dunes actually having a chance of collapsing on units, wind managing to shift dunes around a bit.Graphics and sound are both excellent, they did a good job of making the desert seem visually distinct. The sound design was a lovely return to form.The campain was fun, not so short that I have any complaints and I'm certainly left wanting more time in the deserts after that.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Finally, a new, good looking, good playing, deep sci-fi RTS!Some of the controls I wish I could change - my only gripe, but I can overlook that.Very much Homeworld meets Ground Control. Your units are expensive and robust and thus you want to protect them - requires to you play using your brain over mindless brawn. You cannot just spam endless units to win the day, instead tactics, strategy and efficient use of a maps resources are the name of the game. Each unit has interesting little abilities and/or deployables that really add the to strategic play.And let me say this - vehicle porn - lol, the units are gorgeous to watch.  Im not ashamed to admit I lost a few battles because I was too busy watching things move, wheels turn and turrets deploy =)There is the occassional silliness of an obviously very heavy vehicle flipping end over end when going over an obstacle, but aside from my making me chuckle it doesnt seem to effect gameplay, least it hasnt for me.Also - the unit chatter, the ambient chatter - Ive never experienced something such as this in an RTS game - it feels completely alive - you can really believe all those units you're moving around have living, breathing people working inside them.My short two hours in game took me to the 4th capaign mission if I recall - and its been a very cool experience all the way.If you liked Ground Control and Homeworld, if you like RTS games, if you like the idea of a sort of psuedo Supreme Commander 'lite' (ie: no base building, but large strategic maps and terrain control, similiar play style, rock/paper/scissors style to a large degree) - you cant go wrong here.It looks great, it sounds great, the units are interesting and fun and just plain old fun to watch - I cant wait to get further in =)

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												+Great art style in both cutscenes and graphics+Everything from the sound effects to the campaign plot screams Homeworld+Excellent RTS gameplay, can get really intense at times+Units have more chatter that reflects the action+Expedition guide is full of delicious fluff-Short campaign. A little too short, in fact, and is a little unsatisfying in the end-Only two factions, not "two playable factions" just TWO factions-Missing features from gameplay (that I feel are very important): No in-game pause and no proper way of determing how units position themselves-AI is dumb as balls, once you unlock higher-tier units you can basically steamroll enemies-Very little multiplayer mapsVerdict: Unless you're a Homeworld or RTS fan then I'd recommend staying away until they add stuff in updates or it goes on sale.

												Stay away from this unfinished, buggy game where patches make things so much worse.The performance is abysmal even on fairly powerful hardware. How much more insult can you throw at your customers? How much incompetence can you willingly put out for the world to see?

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												To make it short and simple.Either you will love this game and join its fanbase or you are gonna hate it because it goes against the current standards of RTS.It's a mix of the old homeworld and COH and Ground Control. IT IS NOT A SUPCOM COPY.The Pros:- The Single Player is breathtaking. The perfect prequel to Homeworld & Homeworld 2- The Units while not numerous are well done and play well in the rock-paper-scissor scheme of any RTS.- The theme and structure is awesome. Let me repeat... is awesome. Rarely will a game suck you in and especially an RTS game.- You feel that you are a commander in the field. Not like a base builder and then send your units and thats that. Resources are scarce and tactical descions are paramount to be succesful.- My experiance is mostly on the single player with a few multiplayer games thrown in against a couple of friends and I feel the multiplayer needs a couple of mods and/or ways to play.The Cons- The keybinding issue (You can't change them) and according to the Devs they are working on it.- Unit formations needs to be looked at.- Multi has only 5 maps which is sufficient to get through the time being while more are being worked on.- Needs a couple of multi player modes... Capture the hill and tower like defence against AI?Overall: 9/10P.S. For the new comers to Homeworld... The story continues on Homeworld and Homeworld 2 which are pretty darn good in their own way. DON'T MISS THEM.

												I got this game during the winter sale an loved it big homeworld fan.The things that sucked was the game bug.None of them were game breaking and were small non the less but it picks at you.Not able to rebind keys was ♥♥♥♥ing dumb.The Unit AI control is pretty stupid-units wont auto attack if in guard mode-units wont sync there movements ( so the faster units die 1st)-when launching multiple strike craft it seem they bug out and only 1 out of 3 will attack leaving the other 2 just to fly around your carrier.-Strike craft wont split fire they all attack one unit (unless you control them manually which is hard to do since they move so fast.)I just really didnt like the unit controls i felt they half A$$ed it, with no formations or defend this area no nothing just Attack or guard.. and since they dont attack when on guard seems kinda dumb.I didn't like the camera at all either it was so close to the ground it was hard to command. A game trying to give the feeling of big but having the camera is so close to the ground so your vision is limited and if you use strice craft you dont even see them half the time... Like they fly at 50 feet persay well your camera is at 60 feet so you see them just for a momment.I'm pretty sure this is just cause i picked the hardest mission but I have a problem with the enemy AI they always go after the Hero Base Runner missile attacks the EMP's I spend half the game trying to keep that B!tch alive.Online seems to be a ghost town. content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												One of the biggest surprises of the new year is Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak, a prequel to the original Homeworld that has long remained an icon of PC-based strategy warfare titles.  DOK abandons the vast emptiness of outer space for the sand-choked deserts of the ill-fated planet Kharak, and tells the story of how the people came to locate the ancient anomaly that would give rise to their exodus towards their titular homeworld.  The switch to ground-based strategy gameplay is a definite change from the 3-dimensional tactics one could employ in space, but it's not without merit.  Here, Gearbox selects elements from Homeworld's pedigree and marries them to elevation tactics from other notable strategy games.  Thus, elevation becomes a driving force behind victory over enemy units.  It's a fanciful, albeit simplistic way of approaching combat, but it does come at a cost.  DOK's stripped down "for everyone" approach means that some important elements such as battle formations have been jettisoned, reducing the level of depth that Homeworld veterans may be accustomed too.  It's a bit jarring, and makes DOK feel more like a mini-episode in a much larger storyline.  The game focuses heavily on short and long-ranged units almost specifically, forcing players to mix up units in order to guard and attack.  Naturally, enemies can attack from all directions, and the relative shortage of resources (or should I say, compartmentalized resources) means that there isn't a lot of elbow room to establish bank-breaking fleets as seen in the original Homeworld games.  Researching new technologies is on a need-to-do basis, and therefore feels a tad linear.  The speed of the game has also changed as well.  Units build much faster, research takes far less than it used to, and enemies race in out of nowhere.  Is this an attempt to court players with less-than-stellar attention spans?  Perhaps!Ironically, it's a magnificent game despite the narrowed and more centralized gameplay mechanics.  I'm hoping that future chapters in the Homeworld saga won't go this route, but for a game set on the surface of a planet, instead of outer space, it's an admirable and enjoyable entry in the franchise.  Let's face it.  There's a criminal lack of Homeworld games for us to play, and this is the first true sequel in over a decade.  Who are we to complain?  DOK retains the signature Homeworld atmosphere, music and visual styles of previous games, and it's nice to see unit designs giving nods to what will eventually become spacefaring Kushan fighters, capital ships and destroyers.  It's like going back to the beginning to a world where little is left.  The dry sands of Kharak are a perfect backdrop for a pretty good (but not stellar) story, and a nice little glimpse into the richness of Homeworld's still mysterious storyline.RECOMMENDED!

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												If you're in any way a fan of the Homeworld series, this game will carry with it almost all of the things you loved from previous games. It's not in a 3d space, but it carries over the art style, music, design and interface. Difficulty wasn't a cake walk, but I still managed to beat the game within 9 hours. Compared to say Homeworld which required you to accumulate large amounts of units and cheese the global supply limit by salvage, and say Homeworld 2 where you could very methodicly engage a portion of the map, mine, and rebuild before going to the next mission, HW:DoK fits somewhere inbetween and I find this to be refreshing, as I was always producing units and was never given the chance to simply max my fleet out before moving on. On that note unit production is different in that for one faction in the game all of your units are produced from your "mothership" with numerous production queue's. As far as I know, there is no limit to any one unit type but rather there is simply a global supply limit and you can work in any units you wish within this limit. Research seems to provide you with numerous options that exceede the amount of resources you can obtain, so researching feels more like a choice than in previous games within the series.I could describe a lot more to the game, but I find the differences to be refreshing while still feeling like a Homeworld game even without space and my beloved ion frigates. If you're a fan of Homeworld pick this up, and if you aren't but love RTS games, I'd give this game a shot. If you like this, try out the older Homeworld games and prepare to sit with the rest of us waiting for Homeworld 3.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a true continuation of Homeworld gameplay, even if the story takes place far before the events of Homeworld 1.Many Homeworld veterans might be concerned that battles take place on land instead of in space, however all the pieces are still there:The Mothership/Flagship is now replaced by a massive central crawler that serves the same functions. You produce "capital" crawlers in the same vein as capital ships in previous titles, and use a mix of light and medium units in the same vein as Fighters/Corvettes/Frigates.Positioning is still "3D" in the sense that using proper elevation can yield significant bonuses in combat, and epxanding your sensor net and keeping intel on the enemy, as in previous titles, is key. If anything, I find the gameplay more enjoyable than even Homeworld 2, as combat is accessible, properly paced, and still leaves ample room for tactics and positioning. Graphic and sound design is SUPERB. There are FEW RTS titles that capture the atmosphere quite like this game does. Lighting and specular design is amazing, the desert maps are incredibly detailed and somehow still offer plenty of visual variety. Units are highly detailed and the wreckage and scorched earth of an engagement are satisfying. The unit chatter and tiny details in audio design only add to the effect. This is a superb evolution of the homeworld series and the RTS genre. I cannot wait for Workshop support and see what else the developer does with this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30
												"Homeworld: DoK is a good time", that's the perfect description to grant it with. It doesn't really break any new grounds, it isn't a masterpiece by any means, it's a good time... And that's absolutely fine. I liked it mostly because I feel very nostalgic for the Dune series (Emperor especially, Tribute to Evil is like the best song ever \m/ David Arkenstone, I salute you!). Another reason for my positivity towards the game: the idea of having a mobile aircraft carrier base intrigues me. Let's face it: old school RTS games have always been a bit of a drag, building the base every single mission is a chore at best. Here however, you take your base with you. Genius! The story is engaging enough as well, full of drama and intrigue to keep one's interest stimulated at all times.Now for the bad parts. The game runs like a*s, even on my extremely powerful hardware. The AI is dumb as all f**k. It also takes you ages to get anywhere, the carrier especially, because pretty much all units run at a snail's pace. The latter is the reason that I have 17 hours on my counter for finishing the campaign alone, that and I'm also a greedy b***h that wanted to collect all the resources in her way, but that's how I roll. The graphics are extremely dated, but at least the locations are always varied and interesting despite the game being set on a desert planet.In conclusion: definitely worth it, especially on sale. I'll be playing the Homeworld remaster next, how in the world have I missed the games when they were first released? A forever mystery.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												Well, here it is, the prequel to Homeworld. This game didn't start out as a Kharak story; it started out as just a new RTS game by Blackbird Interactive which consisted largely of the original Homeworld team. When the Homeworld franchise was auctioned off (again) by Gearbox, Gearbox tracked down Blackbird Interactive and partnered up with them to get their RTS game reconstructed to be a Homeworld prequel. It took all of a year or two to rewrite the storyline and plot and apply narration (etc) assets for it.The good: Beautiful game matching the aesthetics overall of Homeworld. Brillliant artwork, graphics, music, sound, narriation/acting.Gameplay mechanics very similar to Homeworld.Fun mechanics, very playable and fun game.[Barely] satisfying campaign length. (Could be longer, feels rushed, but generally satisfying-ish.)The bad:No true 3D gameplay (but definitely 3D terrain if that matters, along the lines of Starcraft)Infuriating glitches such as aircraft needing to be double-clicked (while they're moving in flight, good luck) and "reminded" to land and rearm.Auto-save checkpoints immediately precede long cutscenes that can't be skipped; you must remember to save after every cutscene if you don't want to repeat them.Plot and game ending triggers block resource collection for building up for next mission.Massive narrative plothole at ending requires a complete understanding of the first level of Homeworld 1 before can it be understood to say nothing of being appreciated.Conclusion:I have mixed feelings about this game. Overall, it's a good game, generally satisfying for the Homeworld fan, as the essential gameplay elements that made Homeworld great (other than total 3D strategy) are here. If you're a Homeworld fan, there's not enough to hate here to avoid it. You'll like it.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												The aesthetic and design of Kharak is so interesting and so unique that I really find this a compelling RTS. The storyline is the best I've seen in an RTS in a very long time; this game is (or should be) all about the single player campaign. The multiplayer is fairly standard.The thing that keeps me so intrigued by this game is the "land carrier" concept. The way it's presented, the way they show the lives of the crew and the struggle they have to go through to keep things together, reminds me a lot of the new Battlestar Galactica in its concept. I've always been a fan of huge ships going on an epic journey, weathering direct fire and scrambling fighters; this game gives you the unique ground equivalent of BSG, more or less.For anyone who enjoyed Homeworld OR Battlestar Galactica and enjoys a heavily story-driven single-player campaign, with a small amount of fun to be had with multiplayer (maybe more than a little fun if you play it with friends), I can HIGHLY recommend this game. The mechanics are tight, there aren't any serious bugs, the music is awesome, the sound effects are satisfying, and the general concept of "I'm commanding a massive land carrier that's a mobile city" is just so... AWESOME... that I'm excited to recommend this game as one of the few games that has truly given me joy in the past few years.The team who created this game should also kindly shut up and take my money for Homeworld 3 and begin development right away (if they haven't already). This is exactly the team of artists, writers and developers -- the exact people who made this game -- that we sorely need to stick together to make the NEXT epic Homeworld game. Do it. Do it now.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												A worthy addition to the Homeworld universe, the game is both recognizeable enough to be familiar, and different enough to keep me interested.Pros:- The story of the search for the 'Primary Anomaly' is interesting and a nice look back into the past of the Homeworld universe.- Gameplay, while not groundbreaking, is solid and fun. The unit strengths and weaknesses are easy to understand, without getting over complicated.- Sound is, as always in a Homeworld game, excellent. The background unit chatter makes the forces at your command more than a collection of dots on a map.- Music deserves it's own entry, it fits the tone wonderfully, giving a sense of the open waste of desert, or the thrill of combat. I WILL be getting the OST.- Unit designs are cool, from the zippy Strike vehicles, to the lumbering Carrier. Not many games get me to want to own replicas, but dammit, I want a model of that Carrier on my desk!Cons:- Occasional oddities of units moving inside of each other, mostly noticable on the Salvagers while collecting resources. Not a big issue, but it would be nice to see it patched out.- VERY rarely I would notice enemy units jerking around, instead of smoothly moving. This has only happened once however, on one mission, one playthrough. I have yet to replicate it on any other mission, or on the same mission when I restarted it.-In engine cinematics. I love them, they're well done, add to the story, and look nice... BUT YOU CAN'T SKIP THEM. Seriously, non skippable cinematics in 2016? I am dissapoint. (Yes it's a minior gripe, I know)Overall, I definitely recommend this game, even to those who have not played any of the Homeworld games before.

												Homeworld Deserts of Kharak is the Prequel to Homeworld 1, you are put in command of the Coalitions Expedition Carrier the kapisi. The mission is to retrieve the source coming from the jaraci object laying deep within enemy territory. The enemy being the Gaalsien, a Nomadic kiithid that worship Sajuuk and believe everyone was placed on kharak becuase of a dreaded sin. the kahad Sajuuk believes that going into space will anger sajuuk and bring his wrath upon the world (If you've played HW1 you know what happens) The Campaign takes you across the the harsh deserts of Kharak to the Khar-toba wreck.________________________________________________________________________________~The Multiplayer~At the moment you only have 2 main factions plus the 2 DLC factions - Coalition- Gaalsien - Soban - Khaaneph and there is some unit synergy -LAV's/ skimmers counter rail guns -AVV's/ Assualt Ships counter LAV's -Rail Guns counter AVV's and Assualt ships Soban and Coalition are the only 2 factions who have access to GunShips, so Rushing bombers as Gaalsien/Khaaneph is suicide 9 times out of 10.

												I've been a HomeWorld fan for a long time, having played through the games when they first came out and more recently the beautiful remakes (such a shame they couldn't remaster Cataclysm as well). This is just superb! Having a lot more commitments than when I was younger- well I don't tend to play many games these days and even games I love I can only justify a couple of hours tops in a session, except this. I've just forced myself to put this game down after playing it all evening. Also despite all the reviews saying the game is broken at mission 4- well I've just completed that without a problem so it is possible!If you like HomeWorld or just RTS in general then I highly reccomend as an excellent single player campaign driven title. HomeWorld games have a unique system- your army being persistent between battles and are (comparatively) slow paced compared to more frantic rts titles. A few people have commented that the computer specs are quite high for this, which is suprising given the machine I've been playing on... So far been running this on an old first gen i5 laptop with an nVidia GT 420m gpu. Admitedly I'm on minimum settings yet game still looks nice and frame rates are acceptible. I think if you have a reasonably modern cpu and discrete gpu you should be able to run this. Some of the very latest iGPU's should probably just about manage it as well.

content:
Posted: January 15
												Disclaimer: I never intended to play multiplayer in this game. This review is solely based on the single player campaign. Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is set on, you guessed it, the planet of Kharak, and is a prequel the the now classic Homeworld games. Instead of the sometimes too-complex-for-it's-own-good-3D-plane battlefields of Homeworld 1 and 2, Deserts of Kharak plays a lot more like a traditional kind of RTS, seeing as all the fighting takes place on the surface of the planet. Despite this pretty big change, it still manages to capture the essence of those great past games, with good looking animations and unit models. The story is actually pretty decent for an RTS. Centered around this lady scientist (Rachel something?) and her search for her brother in the midst of a war, it manages to hit a nice balance between a war story, and a personal narative. I really liked my time with the game, even if it was "only" the singleplayer. I got the game from a steam sale for around €16, which is a no brainer in my opinion.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												If you loved the Homeworld series, Deserts of Kharak is totally worth it, and here's why:First of all, a little backstory: the Homeworld IP was tossed around various companies for almost a decade, before ending in a bid between Blackbird (ex Homeworld devs) and Gearbox, the latter winning the auction. This led to the Remastered edition, on which Blackbird helped Gearbox quite a bit, especially with assets. In the meanwhile, Blackbird was working on Hardware: Shipbreakers, an independent title, designed to be F2P. Gearbox eventually asked them if they'd want to rebrand it as Homeworld, and Blackbird agreed. Why did I waste one paragraph writing this? Because Deserts of Kharak is NOT a well-planned,  heavily-financed AAA game. It is a haphazardly put together welcome surprise package, somewhat as a replacement for Cataclysm Remastered, not driven by profit but passion. So, in my opinion, most of the shortcomings mentioned in the other reviews can be forgiven/overlooked.Deserts of Kharak faithfully reproduces MANY themes in the original saga, such as an expedition to explore the past (immediately followed by total disaster), that determines the future; fleet balancing (that some consider the rock-paper-scissor design, but pretty much all CCGs, MOBAs, Arena Shooters, etc. are identically balanced); stellar, beautiful music; emphasis on micromanagement and rewarding effort; and a gripping, tight back-story that segways neatly into the intro to Homeworld 1. There isn't much you can do with a fixed ending, and Deserts of Kharak sprinkles enough suspense, thrill, even drama, throughout the journey to keep you engaged. DoH brings terrain-based tactical combat to the table as new gameplay, and while it works, it's not as game-changing as you'd like it to be. If you used 3D space to lay out ambushes in Homeworld, you can totally use sand dunes to achieve the same effect in DoH. Like Catacylsm, you have one very mobile carrier instead of a big mothership, which is now upgradable and quite capable of holding its own in combat, provided you shunt power to the right drives. You do NOT automatically collect resources at the end of missions, which fits the "nomads on the run" motif, IMO. Besides, unlike HW, resources aren't scattered throughout the map, but concentrated inside shipwrecks that you find on the way: the process of shipbreaking and gathering resources is challenging, especially when under constant attack (an example of the "reward effort" mantra).The game is a bit buggy, camera controls could be improved, cutscenes could be skippable, and a myriad of other minor issues that, in my opinion, have negligible impact on player experience. My harshest criticism against the game would be its pricing: it might have had more success in the $25 range. Deserts of Kharak is a well executed modern RTS (in a world dominated by MOBAs) that you should definitely try.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												I reluctantly requested a refund on this one today, even though I very much liked the overall graphics, the gameplay, and pretty much everything about it.  Unfortunately, the one thing that I didn't like was the proverbial "game killer" for me.Here's the thing: You've got a good variety of units, all of them with very nice graphics, the combat effects are quite nice - great explosions and so on -- but you can't zoom out your view far enough to really see what's going on.  To do that - to zoom out to a range where you can get a large enough picture to let you make solid tactical decisions, to see where the enemy are, and intelligently direct your forces to properly respond to the attacks -- you have to switch from the nice graphics that make this so nice to the eye into a high altitude radar-like view where all the units are little colored dots or hollow triangles moving around on a flat 2D map.  Take a look at the FIVE video clips shown on the Steam store page. You can go through almost all of all five of them and what you see are almost exclusively shots of the good looking unit graphics, a few cut scenes, and more nice closeups of units showing how nice they look. BUT to see what you'll be looking at for at least 50% of the time, jump to the 21 second point of the fifth video and you'll see the dots and hollow triangles that are what you see  every time you pan out to get a larger tactical of the full strategic view.Yes, they make it easy to swich between close up and zoomed out - just touch the space bar - but they have to make it easy, 'cause you have to spend so much time in the zoomed out view, it has to be easy to access, right?Why, oh WHY, make a game with such pretty graphics for their units, and their buildings, and then make you constantly switch to the view that robs the game of all those loveingly crafted components?  *sighs heavily*So - when someone posts a mod that lets you zoom waaay out and still see the decent graphics (they can even be tiny little units!) instead of dots and hollow triangles - someone email me and I'll re-purchase this one. I really, really wanted to like it (played both of the Homeworld games for years) but...honestly if I wanted to watch little dots moving around on the screen, I could get something made back in the 1980s.Sorry, Devs - you made a very pretty game -- too bad you can't appreciate how nice the graphics are for over half the time you're playing.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												OK first up, if you are a diehard Homeworld fan like myself then yes, buy this game. Because it's a bit like meeting an old friend you haven't seen for many many years, and quite frankly feared had died. A friend that was a blast to hang out with in his old spaced out days, but now it seems he has become a well grounded individual (if you catch my drift). Does this make your old friend a bit dull now? Hell no. DoK looks, feels, sounds, and plays just as you would expect a Homeworld game to, irrespective of not being in space. But most importantly it's fun.If you like RTS games, or are new to them then I would suggest you check out reviews and game play videos on YouTube. As HW relies on a mobile fabrication and persistent fleet mechanic with limited resources that make spamming units a pretty much redundant and counter productive strategy. Which is not to everyone's liking. Make your own mind up, don't let me or anyone else tell you what's good or bad.      Also bear in mind this is not a AAA game, and as such I think some people had unrealistically high expectations, and/or no past experience of HW1, 2, and Cataclysm. The game looks great, runs fine on my medium rig with settings on ultra, and no crashes to report.However, there are some tweaking issues within the game at launch, which seems pretty much the norm (an additional month or two in production wouldn't have gone amiss), but can be fixed with patching. BBI have already stated they are going to support/patch and add DLC, so the game can only get better. Plus DoK opens up sooo many possible future game avenues for the Homeworld series to pursue, which has to be a good thing for the franchise, and fans alike. Thanks BBI and Gearbox for resuscitating the Homeworld universe. Any chance of HW 3? Please.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Let me start by saying I loved the original homeworld series, and wish they could find a way to bring back the other Homeworld game(Homeworld Cataclysm I believe).    That said, this is a fun game, but I feel its lacking in a lot of the things that made the Homeworld series amazing.  Part of what I loved about the series was the details they put in, for instance how every ship could be seen actually undocking or docking, even the capital ships, and the resource collectors actually had to dock to drop off supplies.  In this game, most of the ships come out of the right spots on the carrier, but when you retire ships they just drive under the carrier, not into the ramp on the back, and the resource collectors just have to touch the carrier or supply ships, not actually dock with them.  They are all small things, but I feel they are a major part of what made the original games so good.  Also, some of the controls or commands for ships are either missing, or badly done.  For instance there is no patrol option, if you queue up too many build orders on base runners they often get messed up, especially if you don't keep that many resources on hand(when you give it the order to build something, it doesn't subtract the resources from your total until the base runner actually gets there).Overall, yes I would recommend this game if you are a fan of RTS and/or Homeworld, but I feel they could have done better on it by focusing on a few more details.
