Posted: February 21, 2016
												My review comes from a multiplayer perspective. The campaign has already been covered well  by other reviews.Its a bit rushed and rough around the edges, (no key binding, few maps, occasional animation glitches etc.) but the developer hasn't given up on it yet and are planning future updates to fix bugs, balance gameplay, and add new maps.The core game mechanics for online multiplayer are solid. Taking advantage of terrain and scouting are critical to success. Good tactics can and will beat high Actions Per Minute and larger armies in this game. Though there are fewer units available than in other homeworld titles almost every unit has multiple purposes. For example the Gaalsien missile ship is a standard AA unit but also has an EMP motar that can disable ground units.If you are looking for an RTS that is truly tactical you should give this one a try. If not now, at least when it goes on sale.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												This review is based on the opinion of someone who has played all of the Homeworld games, including Cataclysm. So yes, I love the story and the world setting. I have very fond memories of the vast universe created by Relic back in 1999, so my review will reflect that sometimes.To put it simply, if you like your RTS games coupled with a good story then you will be very satisfied. The 10-15 hours campaign is very well made, fun missions that focus on slick action and pacing, with a very interesting story to boot. The conflict between the Coalition forces (the player) and the religious Gaalsien is fascinating to watch as they are two very different factions, each with their own very original and very pleasing audio-visual cues. Story progression is done through in-game cutscenes and gorgeous, incredibly original, animated scenes that highlight the more important events in the game. Although the ending is a bit abrupt, the story on the whole is deeply satysfying, with frequent nods and references do the older games in the series, specially Homeworld 1.Speaking of which, the graphics in this game are gorgeous. They are simple, elegant, and don't tax your computer heavily. Watching the land-carriers and their fleets work and intereact with each other and the enemy is a joy to watch as their animations are very well made and detailed. I love the aircraft animations in particular, as they use somewhat realistic engineering with the launch catapults and all. The larger vehicles are downright imposing and menacing, and the smaller ones give a sense of intimacy and scale that really reflects part of the reason I play RTS games: To watch and play as large armies collide with one another.In terms of audio this game is way above the competition. The music is awe-inspiring, creating a sense of tension and wonder that is rarely matched by other games of the genre. The soundtrack is composed by arabian-indian inspired sounds and instruments, lending the game a very exotic and mythic feeling. Sound effects are also incredibly well made, form the hum of the Battle-carriers to the thumping of large-calliber weapons. Playing this with a headphone is highly reccomended.Gameplay is incredibly fun as well, as the huge battles reminded me of a sci-fi Mad Max, as dozens of vehicles duke it out in a fiery storm of explosions deep in the desert. The player's fleet is centered on the huge Land-Carrier, a giant transport that serves not only as the production center and home base, but also as a fearsome weapon when needed. This is, in my view, a very interesting twist on the Homeworld formula. In previous games, Motherships were incredibly innefective in battle, depending wholeheartedly on their fleet's support, whereas in this game the land-carrier is a lot more independent. You don't have to babysit it all the time. As the game progresses your arsenal of vehicles and weapons expands, and each unit serves a purpose. I believe the variety is just right, enough to be complex without overwhelming the player with vehicles you'll never use.Multiplayer is still in development and could certainly use more maps and a third faction. But as it is, it is very fun and well made. Skirmish matches are also offered, but the AI could use some tweaking. It is not bad, but it's not that bright either. I believe Blackbird will tune it up with future patches, making the game even more fun.To sum it up, this is a very well made and elegant game. It looks and sounds amazing, with a very distinct and pleasing aura around it. I have played 15-16 hours as I write this review and I loved every minute of it. It is not an RTS made for the competitive SC2 guys. Deserts of Kharak is made for those who like a grand, epic story, with a very distinct and original feel to it. Sci-fi fans will love it. The gameplay is very fun, very original, and the two distinct factions offer a lot of gameplay options. I haven't had this much fun in Skirmish mode since Company of Heroes 2! Al in all, I highly reccomend this game. It is a 10/10 for me, and that is rare. I seldom write reviews, but I feel like this gem of a game deserves it. Roll on HW3 or more expasions for this game!

Posted: January 24, 2016
												Loving the transition to ground vehicular combat, very enjoyable. The campaign is surprisingly good with great little cutscenes connecting each mission, some great writing on the dialogue and the art style is fantastic, it's incredibly immersive and the radio chatter is amazing to listen to as it's so varied. Small niggles about the annoying camera controls, your viewpoint feels too close to the battlefield especially when hills and mountains come into view, it's missing vital features which every RTS cannot do without and several other things they need to tweak and fix, but judging by their official forum they're already hard at work on more maps and fixes and improvements.It's a good solid return to the brilliant setting of Homeworld and I hope BBI continue to add and improve upon it. It's a safe addition to the Homeworld series but I just wish BBI did more with the time they spent on this game, it's good but not as great as it could have been.So, basically. What's great is the story, voice acting, dialogue, music, gameplay, immersive both visually and through its audio and easily replayable either through mastering the harder difficulty of the campaign because the gameplay is so enjoyable or multiplayer to see how cunning other Homeworld fans can be!

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Overall, I give Homeworld: DoK a score of 8.5 out of 10.While it may not be a revolutionary RTS, there are some excellent tactical elements to this game that look like it will have some longevity.Before the launch of this game, a lot of people were complaining about the number of maps and units in the game. While it is true that there are not a lot of each, this game has done a good job with adding some depth to standard RTS elements to give what the Homeworld series was originally known for - tactical strategy.The individual units in the game can level up, increasing their power, armor, etc. Research also allows for various special abilities, so the base units in the game can really be customized and used in a variety of ways.The mobile carrier that is your main base is an interesting change to traditional RTS where you have to build stagnant bases. This is where you build your fleet and research, but you can also customize the abilities of the carrier to make it tougher, a repair hub and/or a strong defensive base.I'm only about 1.5 hours into playing the game so far but wanted to give my initial review. Personally, I'll be keeping this game. While it may not be worth a full $50, I got it with the remastered package, so all together they are well worth it.I do hope the game will expand with some additional content in the coming months - more map variety and maybe a few more units couldn't hurt. However, I'll still be happy with this game without it.Honestly, my biggest complaint about the game is the graphics. They're not horrible but they're not great either. They don't feel like an A+ title in 2016 (close-up shots during the cutscenes show gradients realy bad, for example). However, during normal gameplay, the graphics are decent and have a nice feel.Overall, if you enjoy RTS games (especially if you like on-the-go combat) and/or are a fan of the Homeworld series, I would recommend DoK.

												Sublime. No other game makes me feel like I am experiencing the sublime as well as a Homeworld game. I was nervous about Deserts of Kharak--the developers haven't made a Homeworld in twelve years, and the last one they made was in space. Could Deserts of Kharak be any good?Yes.Yes it could be.I don't know about Multiplayer or Skirmish--I don't play Homeworld for that--but this is totally a Homeworld game. All the mechanics that really mattered are here, and, to be honest, they make creative, worthwhile use of the terrain in one of the most innovative ways a developer has ever done. Great story, great gameplay, great campaign.It's Homeworld.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016



YouTube™ Video: Homeworld Deserts of Kharak Preview (Steam/PC) 

			Views: 118		

			Homeworld:Deserts of Kharak is a Real time strategy game and the follow up to Homeworld: Remastered which debuted at PAX South in 2015. The game is set as the title suggests in the desert.		

Homeworld:Deserts of Kharak was developed by Blackbird Interactive and published by Gearbox Software. It was released for Steam on January 20th, 2016 for $49.99. A press review copy was provided for The Hidden Levels.Homeworld:Deserts of Kharak is a Real time strategy game and the follow up to Homeworld: Remastered which debuted at PAX South in 2015. The game is set as the title suggests in the desert. You are in control of what can only be described as a “giant aircraft carrier which can move on desert sand”. The campaign is relatively rich in story albeit militaristic and choppy in tone it does manage to capture your attention. The mechanics are somewhat simple and shallow for a full RTS but that adds a meta game element to the potential multiplayer battles.What I enjoyed:Keeping it simple – Deserts of Kharak doesn’t have a ridiculously deep unit type count nor a wide variety of ranges on those unit types. It has three, and each counters one of the others similar to rock, paper, scissors in that none of the three are overall superior. This was initially a bit of a let down but in the aspect of game design it’s a relatively solid strategy. This type of limitation encourages players to think critically without knowing a rich meta-game or end game strategy like other RTS games require.Dune tunes – The audio and music in the game are well done to a point I felt immersed in the desert once I really sunk into the game. The militaristic style of the game isn’t exactly my personal style, but it’s well done in that I was annoyed by the commanders barking orders at me genuinely. The weapon sounds are also well done and not overzealous like RTS games tend to be so ultimately the audio in the game was clearly part of the cohesive design strategy.Real time real issues – The premise of the game towards the beginning is that the desert and it’s storms are taking over a planet. This is a relatively topical theme weather is was intended or not since global climate is such a hot button issue. The other issues that come up in dialogue suggest that the environment is incredibly important and not to be taken for granted. It’s an interesting notion to think what would happen should a planet begin to slowly evolve into a desert.What I disliked:Sandy voices – The voice overs while convincing were speaking in choppy military speak which started to sound less than human. The dialogue really was a bit of an annoyance to me in terms of how it was written and delivered. The voice acting was likely directed in this course but I can’t help but feeling like it was a less than human performance. The multiple five word sentences and unnaturally bureaucratic tone repeating over and over was irritating.Sunburnt AI – The AI enemies in the game don’t tend to make very logical decisions nor seem to play well against humans. This is a complaint I’ve heard from other reviewers in discussions about the game and it leads to a bigger overall issue. The game with poor AI then relies on the player base to enrich it via multiplayer games. I have some issues with any game that can’t stand alone without an internet connection unless it’s design is purely meant to be human vs. human.Homeworld:Deserts of Kharak does have some great moments and fun aspects which are worth taking a look at eventually. I can’t encourage anyone to purchase a game at such a high price point without a better AI or certain multiplayer following. I’d like to think people will see the use of the three unit types as a good limitation of design but ultimately my thoughts are that they will stick with the bigger deeper RTS titles on the market. Relying on us to populate the multiplayer for replay value is a bold choice and forces the mode upon anyone looking to get their full value. I am simply not sure that the game will have enough of a following to garner that sort of multiplayer presence which is a major contributor to my score to wait until the next Steam sale for this one.Score: Wait for a Sale

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												A Video production of this review can be found here 


YouTube™ Video: Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak Review 

			Views: 1,452		

			http://www.keengamer.com Video review of Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak, great successor of RTS game Homeworld, legendary space-based game. SUBSCRIBE TO OUR CHANNEL!		

HOMEWORLD: DESERTS OF KHARAK REVIEWAuthor: SHADOWFORKS 19-Jan-2016Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a prequel to Relic’s Homeworld series, developed by Blackbird Interactive.  After dejected in development hell for a good 6 years, the game is finally finished.  This new Homeworld game takes place nearly 100 years before the original.  In which a discovery of deviations in  Kharak, ensue an expedition through the southern deserts.The Homeworld games are scientific, yet grungy.  And it is all used as a behind-the-scenes approach to help tell the story.  Religious warfare is a habituated trait among the dusts of Kharak.  And while an acreage of this plot was interlaced with the original Homeworld’s instruction manual.  Preconceived plot devices have been replaced in favor of concentrated design.  Squabbling races, somber sacrifices, and titanic discoveries all move the plot into a coherent stream, eventually creating a dynamic and unforgettable plot. The animation and art-style are cel-shaded into an arenaceous aesthetic.  Vehicles look weathered and blemished.  And the physics are interlaced to the elevations of the deserts ridges.  Another description would be regarding the scale of your expedition through the secluse wild.  Units look impressive in scope when an abundance of them are present.  And the contrast from appliances, such as Salvagers when compared to the Kalisi, is well designed.The art-style perfectly conceives the atmosphere of the desert planet it’s trying to represent, with a great presence towards the desolation and emptiness of the Kharak landscape.  Seeing dune-buggy’s circle and bounce around their opposition is a satisfying use of physics, and the dust their wheels kick up is a wonderful example of the game’s attention to detail.  Overall this is a truly beautiful game, even on lower end computers.  The music in Deserts of Kharak is persistent in reminding you of the bleak pastels that you’re traversing.  Orchestrating and retaining the astrological concept of the original games, the soundtrack twists it into a symphony, chronicling an excursive crusade fully motivated by the desire to discover.  No longer are the airy drawls of the original homeworld, in it’s place are the searing sounds of low methodical beats.   Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is an RTS, a genre that has been seemingly dormant during recent years.  You can organize attack-squads, call in airstrikes, and control the hulking PC called the Kalisi, as you traverse the seemingly endless sand-dunes and opposing forces you encounter.  The micro-managing of resources and defense of incrusion, is an exercise in choices.  Should I allot development of better units, or should I create more of the same in order to fend off this attack?  Which resource should I harvest, and how many attack units should I leave with them in order to preserve them?  All of these questions contribute to how you will execute your gameplay experience when playing Deserts of Kharak.  It’s all very complicated, but intensely rewarding when you execute a perfect mission leaving no possibility unsecured in a timely manner.With a 15 hour campaign, Deserts of Kharat includes a decently meaty story.  And including a multiplayer mode that has a bevy of replayability value, the value for Deserts of Kharat is impressive.  The game is a worthy successor that takes a step back in all the right places, while including an impressive amount of innovation and character that was not yet seen in the originals.  Gearbox, amidst their incredible resume, helped make a descendant to the cult-classic series, a choice that I hope they will continue to go through with.  I was left wanting more by the end of Deserts of Kharak, not because of brevity, but because it was so satisfying to play.  Every second of the game was the perfect amount of difficulty that made me feeling hopeless one second, only to turn the mission around with one bold choice.  With a great world inhabited by great writing, Deserts of Kharak bares the Homeworld badge proudly.  The new perspective of ground combat is fresh and new, while the aesthetic and ambience increase an already quality RTS series worthiness.  Even if you are new to the series of Homeworld, and similarly unfamiliar with the RTS genre. Deserts of Kharak is a great game for veterans of the Homeworld series, and newcomers alike.  HOMEWORLD: DESERTS OF KHARAK DESERVES A 9/10

												Definate feel of the Original spacebound Homeworld games. Though lacking some of the depth in settings. No ability to modify Fleet size in game options... 125 units is one size fits all. Also with only a half dozen maps.... the views are limited. On the up side... the views are AMAZING. Absolutely beaufiful feel of the game and vehicle movements. All the tiny variations in elevations have an in game effect on lines of sight and the weapons that require it.The in game campaing and story line were nicely done and quite entertaining.Ideal patch/update would haveDeathmatchResouce Deposit adjustments (size and frequency)HUGE maps - what's the point of having spectacular landscapes if you can't enjoy themNight time mode or ability to pick time of day for games (one map is set in dusk - definately has room for more optionshere)A must have for Homeworld fans.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												DoK is a very Homeworld game, right down to its gameplay and experience. The only major element that comprises every homeworld game is the compelling storyline. As the storyline is good, I wouldn't say it is great compared  to HW1, HW:C and HW2 (I liked HW2 very much as compared to many people). Also, the feeling of lack of mysticism. Where the feeling of mystery existed in every Homeworld game before this, DoK has a profound lack of mystery surrounding the ancient ships buried in the sand and the artifacts that are collected. The artifacts are just passed off as Carrier Upgrades, and no further explanation or depth is given to them. Also, in HW1, there were many other different factions whom the Kushan encounter, and even mysterious ancient objects that pose a formidable obstacle to your journey. The ending itself feels really rushed and it seems like the devs quickly wrapped it up so it could ship fast instead of expanding the end a little more.I did not quite like the physics of the game as many a time I have seen the entire Kapisi standing with its head up when the immediate area was filled with units. Also, disappointing unit animations. As compared to the original HW, the ballistics can sometimes make no sense at all. I have seen a railgun not firing in the direction of an enemy yet the enemy gets damage. Gameplay itself was fun.A better game than HW1, HW2 or HW:C? Nope but still recommended as the first game for those who are interested in entering the HW universe.

												This is a beautifully crafted game!Despite not being in space, it's still very much Homeworld. The sound, interface, the annoying way cutscenes interrupt you when you're busy sparing your fleet from death, the way you need to avoid the final mission objective until you've harvested all resources or you miss out.The desert approach is great, it makes a great atmosphere. content:
Posted: March 13
												Gorgeous art direction, great voice work, and solid call backs to Homeworld. I wish it was longer, because I want so much more! The flexible power allocation for the carrier is an attractive feature and encourages doing more with the command ship than parking it far from the action. Each unit stands out in design and function, I found myself using scout drones, emp cover, artillery barrages and strike craft in coordination with ground assaults. As other have commented it can be annoying to position your units with the proper facing. I prefer a slower combat speed, sometimes whole armies seemed to evaporate in moments. I didn't run into any bugs during my play through. The whole game is a love letter to Homeworld, which is exactly what I was looking for!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												A game that came out of nowhere but that I somehow wanted very badly. H:DK is a little joy of a game, with outstanding visuals, excellent optimisation... And FINALLY a gameplay that doesn't demand an LSD-Red bull mix worth of APM skills.It's not exactly slow paced, but units don't die in two seconds, so you get time to adjust, control formations and positions, use what abilities there are (all straightforward and streamlined like speed boost for fast attack vehicles or smoke screens for tanks) as needed.Despite the apparent lack of variety in units (something I would personally object, as there are roughly 14 units per faction, there being two factions with subtle differences in their lineup), the gameplay has many layers, and the balance of resource gathering / unit construction-research / carrier usage (they're like the Motherships of old, only much more powerful) / artifact retrieval makes for a game where there is always something more to do, optimise or respond to.Finally, I grew up playing Homeworld 1. It was fantastic. This is its prequel, and from the audio design (guns, engines, UI, and especially the radio chatter), the music, the visuals, and the general narrative and atmosphere... I felt at home. It's more of a talented application of the meaning of this franchise onto a new game rather than fan service, and that means a great deal to me.10/10 would grow up playing.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												Great little game!I've got two negatives, one is probably something I'm quite alone in thinking, the other is a purely objective observation.Firstly, as a fan of the Homeworld franchise I very much dislike how this is so character focused, and how they made it a prequel. I'd much rather have had a stand alone salvage-huge-spaceship-wrecks-game in the Homeworld universe, keeping some of the original mysterious atmosphere etc. More along the lines of what this seemed to be slated as when it was still Hardware: Shipbreakers. Secondly, it's waaaay too easy, even on the hardest difficulty. I had to stop myself from soaking up all the RU/CUs on the maps because it would simply have made it all even worse. Not to mention if you dare to farm some enemies in one of the missions with endless waves (most of them) to gain XP. Or capture a few enemy cruisers. Just don't do it, else you can pretty much just attack move every mission thereafter to completion.Still, regardless of those points you can't help but enjoy the time it takes to complete the campaign. It feels very reminiscent of Homeworld with some Ground Control thrown in. The S'jet focus takes away from it sometimes, but it still feels pretty grand and special while it lasts. The cut scenes are great for the most part, the action is non-stop, the tech upgrades and units keep on rolling out and the maps are mostly well-designed.As for multiplayer in this one. Mjeeeh, not for me. If you're one to enjoy that aspect, I guess you'll get more hours out of it than me, and so might just get it at full price. Same if the mod scene takes off as that will no doubt add a lot of replay value.

												first off let me say I have fond memories of playing rts games such as battle for middle earth 2 and command and conquer 3 with friends and enjoy rts games. number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Pros:* Deserts of Kharak feels like a Homeworld game even with the y-axis removed from play. The gameplay is solid and the missions are varied.* The story elements lend themselves naturally to building up on origin story for Homeworld. Some people are incredibly over protective of the Homeworld story but this seems to build upon it nicely.Cons:* It's far too short. I think this is an excellently made game but I cannot recommend you pick it up at full price because the campaign is over and done with far too quickly. The missions themselves are diverse but the actual tactical options are a bit limited (although not especially different to homeworlds tactics).* Homeworld succeeded because although you were often facing the same enemy you occasionally had missions with other races and bad guys getting involved (for whom the usual strategies wouldn't work) - unfortunately this game doesn't really break out into new and unexpected opponents.In conclusion:If you are a die hard fan of Homeworld then pick this up but expect to smash through the campaign in about four decent length play sessions. The lack of diversity in your opponents means that you don't really end up changing your tactics which is disappointing compared to previous Homeworld games. If you can wait then I suggest picking this game up at about half its launch price.

content:
Posted: January 18
												A ground-based prequel to the classic Homeworld strategy games, this one defies all of the bad reputations prequel games tend to receive. A fantastically detailed and stylized desert warfare game, the gameplay retains many of the Homeworld right-click and hold camera movement and unit tracking. Zooming in lets you see the spinning treads of your wonderful warmachines tearing through sandy dunes and valleys. The cinematics are like paintings rather than the moving sketch art traditionally used but you simply can't ignore the way it sets a beautiful tone. This one won't disappoint Homeworld fans and RTS veterans alike with its array of tactics and clever use of ground-based cover and strategy.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15
												Awesome strategy game with a huge influence taken from the original homeworld series.It keeps you on the edge, has a great story arc, fun unit types and a great design overall.It does, however, still fall short in comparison to the original games... some aspects that bugged me:- The campaign is shorter13 levels in total and a rather abrupt ending with little to no build-up for the final fight. It just sort of ... happens and the credits roll. To be fair though: It really is cinematic and moody, just not entirely on the same level as Homeworld's "No one's left - Everything's gone - Kharak is burning" feeling.- No formations | No adjusted movementSo back in Homeworld we could assign different kinds of ships to the same group and had them fly in a specific formation. This would lead to a certain synergy between unit types.In "Deserts of Kharak" formations are gone. Also, if you assign different unit types to the same group and order them to move, they each move at their own top speed resulting in your units arriving in battle at different times. That....was not such a good idea...- No real 3D movementDon't get me wrong here: 3D movement is not entirely out of the picture. Using the desert scenario height differences still matter in battle, probably even more than they did in the original games. Units that stand on higher ground are harder to hit and get a bonus on their fighting capabilities. Nice and dandy, I'd just prefer to have real 3D maneuvering where I can tell different fleets to move higher on the y-Axis and then attack down. That's a scenario-issue here though, can't really do that in the desert ;)- No more organized unit stealingRemember those small ships that could latch onto enemy ships and drag them away?Awesome stuff! And... they're gone. You can still convert enemy units as an ability of your main "hero" character but that means "Steal one ship - 1 minute cooldown - Steal another ship - 1 minute cooldown". It is alright and gets the job done, it just doesn't satisfy that itch of "making your fleet my fleet".- Less attention to detailRemember how in Homeworld every docking animation tried to be perfect? You stole a huge a** ship from your enemy and could watch it slowly being dragged to your mothership for docking? Every port opened picture perfect, every ship fitted juuuust through and every maneuver worked to a tee. Stuff like that has become scarce here. Units just drive through your main ship or each other without collision, more often than not they seem to dock by ramming through the hull and dissappear. It just kills the mood from time to time.- DLC. Yeah, we all know it. Let's just leave it at that- Some bugs and crashes I bought this game about a year after its release and I still had some minor issues.Fighter-jets wouldn't return to base, the game crashed during a mission and, my favorite, during the last mission the enemy base-ship as well as mine both exploded simultaneously resulting in a game-over for me with the end-cutscene still playing.It's nothing major but still a little annoying.That's about all the negative stuff I can find about this game.Just check for yourself if these details bug you or not, everything else just plays and feels awesome ;)(Still recommending the Remastered-Collection of the original games though)

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12
												Before anything: this isn't a bad game. It's just... not good enough.I actually enjoyed playing through its campaign, but sadly I never really felt the homeworld feeling of the firts two chapters.Drawings are still cool. But that's it.To be more precise, two kind of player will play this game:- those who played Homeworld and/or Homeworld 2- those who didn'tClever, am I not?---------------Anyway, for the latter it's simple: it's not a RTS that you might like, played out of the blue, with no memories about the first two chapters. The few things the plot shows are just as empty as a wall paint plot evolution drying up, if you don't know what those things will become in the future (aka Homeworld 1).---------------For the former... eh.What made great Homeworld 1/2?Pathos, empathy, tactics, epicness. All in a strategic game in an era where only a coulpe of RTS could claim this much.Let's see some of the reasons, with their counterpart in DoK.---------------- That feeling of sad pride. The sacrifice of the Bentusi. That "The Mothership must survive" just before the hyperjump. ==> NOTHING relevant happens in DoK. It sould be a prequel. In fact is just as deep as ONE of the story drawings of HW1.- 3D battles, with absolute control over the fleet formation, the attack angles, flanking moves, scouting the void, hiding in nebulas, etc.==> Deserts of Kharak it's a 2D flat map. Some obstacles here and there. No tactical choices. Nearly fixed paths. Paradoxically, the 3D nearly empty maps of HW1/2 felt more elaborated and rich of opportunities.- Impressive number of ways to battle. Bait enemies. Or draw fire and go bomber.  Or Frigate rolling stone, protected by Fighters. Or battlecruisers blast and hyperjump off. Or kamikaze-probes =)==> Assault units vs Railgun, Armored vs Assault, Railgun vs Armored. Stop. Then you get battlecruisers. At that poin sell every small unit aside antiaerial and go battlecruisers: they can rush through the entire campaign by simple autoattack movement.- The option to destroy the subsystems of a capital ship to cripple it before finishing it was a master's touch in the creation of HW2.==> Removed. No subsystems. And I don't mean that "you can't destroy them". You cannot even build them. It's all just research. Mandatory research.- Hyperspace tactical jumps. No explainations needed.==> No Hyperspace jumps at all. No explainations needed. And it would be acceptable: I mean, the hyperpace jumps are not jet discovered. But at least some form of tactical movements. Air carriers for quick movement. Something...- An assorted fleet with a spot for every. single. unit. Even the simplest explorer or the Fighter had a solid role in the tactics.==> You get to build the battleships? You can forget of the small veicles. Only keep the ones for antiaerial defense. Go battleships and trample everything. - Capturing. This was one of the pillars of the whole game in Homeworld 1. Still great in Homeworld 2.==> Capturing is just a side effect if a skill that says "immediately destroy one enemy unit". Also bad AI that keeps firing to the captured unit, often blasting it apart, while it's being driven to the Carrier for conversion. - Speaking of losses you had to build an assorted fleed, manage it cleverly, and never, ever, let something bigger than a corvette be destroyed. You needed to deploy your best tactics most of the time.==> The final, big, decisive battle? Select your fleet and send it in autoattack in the approximative direction of the target. Done. Thanks. Goodbye. The previuos battles? Select your army and send it in the direction of the objective. You have plenty of resources to win the campaign with that, and plenty of army slots to trample everything with just marginal losses fully refillable.- The immense satisfaction of starting each mission with an undersized army if compared to the enemy, and win by raw tactics and strategy.==> I have NEVER seen more than 3-4 enemy cruisers in the same screen, in DoK. My fleet had 26 of them. And anything smaller got shredded by artillery way before getting in range.- Split your forces. Protect the collectors. Attack the objective. Send units to escort the ally. All while protecting the Mothership!==> Just move your entire fleet, Carrier included along the path, and harvest resources as you pass by them. Also no need to protect the Carrier: it can fend off any attack in normal difficulty with no help from anything. So use fleet to attack, and Carrier / Support Cruiser to harvest.- Research tree. Nothing new even in HW1/2, ok, but still gave the player the chance to define the fleet priorities.==> In DoK might as well remove it. Most upgrade are mandatory story driven. Those who aren't you have plenty of time and resources to research them. And half of them just unlocks in the last 2 missions. When you don't really need anything more to win (in my playthrough the enemy Carrier - the objective of the mission - drifted from its path lured by accident by a collector, got close to my cruisers, and got blasted while I was happily micromanaging the mine-laying-duty on the other side of the fleet).------------------------------Final verdict: I had great hopes. But if you really want to feel the Homeworld you love, just play HW1/2. And if you have never player HW before, play HW1/2. Non-remastered version. Remastered version is still story-beautiful, but the game itsel is somehow way easier.One "could-have-been-good" point: gathering artifacts for powering up the Carrier was a good idea, but largely underdeveloped, sadly.As a note: I played the whole campaign in normal difficulty. Some critics regarding "how hard the game is not" might not be valid in hard difficulty. This I do not know.Still, if I compare this normal difficulty to HW1/2 normal difficulty, the gap is huge. DoK is really, really too easy.

I had some crashes in-game (all of a sudden I am on the desktop, app vanished), this might be due to the fact that I set graphical quality to high, instead of low as recommended - I will have to check that.The GUi is actually quite nice and feels more like the old HW2 one than that crappy new GUI in the remastered HW.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Ok, so quick summary after a couple hours of multiplayer.The game is clearly homeworld. It plays like a proper sequel, and not a generic RTS with "Homeworld" tacked on.In true homeworld style, every unit is unique and satisfying. You feel every loss and celebrate every enemy you turn into a flaming wreck. The land based gameplay adds a refreshing layer of depth to the series, with physical obstacles being more of a consideration (IMHO) than the z-axis movement of the original games. Similarily, while the unit pool is perhaps a bit smaller, the option of having land or air based units gives players a bit more to consider when choosing a research and build path.Lastly, the artifact retrieval mode rules. The game has some minor setbacks, but nothing that wasn't present in the original games.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												I played this game before.  It was fantastic, with a great story, interesting characters, amazing graphics and well executed unit design.  It was called "Ground Control". This is not that game.  This game is a poor imitator that rips off the unit design, factions and plot points from that game.  Then it tries to shoehorn in the plot of the original "Homeworld" game, and I mean literally the same exact story with plot points filled in from the stolen "Ground Control" story.  It plays like any old RTS game with nothing new or innovative.  It bears all the hallmarks of a game that ran out of funding, forcing the developers to scramble to salvage what they had into a marketable product.  The way they refer to units like their spacefaring counterparts seemed out of place and uninspired.  Even more of a slap in the face by the developers was the fact that the levels were exactly the same as "Homeworld" (with the difference being that they are on the ground instead of space).  We were all hoping for a third "Homeworld" game, but this is not that game and I doubt any of us would want to play it if this is the effort the developers are willing to put into it.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												Overall: a positive review. Some points that I would change if i were Blackbird Interactive but any game that wants to keep the Homeworld legend going gets a thumbs up from me.Positives:- The story is really good. You really feel like you are working towards the survival of your people and you do get emotionally invested when you lose your units.- Graphics look great and run well on my ultra HD monitor in max settings- It is Homeworld! Even the unit icons look the same- Controls are relatively easy- Cutscenes are superb. The artistic effects are top notch.- Story follows the Homeworld storyline perfectly and I love the references to things you learnt in Homeworld 1 and 2. Negatives- Dont buy the expedition guide. There is so little information in there that it is definitely not worth buying. In fact I cannot understand how it comes to 600MB. Perhaps I am missing a huge part or I am going blind but £5~ is a lot of money for something that would cost a couple of pennies as a piece of paper.- Units could have a lot more variety. Hopefully they will patch in more at a later date.- This is based in the Homeworld universe but isn't Homeworld. I miss having multiple carriers creating a fleet of ships. In this you have one command ship that makes things and that is it.- Fleet sizes are a fraction of the size of in Homeworld the original. I remember making fleets of hundreds or thousands of ships (yes the lag was awful) and then fighting the enemy, In this game the fleets are only tens or at max a hundred.OverallIt's Homeworld so buy it. The more people that buy it, the more chance of Homeworld 3.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Since I haven't played enough multiplayer to really comment on multiplayer balancing, this would mainly be a review for single player campaign.The campaign itself is wonderfully done with the right combination of story and visual story telling. Story is being told actively as you play the game, and the pace at which the game unfolds new features in the campaign allows the player to pick up what to do with different units very naturally. Story integrates itself well to the original Homeworld universe, and suble hints suggest that this conflict behind the Desert of Kharak campaign does not invole any clear "villain" or the "good-guy", but a society torn between progressivist and conservative at a time of hardship on a planet going through major climate change. If you require the story to be told in your face with everything blatantly obvious, you would probably not enjoy the story of Desert of Kharak. However, if you enjoy picking up subtle hints and plot pieces spread throughout the game's campaign, you'll enjoy playing through this game.As for the aesthetics and presentation of the game, it inherits a lot of the visual and atomospher of the original Homeworld series. The designs are very minimal yet cleanly done, and if you were a fan of the original series (or a fan of the more realistic Scifi design), it'll most likely please you. Voice acting is also done in a natural manner instead of the over-the-top method you would find in lot of the other games. However, this is not without it's cons. Although the game put heavy emphasis on terrain utilization, it's sometimes difficult to visually decipher which grounds offer to terrain advantage until your units are physically interacting with the terrain. Since the difficulty level of the campaign is not too high this is not a major set back, but I wonder if this issue would be addressed in the future patch.Overall, the game offer a lot of promise, and I'm sure a lot of the kinks would be worked out in the near future. I highly recommend this game to the fans of the original Homeworld series as well as fans of RTS. Those who enjoyed games like Total Annihilation or Supreme Commander would definitely enjoy this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Short version:  It's a new Homeworld; if you liked the old ones or have been wanting to try a homeworld this is a good place to start.  If you're not a homeworld fan(or looking to get into homeworld), and you're just looking for a good RTS then your mileage may vary based on what you have previously liked in the RTS genre.  Long version:  Deserts of Kharak does well what every homeworld game has done before it - tell a story.  It's an exceedingly rare experience for an RTS to tell a story well, for you to care about what happens to the characters, for you to get emotionally invovled, and to be able to tell that story actively through the tiny units and voice-overs on the screen.  Gameplay is solid; each unit has a defined role that it excels in.  Exploiting unit's weaknesses and strengths is extremely satisfying when you're the one delivering, and appropraitely punshing if you're on the receiving end.  It's not so overpowered that you can simply overwhelm your oppoenent if they make a wrong move, but not so underpowered that it leaves you wondering if you actually have the upper hand.  Tactics (high ground, terrain blocking) and LOS make noticeable impact on gameplay as well, and this is a welcome addition.  It shakes up the standard rocks-paper-scissors gameplay enough to make every engagement interesting, and so that even a mismatched fight can be turned towards your favor. A side-note on gameplay; I've seen a lot of criticism of this game because it doesn't live up to standards set by games like starcraft.  I found this criticism generally unfair because the comparisions drawn I find unapplicable.  I think this game most resembles a cross between company of heroes and total annihiliation/ supreme commander.  Homeworld to Starcraft is like a BMW to a Ford.  They are both a car, they basically do the same thing, but that's about where the similarities end.  But I digress, moving on. . . AI and MP:  There's no nice way to put this but the AI is lacking in it's current state.  I played the campaign on the equivalent of medium, and at no point did I feel threatened or like I was going to lose.  MP is region locked which is stupid since there's a lobby system in place; it should have been simple to just add a ping and let players make their own decisions.  Also, there's only 5 maps to chose from when playing MP or skirmish.  These things are not a big deal to me (except the region lock), but that's probably because I played company of heroes competatively back in the day and there were only 5 maps I played on back then (1v1 automatch), and I only plan on playing Deserts competatively.  That being said, I still see these things as significant problems.  RTS's thrive on healthy skirmishs and a solid AI (or a solid competative community), and good maps help make both those things happen.  BBI has said, as of the writing of this review, that they are working on the AI and they plan on releasing more maps.  They have also said that maps will always be free and never DLC.  They have not commented on the region lock to my knowlege.  So is it worth $50?  As I said at the beginning, your mileage will vary based on what you like in your RTS genre.  If you're looking for a RTS you can play by yourself and be entertained with for a long time (e.g. AoE, RoN), I would say not in its current state.  Give it a patch or two; see if the skirmish state improves.  If you're looking for a good story with potentially competative MP, then I would say yes.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2016
												This game is a gem, but it is not without it's flaws.The game is gorgeous and well thought out.  The landscapes and cut scenes are worthy of the homeworld franchise.  The game play is fast paced and brutal.  Tactics being your friend and hesitation your death.I beat this game it about a week of on and off play.  I played the first few missions on the hardest setting and the rest at "classic".  many other people think this game needs the ability to pause the game and perform orders.  The developers have put forth that they did not include this feature because it breaks immersion and takes away from the desperation the missions in Deserts of Kharak have you play through.Personally I think it's ridiculous the developers try to defend the idea of not having any sort of "real" pause feature auto-included in an RTS game (as anyone who has played previous titles in this franchise will know that such a feature is not only necessary; but really cool as you actually get time to enjoy the visuals which are a hall mark of Homeworld).  Currently the only way to "pause" the game is the main menu screen.  This does not breeak the game but is disappointing; and honestly will prevent me from playing thorugh the campaign again as half of what goes on is understandably simply "missed" by the player in the chaos.Still I would readily recommend this title to anyone who enjoys RTS game play, and cross your fingers that the devs atleast implement an honest pause feature (even if they do not allow you to give orders cretae CTRL gorups etc).

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												HW: DOK is as I had expected. I really like many aspects of this game, including the persistence of units (so they follow you from map to map), unit experience, the "sandbox" mode (and with all that sand, it really is a sandbox!) Also the voice acting is fantastic. Try to notice the smalltalk that you can hear as a background ambient sound effect. Some of it is funny and really adds a nice touch to the game. I also like the "realism" since all units have a well defined purpose and a sense of unity binds all of your units together. The art direction is top-notch. So overall, it's a fantastic game and I would highly recommend it. I would've liked to have a pause mode, letting you pause the game and issue orders. Also there are little things that might be improved in future patches but again, overall, this is a must for RTS, sci-fi fans and makes for an engaging and beautiful, classic game of the genre! Bravo to BBI!

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Right, so gonna make this quick, yes I do love the homeworld series, and it does color my judgment somewhat, but none the less, I'll try to be as honest as possible. So here are my Pros, Cons and MiscPros:-Decent looking graphics-Has the homeworld feeling to it(Even though it is a 2D unit control)-Every unit feels useful(Yes some strategy games do have virtually usless units like in CoH)-Great sense of Scale-Interesting level of use of terrain for units-An okay campaign with a nice homeworld feel to it(The long trek feel)-Units gain promotions and utility so keep them alive-Not a twitch strategy game-Awesome soundtrack that feels it belongs here(Unlike some! *Stares down Act Of Aggression*)Cons:-AI is dumb(Really a shame because I see much potential here.)-AI in skirmish cheats but is still stupid...(Yeah so basically it's gonna be pumping ressources like a mofo and then not using them...)-Game breaking bugs in the campaign(Had none yet, but had a friend and a few people that I know that had some)-Only five MP maps(This kinda goes without saying WTF?! Only five?!)-Somewhat a limited unit selection(But atleast they're all useful)-No keybinds(Wtf? Seriously?)Misc:-Occasional funny graphical glitches (Rachel S'jet's baserunner bouncing around like a rubber ball, AAV rolling on its side  and LAV rolling on its roof... The list kind of goes on)-Has a mixed feeling between dune and Mad Max-IGN says not enough water-So much sand... OH LOOK A ROCK! More sand... OH LOOK A SHIP!-Rachel talks about studying the ships and everything then finally just blows the crap outta everything.-DON'T TOUCH ME YOU ZEALOT!-Minor Inconsistencies with the lore.Final word:I honestly recommend this game for those who enjoyed homeworld and for those who enjoy a slow paced RTS. Though I admit it's not going to get a Game of the Year award(Hardly any award actually), it is a breath of fresh air in this ocean full of games, though lacking in the RTS section recently... I hope that BBI and/or Gearbox addresses the issue for not bindable keys and the lack of maps. Because this game is honestly a beatiful but rough diamond in the sands of Kharak.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Short version:  It's a new Homeworld; if you liked the old ones or have been wanting to try a homeworld this is a good place to start.  If you're not a homeworld fan(or looking to get into homeworld), and you're just looking for a good RTS then your mileage may vary based on what you have previously liked in the RTS genre.  Long version:  Deserts of Kharak does well what every homeworld game has done before it - tell a story.  It's an exceedingly rare experience for an RTS to tell a story well, for you to care about what happens to the characters, for you to get emotionally invovled, and to be able to tell that story actively through the tiny units and voice-overs on the screen.  Gameplay is solid; each unit has a defined role that it excels in.  Exploiting unit's weaknesses and strengths is extremely satisfying when you're the one delivering, and appropraitely punshing if you're on the receiving end.  It's not so overpowered that you can simply overwhelm your oppoenent if they make a wrong move, but not so underpowered that it leaves you wondering if you actually have the upper hand.  Tactics (high ground, terrain blocking) and LOS make noticeable impact on gameplay as well, and this is a welcome addition.  It shakes up the standard rocks-paper-scissors gameplay enough to make every engagement interesting, and so that even a mismatched fight can be turned towards your favor. A side-note on gameplay; I've seen a lot of criticism of this game because it doesn't live up to standards set by games like starcraft.  I found this criticism generally unfair because the comparisions drawn I find unapplicable.  I think this game most resembles a cross between company of heroes and total annihiliation/ supreme commander.  Homeworld to Starcraft is like a BMW to a Ford.  They are both a car, they basically do the same thing, but that's about where the similarities end.  But I digress, moving on. . . AI and MP:  There's no nice way to put this but the AI is lacking in it's current state.  I played the campaign on the equivalent of medium, and at no point did I feel threatened or like I was going to lose.  MP is region locked which is stupid since there's a lobby system in place; it should have been simple to just add a ping and let players make their own decisions.  Also, there's only 5 maps to chose from when playing MP or skirmish.  These things are not a big deal to me (except the region lock), but that's probably because I played company of heroes competatively back in the day and there were only 5 maps I played on back then (1v1 automatch), and I only plan on playing Deserts competatively.  That being said, I still see these things as significant problems.  RTS's thrive on healthy skirmishs and a solid AI (or a solid competative community), and good maps help make both those things happen.  BBI has said, as of the writing of this review, that they are working on the AI and they plan on releasing more maps.  They have also said that maps will always be free and never DLC.  They have not commented on the region lock to my knowlege.  So is it worth $50?  As I said at the beginning, your mileage will vary based on what you like in your RTS genre.  If you're looking for a RTS you can play by yourself and be entertained with for a long time (e.g. AoE, RoN), I would say not in its current state.  Give it a patch or two; see if the skirmish state improves.  If you're looking for a good story with potentially competative MP, then I would say yes.

												At first I thought I would end up bored by what seemed like a paucity of units and a desert enviornment. I mean how exciting can it be to fight in a desert? After playing 4 missions in the campaign I'm happy to say I'm pleased and hours went by without me realising it. The campaign keeps you on your toes and at least for me didn't allow me to camp too long and build my forces up to an overwhelming level. How you use light and heavy units becomes important as they all have strengths and weak points. Example: a pack of ranged railguns annhilated my swarm of light attack craft from high ground before they reached effective range. I'd like to see more maps for skirmish and multiplayer and hopefully some new units if possible. I loved homeworld and it's sequels and this ties in nicely as a prequel. In my opinion it's worth the money.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												It's very difficult for a modern game to be as innovative as the original homeworld.This game, I would say, isn't innovative at all. For fans of homeworld though, I would recommend this game. There are a few caveats, though.1. Controls are not rebindable.2. For a game that depends on terrain placement, one has to individually place each unit. With older homeworld games there was formation control, with this one, the controls are point and click. It's streamlined in a lot of ways, and this detracts from the overall experience.But the major successes are that this game lives and breathes the homeworld universe. They essentially took every bit of lore from the 1999 manual to the cataclysm game, and fleshed it out completely. The multiplayer maps are a bit thin at the moment, but they've promised that more maps are coming with future updates.Launch Day bugs are very minor. Occasionally an enemy won't attack your position as expected. It's trivial to just go get them, or hit them with airstrikes. Overall, as someone who loves the homeworld universe, I loved this game.If you like the homeworld universe, you'll love it too. You'll be slightly disappointed that it lacks some of the features of previous games, but you'll still have fun. So with a few caveats, I absolutely recommend this game, and hope for more and better from Gearbox in the future.

The glimpses I caught didn't impress, mind.The CPU AI players in skirmish mode are either absolutely dreadful or cheat, so there's very little replayability there, and there's not much of an online community it seems. So at full price, this seems a very raw deal, as while the campaign is good, it's not £29.99 good, and is pretty much the only aspect worth paying for given the skirmish/multiplayer issues.Overall the campaign in and of itself *is* good fun so that's why I'm recommending it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Real Time Strategy*Minor ClichesOverall 4 out of 5Complexity 4Graphics 5Immersive 4Innovative 3Game Pace 4Yes, this is Homeworld, despite being in a planet it's not another Command & Conquer.The game felt much like playing Dune 2 again (after 20 years!) and it has two very fundamental differences from the C&C series: The resources are more scarce and you need to be more responsible about it and the specialisation of the units require more active control of them other then just throwing hordes on your enemy.The main campaign has a well written and engaging plot, which makes the game far more immersive than RTSs normally are.There are some basic things missing, which is hard to understand the reason since this is a quality game. Managing formations of the groups for example is a nightmare, you can manually organise the units while on stop, but if you order an advance all becomes a huge mess by the different speeds. Another things that annoys me is the Skirmish standard "build quickly and attack quickly" strategy, I would expect a proper strategy game to do not reward this as when it works it flattens out the game, but that is recurrent in RTSs.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												Deserts of Kharak really brings me back to Homeworld -- the look, the sound/music, and the story are all great. There are a few points that are kind of iffy, though:- Playing it is a little bit of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ The regular camera doesn't zoom out as much as you'd like, control groups are a little wacky, unit formations can be suicidal, and so on. - The story is pretty short. Eight or nine hours on normal difficulty. There's skirmish and multiplayer, but the skirmish AI is not very challenging and I'm not really interested in multiplayer. - There's really not a ton of variety in the way that missions play out. Sometimes you have to collect an artifact or place some turrets, but basically a couple big control groups attack-moving will carry you through the game.- No unit variety between factions that I could see. Obviously they look different, but each of the two factions share the few basic unit types. The DLC factions are really minimal reskins of the two standard factions -- don't bother.With that said, for $25 I feel like I got my money's worth, but at the regular price of $50 I'd feel kind of ripped off. In general, it's just how I like RTSes -- a little more sweeping and "arty" than StarCraft, not too much boring macro (Planetary Annhilation), and the great Homeworld feel. I just wish it had more and more varied missions.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												Deserts of Kharak really brings me back to Homeworld -- the look, the sound/music, and the story are all great. There are a few points that are kind of iffy, though:- Playing it is a little bit of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ The regular camera doesn't zoom out as much as you'd like, control groups are a little wacky, unit formations can be suicidal, and so on. - The story is pretty short. Eight or nine hours on normal difficulty. There's skirmish and multiplayer, but the skirmish AI is not very challenging and I'm not really interested in multiplayer. - There's really not a ton of variety in the way that missions play out. Sometimes you have to collect an artifact or place some turrets, but basically a couple big control groups attack-moving will carry you through the game.- No unit variety between factions that I could see. Obviously they look different, but each of the two factions share the few basic unit types. The DLC factions are really minimal reskins of the two standard factions -- don't bother.With that said, for $25 I feel like I got my money's worth, but at the regular price of $50 I'd feel kind of ripped off. In general, it's just how I like RTSes -- a little more sweeping and "arty" than StarCraft, not too much boring macro (Planetary Annhilation), and the great Homeworld feel. I just wish it had more and more varied missions.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												These thoughts are regarding the campaign.I get terribly stressed out playing RTS, and so I play them all on the easiest difficulty and mostly for the atmosphere and story. This game has both of it. The desert is looking gorgeous and the story is subtle and compelling. The campaign gives you a sense of discovery and adventure. You get to keep your units between missions and see them level up, gaining many times the power it had when it was a rookie. You get a feeling of responsibility towards the survival of said units, and I've reloaded a save game many times in order to save a unit from getting destroyed.Otherwise the mechanics of the game are pretty straight forward. It's a case of stone-rock-scissors, even up in the tiers of units. You gather resources and spend them on new units (up to a unit cap that increases during the campaign) and on research which is done from the carrier which acts as your mobile base.For the atmosphere and story I thoroughly recommend this game. I can't speak for the challenge, seeing that I played the game on easy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Real Time Strategy*Minor ClichesOverall 4 out of 5Complexity 4Graphics 5Immersive 4Innovative 3Game Pace 4Yes, this is Homeworld, despite being in a planet it's not another Command & Conquer.The game felt much like playing Dune 2 again (after 20 years!) and it has two very fundamental differences from the C&C series: The resources are more scarce and you need to be more responsible about it and the specialisation of the units require more active control of them other then just throwing hordes on your enemy.The main campaign has a well written and engaging plot, which makes the game far more immersive than RTSs normally are.There are some basic things missing, which is hard to understand the reason since this is a quality game. Managing formations of the groups for example is a nightmare, you can manually organise the units while on stop, but if you order an advance all becomes a huge mess by the different speeds. Another things that annoys me is the Skirmish standard "build quickly and attack quickly" strategy, I would expect a proper strategy game to do not reward this as when it works it flattens out the game, but that is recurrent in RTSs.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												One of the only Games I ever pre-ordered. A solid entry for the Homeworld series.  You'll see a whole bunch of niggles by people in the reviews and comments, but by and large these are fairly minor issues. I myself would feel it desperately needs a "pause and give orders option" which was present in all the other games, However I wouldn't give it a negative review simply for that, (although it is pretty bad in my eyes).The biggest drawback is that its really been set-up as a multiplayer game, kinda like a tournament type, which when you consider the pedigree of Gearbox, isn't all that surprising. And you cant really blame Gearbox as MP seems to be where young gamers are these days and thus so is the money.  For me the emphasis has been on a thoughtful, singleplayer game you can take your time with. A result of this is that most of the sides are somewhat bland and homogeneous, (equal), and there is little differentiation between the opposing sides units.  Assymetric warfare, this is not. Practical Upshot:  If Multiplayer is your thing, you'll prob really enjoy this.  If you want a deep thoughtful RTS, you may want to think twice about this, unless its on sale.  It's not bad, but depth and ability to take your time, (away from a frantic MP pace), is not its strong point.  The Original HW games were far better at that.It is fun though, and definitely has all the flavour and feel of the original HW games.

												This was a game that I longed to play for a time. I bought it with expecting to play a good RTS with stylish graphics. And I expected that strategy game has the "classical RTS" concept, like the Command and Conquer.So far I have played four missions but I can see to my expectations are well met. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10
												While this is a prequel to the Homeworld games, I decided to play this first, and I was never lost or feeling left out. Even if this would be your first Homeworld game, go ahead and give it a shot!Deserts of Kharak is a game with very interesting pacing. Units turn and move quite slowly overall, and many ranged attacks take a while to land, but a combination of strong counters and powerful area of effect weapons means that once a battle starts it's often over very quickly, one way or another. The significant impact of terrain elevation on damage and your units' ability to see their targets is very easy to overlook, but beware: it really matters.Sometimes this all means one or two wrong choices will cripple your entire operation in seconds, but on the plus side you also have time to break off attacks, and your decisions really do matter - going into the same fight with a different mix of units and tactics can make a dramatic difference. The story is compelling if simple, and has a great mystical undertone that reminds me of Battlestar Galactica. The game is also beautiful - seriously, I don't think video game deserts have ever looked this good. Weapons fire satisfyingly, weather and sand effects are convincing, and the architectural and vehicle style is cohesive and immersive. The units are a bit visually indistinct at playable distances, but if you're managing hotkey groups actively it shouldn't be such a big deal.My main complaint with the game is the way it handles zooming and the visual (small-scale, pretty) versus tactical (large-scale, abstract) maps. Rather than smoothly transitioning between the two, there's a key transition, and moving from the tactical to the visual map often results in the camera ending up somewhere in the middle of nowhere. Double-clicking zooms you from the tactical map to a specific spot on the visual map, unless you’re double-clicking on a unit, but the camera angles often end up skewed away from whatever you had set it to before, and the camera is often zoomed too close to the ground as well.Oh, and couldn't the Escape key bring up the damned menu? You'd think.Aside from some interface frustrations, though, this is a great RTS game, suitably challenging and with great aesthetic and style. I highly recommend everyone interested try it out.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												I am a huge fan of the original homeworld series, 1, 2 and Cataclysm. So when Homeworld remastered got released last year, I spent a huge amount of time working my way through the missions and the skirmish mode. When I found out that Shipbreakers wasn't far off I took the decision to stop playing and move onto something else , and a day after it was released as Deserts of Kharak I have already completed the games campaign in the easy mode. So what does this game have to offer?If you are a fan of the RTS games like C&C or Supreme Commander then this is a must for you, even if you didnt like the original homeworld games. The ground orientated combat is merged seemlessly with homeworlds ambiance and storytelling as you guide an expidition though the war torn banded desert on the hunt for an artifact that will save your race.Yup - you guessed it if you didnt already know, this is a prequel and you ultimatley find the Khar-Toba, which would lead onto the Guidestone, and onto Homeworld 1...What doesnt this game have?Well, I'd like to say a long story, its only 13 missions long which was a bit of a disapointment, i would have liked to have played a bit longer.Also the game seems to end each mission very quickly not allowing you to harvest the local resources and find artifacts that remain. Surely a mission like this, that would be a key focus. Similar to homeworld 1.Also there are only a handful of skirmish maps, so I am hoping the developers release some FREE DLC soon with added maps, maybe some of the missions converted into skirmish maps as each mission map was excellently crafted. All-in-all this for homeworld fans and other RTS fans alike, this game is a must. But remember if like me you have an older system to turn the graphics down before you launch into the campaign as its difficult to change the settings unless if you use the main menu options pannel. There is one mission in particular that is a graphics hog.So why did i metion that I stopped playing the remastered games? I had a feeling that the last scene in the last mission would get me wanting to play the other games again.And I wasnt dissapointed when I heard something familiar in the last cutscene. Im looking forward to playing homeworld 1 again after this. And I hope we see more new homeworld coming soon!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
												Not a perfect game by any means, but pretty enough looking and sounding to add a sort of aesthetic enjoyment in playing, and the strategy genre is few and far between nowadays. The music, artwork and scenery are genuinly enjoyable, and the story is passable enough to string it all together. The campaign is fairly short, but to be honest if you're like me and don't have too long to sink into a game its a decent enough length.Its hard to describe why I wouldn't call this game great, despite it having hints of greatness. The camera can be hard to get just right - its always close enough to work, but never quite comfortable. I often wanted to zoom out slightly more than allowed, meaning I spent half the game in the strategic overview map view, clicking on little icons when I really wanted to be seeing the action in all its visual glory. Theres no mini map, so you will often find yourself feeling slightly out of the loop.I haven't delved into the multiplayer too much yet, but after a couple of skirmishes the mechanics strike me as averagely good for online play - its the sort of thing I imagine playing with some friends a few times then dropping, as opposed to getting competitive like company of heroes or one of the other big strategy titles.  Overall - 7/10, pick up on sale and enjoy, and try to enjoy the atmosphere throughout the relatively short ride.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Overall, a solid game whose flaws are more than made up for by excellent atmosphere and style. Gameplay is similar to Homeworld, mostly minus the Z axis*, and has not been made overly complicated, which personally I approve of.* Some units benefit in terms of visibility (and damage?) from a height advantage.+Great atmosphere; looks and sounds like a Homeworld game. Paul Ruskay is the composer of the music, as he was for the earlier Homeworld games.+As far as science fiction goes, the story is plausible and interesting and does not contradict lore established by the earlier games (note: Deserts of Kharak is a prequel).+Units gain bonuses if they see enough combat, giving some incentive to play optimally.-AI is rudimentary and unchallenging, even on hardest (Classic) difficulty. Enemy attacks en masse happen only by chance or when scripted to.-Blobs of units, self-repairing and requiring very little micromanagement, are a little too viable as a tactic.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												The only issue I have with this game is that the campaign becomes much too easy once  the Kapisi gets power available for use. As soon as it becomes weapons capable, unlike other Homeworld games, the Mothership itself becomes the strongest weapon in the fleet (With the exception of possibly Homeworld Cataclysm).   Fleet composition and maintenance become less and less important as the massive amount of units sent at you must be dealt with greater and greater force which is why I did not find that aspect of the game satisfying.Other than that, the game mechanics are fairly straightforward and function well: the rock paper scissors style of combat with LAS, Armor and Rails make battle easy to learn, but harder to master once you can mix it up with cruisers and other support. A good game and worth what I paid for it.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Overall, a solid game whose flaws are more than made up for by excellent atmosphere and style. Gameplay is similar to Homeworld, mostly minus the Z axis*, and has not been made overly complicated, which personally I approve of.* Some units benefit in terms of visibility (and damage?) from a height advantage.+Great atmosphere; looks and sounds like a Homeworld game. Paul Ruskay is the composer of the music, as he was for the earlier Homeworld games.+As far as science fiction goes, the story is plausible and interesting and does not contradict lore established by the earlier games (note: Deserts of Kharak is a prequel).+Units gain bonuses if they see enough combat, giving some incentive to play optimally.-AI is rudimentary and unchallenging, even on hardest (Classic) difficulty. Enemy attacks en masse happen only by chance or when scripted to.-Blobs of units, self-repairing and requiring very little micromanagement, are a little too viable as a tactic.

content:
Posted: March 3
												Homeworld:Deserts of Kharak, continues the tradition of what is not even contestable as being the first RTS environment. Homeworld and Homeworld 2 brought about an era of game play that has inspired hundreds of games such as Eve Online. A dedicated HW fan is able to see the connections."Mothership."Homeworld 2 : Eye of Aaran that cannot be traveled through.Eve Online : The Eve Gate collapsed trapping explorers in New Eden.Homeworld 2: Both S'jet and Maakan were isolate from the rest of the crew in vat tanks surrounded by embryonic fluid.Eve Online : Pilots are contained in "Egg Shaped" pods containing fluidHomeworld 2: There is a an "Easter Egg" that is part of the models but is never used.Homeworld 2: S'jet and Maakan are attached to each ship controlling its functions via implants.Eve Online : Pilots controll the ship functions surrounded by crew using implants. Homeworld : Deserts of Kharak : The Kushans begin to build great ships that will take them on a search for Hiigara using the Guidestone.Eve Online : Recently the Dev's of Eve Online has discussed introducing Exoplanet searches of finding something new that revolves around a lead female scientist being the instructor just like Rachel and Karan S'JetIt's obvious the comparissons are there and that the Homeworld series of RTS is the Hyperspace Core for Eve Online.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7
												Deserts of Kharak has most of the elements that make a great sci-fi RTS, but it comes together a bit clumsily in the end-- especially where UI and controls are concerned-- so that it's harder to play than it need be, and harder to recommend than it should be. As a long-time Homeworld fan I was pleasantly surprised at how well Deserts translates some of the aesthetic and design of previous games to a ground-based game. Deserts has great visuals and exciting sound worthy of the franchise. Unfortunately, the game is bogged down by a clunky hotkey system in comparison to previous Homeworld titles so that it can be hard to find and control units easily. Though the build menu allows you to create a queue, the research menu does not, and you can only access this by selecting the mothership (rather than just pressing 'r'). Altogether, there's a lot to like here, but it lacks the refinement that has given games like the original Homeworld its staying power as an RTS.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												Singleplayer delivers the homeworld feel pretty well. The feeling of isolation and limited resources is really nice. The persistent units and veterancy helps with giving you a sense of what is at stake.However it is short, and the AI isn't anything special but is challenging enough in the campaign as it can spawn tons of units and is heavily scripted.Skirmish isn't great, as there's too few maps and the AI cannot counter air units and in general isn't very good.Multiplayer isn't great either. The tech tree isn't entirely visible, so you'll have to memorize it while the gameplay is mostly focused on "getting a bigger blob" of units than your opponent. The game is not very focused on decisionmaking or strategy. There's little sense of "outsmarting" your opponent as it is you're "outplaying" him by keeping up your production constantly, getting the upgrades at the right times and expanding at the right time. You're not setting traps or making elaborate plans. You're just building units and trying to keep your economy intact while doing it.Some units have special abilities but they are not the focal point of the gameplay.TL;DR: The singleplayer campaign is interesting. Skirmish and multiplayer is not very interesting.
