content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												I think the game is a little overpriced right now; I got it because on preorder it came with the old homeworld games. If you bought the remaster on the steam sale you automatically get 20% off this game so that's an equivalent deal.Game runs decently well, even on ultra settings (i5/970) but in MP you probably want to play at lower settings for FPS. I like how you can press ALT to toggle sensor range / fog of war area, just try it because I'm not great at explaining it.So far so good except that when you play the campaign the cutscenes are unskippable which is annoying. MP modes seem fun, some folks at the Homeworld discord are streaming their MP matches now (release day afternoon).The most annoying things about playing the campaign right now are:- Can't pause to issue commands (hard to coordinate multi-pronged tactics, but I guess that's like playnig a MP game)- no labels for control groups- unskippable cinematics (unlike in the old homeworld games)I'll update when I play some more campaign and MP matches.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Just finished the camaign and absolutely loved the entire playthrough. Engaging storyline, fresh units, classic combat style and nice graphics backed by excellent voice acting, I couldn't stop playing the game until I had it seen it through to the end!Definitely recommended for both new & old players of homeworld, The game makes an effort to stay true to its homeworld roots while bringing something fresh to the table as a sequel.My only gripe: it ended too fast! 9 hours in, I've finished campaign with little effort (at normal difficulty). While I'll revisit the missions at classic difficulty now, it's unlikely to take me more than 24 hours of gameplay to finish it at this rate. Still, it's not a big con as the campaign is meant to get you comfortable with the game and it does that quite well. Now for the real challenge, I have to explore the multiplayer side of things where homeworld has always shined.Tips for players new to the game or genre:The AI in this game appears to have unlimited resources. It doesn't harvest anything so if you're hoping to just wait it out, it'll never stop sending squads your way. Yet instead of taking it as a negative aspect, use it! It's an excellent way to level your units up and raise their ranks if you position them correctly with a supporting cruiser backing them.Make extensive use of Rachael's hacking & emp ability. The enemies railgun cruiser is devestating in large enough numbers and can only be acquired through hacking (hacking requires upgrade for this but you will get it in due course of campaign)Units are precious as experience is hard to come by. Take care of your units. You may have a lot of resource at hand but new units cannot replace your veterans right out of factory. Make sure you keep them safe.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Premium RTS experience from veterans who built some of the best offerings in the genre.Approachable game play and controls immerse you in this highly polished environment wrapped in an engrossing story with excellent art and audio. Being able to maneuver the camera to see all angles of a map puts you in the middle of the action when you want to see the bird's eye view, or follow a single unit as it attacks an enemy.Interface with its keybound counterparts lets you activate commands quickly and not get jammed up with deep layers of menus.Combat is loud, flashy and fun with different units having their own characteristics and purpose in a fight.Blend of fast paced action and well told story encouraged me to want to jump to the next map after each battle. Hoping the complete campaign is as fun as the missions I've already played, and the game remains playable when the mayhem from later missions unfolds.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Story elements like any Homeworld game have been knocked out of the park, even with playing HW1 and 2 you still are invested, despite knowing the ending. They actually tried to flesh out the characters in this, which seems weird, you feel some connection to them, but they are relatively flat. Combat is interesting, though aligning your troops on a ridge is damn near impossible. Aircraft offers a good long range strike capability which is OP, unless they have some AA defenses, but still they can also be knocked out using aircraft. Despite the aircraft dominating land vehicles still are effective for holding ground so you can better position your aircraft. The little things are sadly underdone: docking, formations, tactics all seem to be gone which is saddening.Overall I recommend because it is relentlessly capturing, I could not put in down.

YouTube™ Video: Random Review - Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak 

			Views: 57		

			Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a Real Time Strategy game that has you leading a last ditch attempt at recovering a power artifact to assist in your peoples survival.		

Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak ditches the usual base building RTS mechanics in favour of a more manuevarable base carrier. The story is also very well entwined with the gameplay providing alot of different scenarios to play through rather then just going through the motions of building up a base some other RTS have become accustom to.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												I've not yet played all the way through the game, but have completed a little of the single player campaign. I'll write my thoughts now and update the review as I go through the game. This is my initial impressions.Graphics, gameplay and performanceAgain, graphically, the textures are of high detail for a RTS game and its a joy to zoom in and see the detail. Talking about the zoom, I like the tactical view, but, would love the ability to zoom out a little further, this game needs a supreme commander like tactical zoom. It can be tricky to navigate the battlefield when there is a lot going on.You can customise the look of you fleet, for each battle, away from the default JCB yellow and in skirmish/multiplayer, play as either of the two factions, the Coalition or the Gaalsien. The Gaalsien have production carriers, allowing them to create units anywhere on the map, where as the carrier does this job for the Coalition, so they have managed ti create two gameplay styles here.I played this on my Core i5 4670 with GTX 970 and it looked amazing, frame rate a costant 60fps, lovely to look and and play with such a smooth frame rate. All settings were set to maximum. The minimum requirments suggest a GT 440, which is less than half the power of the GTX 860m in my 3ghz core i5 4210h laptop. Initially I got an appauling framerate in 1080p, and wondered what it would be like on one of the older cards! Dropping to 1600x900 or 1280x720 resolution, settings can be upped to medium and a respectable 20 - 25 fps can be acheived. **Update** I investigated further to see the cause of the low framerate and it was a combination of things.Firstly a recent Windows 10 "upgrade" had reset many of my settings to default, so the nvidia GPU was on auto select and the game had chosen the onboard intel gpu to run it! Forcing the 860m to again be default gave me 60fps at ultra. :)The game seems stable and i've not experiences any crashing.Single PlayerLovely cut scenes and graphices, love the audio and it really adds to the atmosphere of the game. I played on normal and found the game very balanced and fun to play. The AI didnt overwhelm you, but put up a good fight. Early on you are led through the first misson propper, after the initial training mission.Skirmish mode.Oh dear, what happened here. I played this against and easy AI and it was impossible to get production off the ground, the AI relentlessly attacks from the off and you end up running out of resource collectoes before you have time to build any offensive units. Even when I did get some units, the AI player seemed to have overwhelming numbers very early on. The developers really need to fix this as the AI is stupidly hard to play against and skirmish mode is where the replay value is, co-op multiplayer vs the AI and so on.MultiplayerThe multiplayer is really good fun and when you introduce another player into the mix the AI responds diferently, is more cautious and doesnt bombard you with so many attacking units. Seems there are a fair number of people playing the game, so finding a multiplayer mach was relatively easy.Game modes are limited to Annialate everything, or just kill the carrier to win. You can turn artifacts on and off, these are kind of like capture the flag missions, get five to your extraction point and win the game.I'm not the best games player, so was easily beaten, but as i'm relatively new to this game I'm sure i'll get better.Overall, I'm enjoying the single player. Its just a shame about the low end perfomance at 1080p espically, and the insanly hard AI in skirmish mode on 1v1. I hope in the future there will be more in the way of units added, whether through dlc or free updates, as what you have on offer is limited.I paid 23.99 for the game and think it was money well spent. I'll do a final update when i've completed the campaign, so far I've found it very absorbing. The game reminds me very much of the origional homeworld games, and has a great look and feel to itI'll give the game a thumbs up for now, but will update the review as I go through the campeign :)

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Homeworld: Desert of Kharak is a great game a fantastic spin-off for the Homeworld franchise.Singleplayer campaign took me about 12 hours on the hardest difficulty setting, I got wrecked by the AI a few times and had to restart or reload from a save multiple times. The story is well written and executed, it is mostly fed to you through cutscenes and animatics. Even for fans of the original titles (who kinda know how the game is going to end, after all it`s a prequel) there are plenty of surprises!Multiplayer/Skirmish is fun but it suffers a bit from the low map choice (5 maps at release). At least in "Artifact Retrieval" mode (basically capture the flag) the AI can be very, very challenging actually, I can not confirm the experience of some reviewers here. Note that keys can not be rebound at the moment, though the standard layout of the quickbuttons is okay and usable. Performance was good on an i3 and a GTX 650 Ti, FPS did only drop in very, very, very intense situations (lots of units and boom). No major bugs encountered, except for an UI bug that caused returning from the options menu to be quite a wait (30 secs+). Only ever had a single crash so far, this occured right before loading a new mission. Although the title obviously still needs some work I am satisfied with this purchase and excited for upcoming new content (free maps have already been promised, further DLC are "in the pipe"). 8/10 would recommend

												Who would have though 12 years after homeworld 2 we'd still be waiting on a sequel.  Well here we are, and how pleasantly suprising it is to find a prequel that fits in so well with the established universe.For the unitinitated, homeworld is a series that lives and dies based on atmosphere and imersion.  And holy smokes, does this game deliver.  The campaign cutscenes are epic, the desert landscapes are vivid, and the tension feels real.  And holy smokes do I sound like a shill.This game is worth it for the campaign alone.  Some of us have waited years for a game to continue the homeworld legacy, and while its certainly not homeworld 3, and you can see the edges where the budget didn't quite come together, this is proably the most imersive RTS I've ever played.Buy the game.  Drive a landcarrier.  Play homeworld 3 someday. (maybe)

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												If you're a fan of the Homeworld series, this is a must-get.  If you're a fan of RTS, it's still a great game but due to the shorter than usual game length I'd probably wait for it to be on sale.  Beautiful graphics, immersive story, fantastic music.  Exploring the Deserts of Kharak years before the events of Homeworld brings a whole new level of epic for the original game.  The voice acting is top notch and deserves special mention.  The random yet relevant radio chatter is a welcomed addition and pays pure homage to the original Homeworld in that respect, something Homeworld 2 did poorly.This game has actual difficulty levels.  Easy, Normal, and Classic Mode--being more in line to Homeworld I and II's arguably frustrating difficulty.  9.4/10, absolutely love it.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												As you can guess by the name Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a prequel to the first groundbreaking Homeworld game.Of course you’re not in space this time but on the world of Kharak fighting a ground and air war against your enemies. In typical Homeworld fashion your ship a massive is LANDCARRIER is forced to start it’s journey and fight battles before it was ready to. Unlike with the Motherships in the previous games, the Kapisi is not only a mobile production center but a warship able to destroy the enemy all by itself. Another change from the earlier games is you find out about the people who crew this ship. The most important of these characters is Rachel S’Jet. A science officer who plays a critical part in the story and has her personal reasons for being on this expedition. But you also find out about the captain, different officers and even your more experienced vehicle commandeers will have names given to them. The AI isn’t the best and Blackbird has promised to work at fixing this and more multiplayer maps are said to be on the way. The number of missions is huge, but they are fairly varied and things can go sideways at times and your original goals might go out the window. Despite it’s flaws it is a good game and I look forward to spending no small amount of time playing in the sand. sm

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												This is a RTS with a new perspective of the Homeworld universe more of a prequel as it tells the story of an expidition force scowering the deserts of their planet for the salvation of their people. Your base is basically an aircraft carrier on treads called the Kapisi, you can reasearch, build and upgrade units from it and as you progress through the game it will also be one of your most powerful weapons (cue tomahawk missle). The bulk of your forces will consist of various attack vehicles of many roles and sizes but the best part is when you get aircraft. Nothing beats playing the song Dangerzone while launching fighters into enemy territory! The AI in the campaign is ok, but skirmish is where things are much to be desired. You'll be rushed quite a bit in the beginning with quite a few units, but as soon as you pick you balls up and build up a sizable the AI starts ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ itself it just.... you win... basically, you walk your army to it's carrier and blow it to hell.The Good- the story is good for homeworld players- the unit designs are good- the art in general is amazing- the voice acting is good quality- combat is fluid - units have a reasonable rock-paper-scissor mechanicThe Bad- AI needs more work- Story feels a bit shortThe VerdictThis is a is good game but it's still kind of a diamond in the rough, it has the ability to be a top notch RTS game it just needs a couple more updates to skirmish to make solo play all the more enjoyable. I give it a 7/10, I can't lie it was hard putting down $50 but overall I don't regret it.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30
												The good-Prequel to a classic. All pros of the space RTS carry over.-Solid RTS you expect from Homeworld.  There is a good reason to delay finishing a mission to harvest resources. Surviving untis carry over to the next mission and each has a purpose, abilities, and strenghs and weakness to consider. -Terrain elevation and line of sight really makes a difference. Terrain will show deformation and burnt chassis.-Each level bring a unique obstacle to overcome. -Some enemy units and tactics can feel cheap and spammy but preperation and good strategy will always win out. It helps to be patient and methodical and it feels tremendous when you overcome.-Tactical overlay is better than ever. -Strong narrative. A Focused origin story. Handles themes of systemic oppression and religious fervor quite well.  Its dramatic, somber, compelling, well paced and expressed with beautifully illustred animatics.-Visuals are pretty. The Desert is vibrant and varied. Explosions kick up big plums of sand. Wear and tear show up on selected vehicles and debris liters the sands.-The audio is nothing short of outstanding. The voice work is strong, the OST is recognizable and adds more of the Middle-eastern flair that's familiar to Homeworld and something that you would expect from being in a desert but the sound effects and Ambience is where this game really shines. Everything from vehicles driving on dunes, random radio chatter, gunfire, missile volleys, hits and ricochets, explosions, battle chatter, and aerial vehicles swooshing overhead is so atmospheric that it would be forgiven to overhear it and mistake it as real.  I'd go so far as to say that the tactical ambience is revolutionary for the RTS genre as a whole.The bad-The game can crash. Crashing after logging 30mins+ into a mission that's going well is irratating beyond emotes.-No keybindings! A PC game in 2016 (last i played) what a sacrilege.The ugly-My system more than meets the requirements but the game can get glitchy in long play sessons. Debris and burnt chassis can cause crashes if they keep getting strewn all over the battlefiled.-Clipping and units will sometimes phase through each other.-Units can freeze in place and spaz out from time to time. Despite the bugs if you're an RTS fan, Homeworld as a whole is definitely worth playing and worth the price of admission. Thank you Gearbox and Blackbird.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												I wanted to like Deserts of Kharak, I truly did. It represents the first truly new thing for the Homeworld franchise in over a decade. As a hardcore fan of the first two games who plasters the Hiigaran insignia over everything, real or virtual, and can recite all the cinematics from memory, I *really* wanted to like this game. But I can't.A mediocre RTS that manages to have more bugs and fewer features than its now-teenaged predecessors (no formations, no stances, shadows are a mess, etc.). Its very existence depends on a retcon of existing canon (the extensive historical and technical briefing book originally released with Homeworld 1 states categorically that no major conflicts occurred for centuries prior to Homeworld 1, the version of this book printed by Gearbox in the re-issue changes this fact to allow for Deserts of Kharak to exist) and it goes out of its way to twist that canon like a pretzel (spoiler warning: you'd think someone would've mentioned the giant orbital death ray left behind and been less surprised when the people who placed it showed up again). Furthermore, it couldn't even make its surprise twist surprising, and somehow manages to look worse than the Homeworld: Remastered games that came out *before* this did.For existing Homeworld fans: Look elsewhere, this is just a worse version of what we've already got that takes dumb liberties with the story.For those who've never played Homeworld: Look elsewhere (might I suggest Homeworld?), there are better RTS games out there (like Homeworld).

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												I am one of the 700 people who backed this game as a Prospector in 2013 when it was first announced, because I'm a Homeworld nerd and  loved the idea of the spiritual sucessor of Homeworld. I even tracked the progress of this game all the way to release because I believed so much in this project.Almost all the other reviewers here have ticked the typical checklist: the game is beautiful, the interactive manual is meaty and full of the lore goodness which has been missing from games, the campaign is great but...The multiplayer aspect doesn't work.The devs kept on talking up the MP aspect of the game and how amazingly competitive it's going to be, but it doesn't work. To make things worse, on the rare off-chance the MP works and you are able to wait out the 15-minute matchmaking timer, the players are horrid. I've had people banzai-charge their carriers into enemy lines, I've had roleplayers spamming chat with RP while doing nothing in the game but sending 4 LAVs to die. I won't mind the trouble of waiting for the multiplayer function to be fixed if the community is great, but it's worse than the "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥" and "putang ina mo" spammers in CS:GO and Dota2. But no, this game has no longevity as long as the MP function doesn't work, and the devs have not said a single peep on intending to fix it.And oh, it's not worth it to even play Skirmish with AI because the AI is pants-on-head ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.As much as I want to like this game, I cannot in good conscience recommend this game to fellow gamers.tl;dr the game is cool but has no longevity because multiplayer does not work. Do not buy unless it's $15 on a future Steam sale.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Beautiful, story and narrative driven RTS. This will be an ongoing, updated review, as I progress through the campaign.CAMPAIGNI've completed the first two missions and the tutorial so far. If you enjoy any of the following, I'd recommend the game based on my limited play: Hard-sci fi narrative in RTS A decent mix of tactics and strategy Big Damn TrucksThe gameplay is much like the Homeworld series, streamlined, with an even greater emphasis on narrative. The game is gorgeous, and as mentioned, it's all about Big Damn Trucks.This is a game that emphasizes strategy, not actions per minute. There's a nice combination of use of high ground, and unit special abilities to keep engagements fresh and allow specializations.BBI has been great about supporting the game. If you're a fan of their art style, the DLCs are well worth it. I've generally had a wonderful time with this, and definitely think this product is worthy of support. It will likely never be as big as Starcraft, but it's not trying to be that. ConsNo docking animations for resource harvesters.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												I like the way this game feels, I like the strategic overview, I like the general vibe.This does not make up for the fact that this game is bug-ridden and has some of the absolute worst unit pathing I have EVER encountered in an RTS. You can't change your hotkeys at all, the camera is obnoxious, music and cinematic sound are inexplicably linked. I had often wondered why so few of the people I know purchased this game, and now I absolutely know why. I can't even complete a mission because of a bizzare bug that has not been fixed since launch. What the hell?This feels like a game from 15 years ago with good effects quality. I'll likely complete it, and I definitely enjoy the story, but I can't possibly recommend a game with such poor quality of life, pretty much across the board. This was the opportunity to bring Homeworld back into the genre properly and it feels as though it's been wasted.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Best RTS game I've played in a long time....Just finished the single player campaign and I was impressed with this game. A pleasant surprise in the RTS genre! I've never played the Homeworld series, but I'm looking forward to playing those next (especially since the remastered editions came free with this).Pros:- Good unit selection with useful upgrade options carefully spread across the campaign- Gameplay is challenging, but not overwhelming on 'normal difficulty'- Interesting story with a climactic campaign- Excellent graphics!- Persistent resources/units makes you consider options more carefully before spending resources (which pays off in later scenarios)- Good use of terrain/elevation - Strategic map works well, which is good since you use it alot!Cons:- UI graphics were almost cartoonish in nature- Aircraft AI needs some work (airplanes refuse to land and bombers can hover too long in target areas)- Short Campaign (13 missions)Also, desert missions looked great but would be nice to get away from the sand in any future DLC/expansions.Highly Recommended!

content:

Posted: January 21, 2016
												Few hours into the game I can say that this is a must have for any Homeworld/RTS fan.Graphics: 9/10 - I am not 100% happy with AA as it stands out with everything else being gorgeous.  Also occasional rapid turn animation of aircraft breaks the immersion.Storyline 10/10 - so far I am loving it and it is a mix of original Homeworld with some elements of Battlestar Galactica in the desert setting (not to give out anything else)Strategy 6/10 - at least early missions remind me of FF13 where you have pretty much one way with smallish side pockets.  Later on it opens up so gameplay is fun for an RTS.  Fairly limited resources and locations slightly limit your angles and the game doesn't feel as open as some of the other strategies out there but it is far away from being linear.Over all: SOLID and fun gameplay and most of all bug free on release!

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Having played +20 hours multiplayer I can say this is a lot of fun. One of my favorite multiplayer games I have played. reminds me a lot of world in conflict which I loved growing up but this game takes all the good about that game and leaves all the negetives behind. the los battle combined with high ground and such is so interesting and fun. battles feel more like a dance as players jockey for the best postions. if this where it it wouldnt be so fun since the game would turn into who has high ground wins game, but with the relics and having to take them to extraction zones your forced to not only defend your    own relics but attack the enemies as well. the way the units are done is also really good, they have a nice balance bettween the different types. the railgun for instance is a long range heavy damage unit but it is a glass cannon and to get use of it's full attack range you need lav's which are fast and have a short range but fast firing gun, which can easily swarm over a bunch of unsupported railguns. to blance this all out there is armored units whihc the lav's do basicly no damage to but the railguns tear up if at range, due to there slower speed. if you can get close to railguns using cover or smoke your amrored units will tear the railguns up. add in height advatanges and experince as well as limted resources and time and you have an interesting dynamic which forces you to be out on the map in an ever changing battle.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												*Review has been updated below with regards to the Expedition Guide DLC*At the time of writing this review, I have finished the Campaign on Normal difficulty and played a couple of skirmishes against Hard AI. Not tried Multiplayer yet or the Classic Campaign, may update review later if I try them. I played the Remastered Collection to completion and know the storyline of Cataclysm.Pros:Fantastic visual design and art. Cutscenes are beautiful, artwork is beautiful, maps are usually beautiful, but occassionally not to the same standards of Sup Com 2 and similar titles.Music is as good as the originals I'd say, definitely the same feel.A few nice gameplay mechanics - such as acquiring new resources and artifacts from destroying wreck bulkheads, Carrier power systems, etc.Meh:Unit design is nice far out, kinda flat when zoomed in. This is an RTS though, you get most of the pretty factor focused away from the very expendable, very numerous units. Unit combat has a few visual bugs such as firing angles being messed up, and units hit by heavy weaponry sometimes do somersaults. Aircraft that are shot down will bounce as though they are made of rubber sometimes, but look very cool at least.Couple of frame freezes in big battles but game ran smoothly for the most part.Cons:Story is a bit barebones. I know Homeworld is very much about saying a lot with very little, but it seems like they only managed the very little part here; it comes close to capturing the feel of the story but misses the mark a bit. There's quite a few points where something is mentioned and never expanded on too. I think I might need to access that Expedition Guide DLC and see if it has the missing pieces there, but it feels like a lot of the additional lore and background for this game is simply not present. I'm also not really satifised with many of the wrecks present in the game; a couple of them especially feel like retconns, well, nearly all of them are iirc besides the Khar-Toba. A couple in particular are very questionable additions in my view though, and the ending itself was a little underwhelming. There's little characterisation in the game and little exposition.Combat is very Rock, Paper, Scissors. A lot of the time it boils down to "Does the Enemy have AA?". If not, use air. If yes, use a Cruise Missile and ask the question again. If still yes, then send in the ground troops; otherwise, you'll be spending more money rebuilding troops than you spend on Cruise Missiles blowing everything to kingdom come. On Normal difficulty, I spent the majority of the game sitting on a surplus of least 40K CU and 4K RU, patiently waiting for a challenge to come that'd need me to rebuild. It never did, because Cruise Missile <-> Air ---> Ground Troops is the solution to everything.Enemy AI is braindead. The Enemy will never react to your actions smartly, if you use air often, it'll never build more AA than it otherwise is preordained to. This makes air the solution to every problem in Skirmish mode, and most of your problems in the Campaign too. In Campaign, it'll send cookie cutter attack waves that are easily predictable due to how sensors work and the complete lack of stealth mechanics. Normally they can be dealt with by air, sometimes you'll want a Cruise Missile instead. Sometimes you'll just bludgeon them to death with a souped up combat powered Carrier. The enemy never seems to use abilities, and difficulty is more of a setting of 'How much shall the AI cheat?' with regards to their resource collection. The Enemy will rarely retreat, if ever, even under overwhelming fire or fire it cannot fire back upon. It will either sit there and die or chase you blindly and die.Unit AI is a bit off at times. Nothing co-ordinates their attacks intelligently, such as splitting their fire if they know they will kill the enemy in a single attack. This leads to entire airstrikes being wasted on a single light attack vehicle when a cluster of assault vehicles are behind it, and artillery fire being massed on singlular points rather than covering an entire wave. So you are forced to micromanage your artillery and air, to prevent your most powerful assets being wasted on the weakest units. Everything aims for overkill, and everything targets the first thing in sight, not the most dangerous or most relevant to their preferred target class.Controls are strange and un-rebindable.The 3D aspect of the game doesn't see much facetime due to the skewed balance towards air. No high ground is higher than the sky. But besides that, a lot of the time it requires finicky micromanagement to make proper use of it due to the lack of a Company of Heroes style click and drag movement control. Trying to organise units into a formation facing in one way in this game is a nightmare. Formations in general in this game are nightmarish to manage, the default unit layout is abysmal and will lead only to defeat and despair. No targetable subsystems on larger vehicles or the Carrier itself, nor much unit variety beyond some simplistic balance where basically smaller direct combat unit is the counter to bigger indirect combat unit (if it survives long enough to reach it) which is counter to similar sized direct combat unit which is the counter to smaller sized direct combat unit. I.E. LAVs > Railguns > AAVs > LAVs and their cruiser cousins appear to follow the same pattern but ground combat is unneccessary against the AI by that point as you have air units. Abilities are generally uninteresting beyond the AAV smokescreen which is actually both useful and interesting. There are no units comparable to Destroyers or Dreadnoughts though. Just fighters, corvettes and frigates really.Conclusion:The game feels rushed. It feels like the purely multiplayer title (no computer AIs iirc) Hardware: Shipbreakers was instead rapidly transformed into a singleplayer game that wanted to be a Homeworld prequel, but didn't have the time or resources left to flesh out the story or build a worthwhile computer AI. As a result, we have neither the very promising Hardware: Shipbreakers, nor do we have the fully realised Homeworld prequel that either Gearbox or Blackbird ended up pushing for. What we have is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of the two, a Homeworld story set in the Hardware: Shipbreakers game with plenty of crossed circuitry and not much of it functional.It comes very close to being a brilliant game, but the AI is woeful to the point of inexcusable, and the story did not satisfy me, hopefully the Expedition Guide changes that but I doubt it. Combat becomes quite boring once you figure out that Air is supreme, and unlock the Cruise Missile.To end with, I recommend this game if it is on sale for anything around 50% off - £15 or less. It feels like a half-baked standalone expansion pack, not a AAA RTS title. I'm dissappointed, and hope they can fix the AI issues soon so that Blackbird does not suffer too much for this muckup.Expedition Guide UpdateI've read most of the Expedition Guide now, it contains most of the setting and background I felt was missing from the Campaign itself, and contains hints towards either possible expansions/sequels, or ideas that were not realised in time to be implemented in this game. However, it does not make up for the Story itself in my eyes, nor does it negate the issues with combat in this game at all.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												Homeworld is back.The singleplayer is beautiful. The sounds as in background chatter and music are just right and much like the orignals. Throw in sand tornado's gigantic rolling sandstorms the GFX are beautiful. The missions are progressive and take the player through the learning steps of how to play the game. The end is well it makes this a standalone by its self much like cata. Overall very fun game.That said there is such a huge strategic side to this game. You want to keep you units alive because they level up. Each unit has a name and Xp. The more you keep them alive the stronger they get. So Blob tactics will get you killed quickly. Especially in multiplayer you need to work with your team to plan attacks and get out with the least losses.Each race has its good and bad points for multi. In the end I would say try it. The single player alone is worth it and Multiplayer is very hard if your looking for a good stratigic game. This is it.Knowing the modding community on this is huge. Expect a lot of fun mods for this. Already a few mods out for fun.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Full disclosure:  I'm about 3 hours into it right now.   I'll update this after I finish the game.  So take this as a first impressions after getting a few missions under my belt.I played a lot of homeworld back in the day.  I really enjoyed it.   For me this has fell a bit flat.   I'll list out some pros and cons I've felt playing it.pros:+ homeworld kinda-feel+ carrier can behave as a unit that is very effective depending on how you distribute the power+ nostalgia around the control scheme+ unit persistence+ tech upgrades+ beautiful, although somewhat boring, terrain+ simplification of y axis movement (or maybe removed?)cons:- physics engine almost seems not to exist.   -  height advantage is nice in theory, but is a constant struggle as you fight the camera to figure out where high ground is relative to other units.-  constant fighting with control scheme and figuring out which units are which. - textures are inconsistent.   Some are decent, others are just horrible.  - missions seem to follow a formula that is as predictable as ever.   Do something non-combat related, prepare to trigger waves of enemies.- scale of stuff is really strange and disappointing.   Some of the cut scenes have the correct scale, but then you have a ship that fits a few people in it (like the science team unit) and the giant carrier not looking as big as it should outside of a cutscene.   I get it, a lot of RTS do this, but there's some weirdness in that sometimes scale is preserved and sometimes it isn't.  Plus, with the camera zooming functions you kinda expect reasonably to scale.- story seems to try to replicate the homeworld experience,  like with the launching of the carrier -- but it just doesn't feel as grand.   It feels like you're a petty raider.   Story not very well explained as to even what your character understand of the world. -  objectives seem very outward facing without the original story and characters backing up your fight for survival.  -  unit persistence can cause some problems at higher difficulty if you barely win a mission.  Mitigating this is the option to use a default set of units for the mission. -  knowing where you can move units based on height of terrain is difficult or impossible until you try to move.Right now my feeling is if you are a die hard homeworld fan like myself you will find this generally enjoyable.   For others I can't really recommend the game.  Will update after I finish.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Its a mixed bag that to me smells of publisher interference, I'll explain.- The core gameplay is there but it lacks the finesse of previous Homeworld games such that battles become more one of attrition than playing smart.- The look and feel is Homeworld even though its not in space, BBI have done a good job there and the story telling works well... Until the end where it stops far far too short? If you aren't into Homeworld you are going to struggle with the plot imho because the ending isn't explained well at all almost as if they didn't want to fully cross over into HW1 territory just yet.- Had a go at MP with a friend and soon discovered an OP early game strategy which basically blows MP out the water for now.In summary then the basic game is there and is solid but to me it feels like I'm playing 1/2 a game (and suspect the 2nd half is on its way in 1yr time). Its almost like Gearbox is testing the market to see if "Homeworld 2016" can work and opted for a shortened/summarised version.Would I recommend it? Yes I would, I wouldn't call it 9/10 material though it clearly had the potential if it was allowed to mature. Overall BBI did a good job and really their fault is in not releasing what I would call a complete and well-rounded game but what they have done they have done well. To draw an analogy a little like Elite Dangerous where what was done was good but there needs to be more for it to work properly for the player/User Experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												Deserts of Kharak, while good, is somewhat difficult to recommend at its current price. The campaign, while quite good for the most part, has a frustrating last mission/ending (although maybe they assume most who are playing have also played the first Homeworld game, which takes place soon afterward) and fewer missions than I would've liked. The art style is terrific, although certain things, like the textures, are a little muddy (it also drops a lot of frames in parts where I feel it shouldn't; I have a GTX 970 with an i7 3.5 Ghz CPU and 8 Gigs of DDR3). I have yet to try multiplayer, but there only appears to be 5 maps, which for an RTS in 2016 is too low. The game itself alot fun to play, with cool unit design, old school RTS gameplay and some pretty unique game mechanics. The vehicle physics are particularly impressive, with dune buggies jumping and tumbling all over the place. There are only two factions in the game, as has always been the case with the Homeworld franchise, which didn't bother me as much as it might others. There aren't a WHOLE lot of units, but there are tons of upgrades that offer them a great deal of flexibility. I am hoping that Black Bird Interactive will add more multiplayer maps soon, as I believe that interest in this game will die pretty quickly with only the 5 available (which would be a huge shame).  In short, if this game were even $10.00 cheaper I wouldn't hesitate recommending it to anyone, but at its current price I suggest you check out gameplay videos and get a feeling for it. If the asking price doesn't scare you away and you like supporting small, new and promising development studios (or just the Homeworld franchise), you'll get plenty of RTS bang out of your buck from DoK.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
												I think whether you like Deserts of Kharak will depend on which parts of the previous Homeworld games you like. If you enjoy the story, art, sound, aesthetics, missions, and basic combat, then grab it on sale and you'll be quite satisfied.If you enjoy careful tactical choices, then you'll be a little disappointed. While there are some new  tactical tools in the dunes -- new to the Homeworld series, anyway --  your fleet will be simpler, and your ability to direct your units is cruder. I'm no RTS expert, but in the singleplayer campaign I often ended up resigned to controlling a "big slow blob of death", due to the difficulty of micromanaging and the lack of formations.The single-player campaign on Medium difficulty took about 10 hours, which to a certain extent may represent a less attrition-based pacing.Pro: * Has all the right Homeworld looks.* Has all the right Homeworld sounds.* Units have cover and indirect fire.* Height advantage when firing on lower enemies.* Smoke screens.* Centralized control of air units seems odd at first, but it works.* Powerful veterancy bonuses.Cons:* No more ability to pause and issue orders in solo campaign.* No formations: Difficult to prevent fast units from staying with slower ones without micromanagement or ordering them to "guard" the slowest unit.* Key-combinations are less expansive and cannot be re-bound.* No more unit engagement rules (chase vs guard).* No more unit tactics (trading speed for firepower).* Your land-carrier is your only production unit.  * Some unskippable mission cutscenes* Unit icons/portraits could be more distinctive from one-another.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Wish there was a middle ground for reviews other than a strict Y/N. As it stands right now, my answer would be only if you were a fan of RTS games. Keep in mind, I am new to Homeworld. I have the Remastered collection, but have less than an hour or two in it. Got it on sale and have barely touched it. Think that hols true for many of us on many games.Here is why I wish for a middle ground for reviews. In the last few missions, it got to be somewhat easy, even against the "overwhelming" enemy AI. I just spammed air units and cruise missiles and such while keeping my core forces around the Kapisi and my salvage crews.  I played the game on Medium (two stars) difficulty. Then again, I have had somewhat extensive experience playing RTS games in the past and have greatly enjoyed doing so myself. Then again, I did greatly enjoy the missions and it did eventually present a challenge, even if is was only when the friendly AI derped and Rachel was left hanging instead of following the main force around. I enjoyed the concept of the upgradeable and mobile base and units. The UI was refreshingly simple and easy. Use the carrier for production and research. You have deployable repair/collection units. The rest of your units are combat/combat support types. (Very broad categories here.) i have not really tried out skirmish and multiplayer, so can not write a review on those game modes at the moment.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												im recommending this game for a few reasons, namely because it's a "prequel" to the homeworld series which will open up more of the story and let you play through it, also because it does feel like homeworld.the game itself feels like homeworld. the units are different, but pretty much act and feel a lot like what you would see in the current landscape of war on our planet with some other high tech stuff mixed in, but not a lot. it's very realistic feeling, even for it being sci-fi. some of the things they have in this game are not far fetched in the scope of them being able to be used here on our planet, if we didn't have water that is. the planet is actually from what i can tell, a lot bigger than earth, which gives a lot of scope to the realism of having massive aircraft carriers that have wheels and rolling across huge seas of sand. the reason i say it feels like homeworld is the resource harvesting, the overlay, the ui, the maps, the radar screen, even some of the sounds when you have a unit selected. they start talking like they did in homeworld and it kind of freaked me out a little bit the first time i heard some of them talking about there being contacts nearby and what not. some of them would say some pretty cool stuff when there were no contacts nearby. the way you move units with attack move will show you the line of sight option as well as the elevation of the world. the unit cap increases as you go along and collect artifacts. you can capture units with your science officer, but be careful about going over unit cap as you can not capture planes to my knowledge (as in i havent tried it) and if you go over unit cap u will not be able to replace your planes. the planes (there are 3 types) are going to really make a difference in this game.for some tips:-use your aircraft carrier as a mobile gun/support craft with aa and move it closer to the fight as much as possible, if not even using it as a main target to draw fire at times repairing it with your support vehicles and letting your other units fight, this is especially helpful when you are out of cu's and they have a lot of aa and u cant get any more cu on the map.-support units are your friends but will not be able to autorepair themselves unless u find a module mid-late game, so use a couple support modules for your main group of fighting units-always keep cu available for your baserunners and the shipbreaking abilities from your salvagers/rachel-always keep as many planes as possible in your carrieri played this on classic difficulty, i restarted from a save at the beginning of one mission in the very early game because i kept screwing up. then only one mission did it make me restart mid-late game because i couldnt keep the objective, aced it and captured units after i did it the second time. 10/10 for massive air game and ground game10/10 for prequel to homeworld10/10 for quality productbuy this game so we can play on multiplayer please...

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												Because i detest long text reviews myself, here i will keep as short as i possibly can. Also, i didnt touch multiplayer so keep that in mind. The credits rolled for me 10 mins prior to writing this.Veterans of the series who have played all the previous games quite a bit, will find even the hardest difficulties too easy. That isnt a fault of the game, but rather the fact that you know more than most, making the game not balanced for you. Veterans such as myself will adore this game and be sad when the relatively short (its long enough, but you kinda want more after the credits roll), the sounds, visuals, art style, cinematics and emotion are all amazing. The gameplay is 100% Homeworld. Only, set on a planet. At one point in the campaign, you will be annoyed at a plot twist, considering previous story elements. No spoilers. As for newbies, you only have to learn the basics of finite resources, two types of resources, the value of different vehicles and general functionality. Once you have gained that, it will become easy to master. If you manage to figure out the true objective of each mission (that is never made obvious) and end up making the latter half of the game effortless, you know you have discovered exactly how the original Homeworld games worked. :P

Posted: January 24, 2016
												I just finished the campaign and played a few skirmishes.The game rules aren't exactly the same in the campaign and in the multiplayer.Overall, the story and cutescenes are good, it is definitly an homeworld game. I still prefer HW2, but DOK is quite funny.Several physics bugs encountered (a few pathfinding problems, vehicles jumping in the air for no reason...).The real problem in this game is that units aren't "smart" like they were in HW2  : they aren't autonomous at all, sometime they'll have allies getting attacked a few millimeters outside their action range and they won't even come to help like they did in HW2. The "aggressive, neutral and defensive" behaviors are really lacking. They aren't any formations for your fleets either : those damn support cruiser will often walk over your lines of tanks and it looks ridiculous, and the cruiser exposes itself to enemy fire on the top of that. To have exactly what you want, you must micromanage every class of unit.The graphics are good, but expect a few crashes on certain missions.

												This was a great pre-quel to a Real Time Strategy game that revolutionized an industry. The dynamics of playing on land rather then space but still keeping the feel of the original game are observed.  The story campaign is short, sweet, and full of drama and a real plot unlike most stories.  The gameplay is quick, many units counter other units,  geography is key as height gives you an advantage when shooting down on your oppenent. The graphics are beauitul the gameplay is great. Its one of the better Real Time Strategy games out there. Iv'e played over a dozen hours on Multiplayer they are always fun experiences. The only badside is lack of maps but the developers are going to release more soon. A lot of the issues brought up by people are being observed by the Developeres and they are going to be releasing patches with updates, new Maps, Replay ability and more. I believe they wanted to test the waters and make a great gameplay and later on when they had the resources give the game the much needed polishing it needs to be an outstanding Real Time Strategy game.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Fun RTS game at a time when there are virtually no new RTS games.What I played: the single-player campaign all the way to the last mission, a few scirmish games against the AI and human opponents.The good: the game feels like Homeworld. The music, art, unit design, UI all give the game that distinctive Homeworld look. Controlling units is a breeze and the UI is very clean and not very cluttered. Camera controls are also very smooth. There is a decent variety of units and you need to use most units effectively to achieve victory. There is no single massively over-powered unit that you can just build and win the game. Elevation and line of sight are done very well and are very important to winning each battle with minimal casualties. I found the story (a prequel to original Homeworld) to be a pretty good one, although anyone who has played the original Homeworld will know the story already. Although the entire game is set in a desert I loved it anyway because of how beautiful the game looks and there are still different desert types. It really made me think of Dune and how awesome it would be if Dune was remade using a modern engine.The bad: the campaign is short, it took me about 8 hours to get to the last mission and there is no replayability value in the single-player campaign. It's not like Starcraft 2 campaigns with some branchine choices and big diversity of units. The voice acting in the campaign is not stellar and I didn't care much about the characters (heck, I don't think I can remember more than two or three names of in-game characters). The AI is terrible, it's not much of a challenge even on hard and it cheats aggressively to offer even this meager challenge. The scirmish mode is fun but it needs more than just 5 maps and two different game types (destroy the carrier and artifact hunt). Furthermore, there are only two factions and although their tech trees and units are slightly different, they don't really have that big a difference in play styles and tactics. There is a bit of color customization but otherwise you can't customize the look of your units.Bottom line: this is a good RTS with a lot of potential, but at the moment there just isn't enough content in the game to warrant the price. I liked it a lot but I would recommend waiting until it's on sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												I'm in love with this game. While you can find it strange, I will try to explain why.I like this military drama story. Aside from that, I like how BBI used the Homeworld lore and added stuff to it. After a series of my recent disappointments like HotS (what they did to Kerrigan is abysmal if we take Brood Wars into account) and SW7 it is such a pleasure to watch the coherence with HW1&2 story.Scenery is not as diverse as I wanted but it is okay for a desert planet. Unit design is sometimes cubic but I have no problem since it looks organic and intended: we have a really advanced and exotic race focused on hid and run tactics and slow but sure utilitarian design race. Which leads you to gameplay which is insanely addictive, watching the battlefield from a close distance can consume me for hours, excellent soundtrack adds to it and multiplayer... It is insane how many tactics you can use and how many builds you can choose since both races similar but plays different. Balance needs some tweaks but the core looks very promising now. The only thing I want to complain about is spawned enemy forces in campaign on higher difficulty, looks a bit cheap but who cares? It just intensifies the campaign :)It has small bugs but nothing game breaking and almost all titles have them these days so I am used to it.If you want a clone of Starcraft or Supreme Commander then this game is definitely not for you. And I am completely unsure about the e-sport part (since I personally don't care about it) so no input here. But if you can live with some rough edges and ready to invest into learning of this game's mechanics then you can find it just as fun as I am.Crossing my fingers and hoping for a long after launch support.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
												I think whether you like Deserts of Kharak will depend on which parts of the previous Homeworld games you like. If you enjoy the story, art, sound, aesthetics, missions, and basic combat, then grab it on sale and you'll be quite satisfied.If you enjoy careful tactical choices, then you'll be a little disappointed. While there are some new  tactical tools in the dunes -- new to the Homeworld series, anyway --  your fleet will be simpler, and your ability to direct your units is cruder. I'm no RTS expert, but in the singleplayer campaign I often ended up resigned to controlling a "big slow blob of death", due to the difficulty of micromanaging and the lack of formations.The single-player campaign on Medium difficulty took about 10 hours, which to a certain extent may represent a less attrition-based pacing.Pro: * Has all the right Homeworld looks.* Has all the right Homeworld sounds.* Units have cover and indirect fire.* Height advantage when firing on lower enemies.* Smoke screens.* Centralized control of air units seems odd at first, but it works.* Powerful veterancy bonuses.Cons:* No more ability to pause and issue orders in solo campaign.* No formations: Difficult to prevent fast units from staying with slower ones without micromanagement or ordering them to "guard" the slowest unit.* Key-combinations are less expansive and cannot be re-bound.* No more unit engagement rules (chase vs guard).* No more unit tactics (trading speed for firepower).* Your land-carrier is your only production unit.  * Some unskippable mission cutscenes* Unit icons/portraits could be more distinctive from one-another.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Atmospheric and fairly engaging, but don't expect strategic depth on the level of a Starcraft-tier RTS. Think more like Supreme Commander 2 but on a more tactical scale. Combat features generally small engagements with well under 100 units per side, and the campaign can be drawn out in terms of time (especially by completionists who make sure to mine every penny on a map before moving on), but it isn't very complicated or difficult. The UI can also be a little wonky at times (good luck figuring out weapon ranges, and just try getting units to form up facing a particular direction), and it would be nice if the main camera could zoom out a little more so we don't always have switch to the strategic view.Nonetheless, good voice acting, very good - and mature, thoguhtful - writing, nicely done cutscenes, and excellent music all combine with a beautiful aesthetic to make something very enjoyable. The levels may just all be rocks and sand, but they're memorable, and even though a couple of the units tend to blend into each other when amassed in great piles and viewed at a distance, a lot of thoughtful detail has been put into the audio-visual experience.It's soothing. It may not require tactical genius or bring very much new to the RTS genre, but it's a fun piece of art.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												This was my first experience with the Homeworld games, as such as I had no idea what the storyline was or how the game's dynamics function. With that being said, it took me 9 hours of play to make it through the campaign on 'normal' difficulty. The last mission took 3 attempts. I would definitely recommend this game for RTS fans, but be aware that the terrain directed fighting is mostly a joke. Line of sight should give you an advantage, having the high ground should give you an advantage... both of these things do, sometimes, but usually not. Enemies can sometimes fire through hills. But so can you, somtimes.All in all it was a fun 9 hours with a storyline that kept me engaged and the cutscenes... oh boy those cutscenes, absolutely gorgeous!

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												I do recommend this game, but not at this $54.99 CDN price. The campaign, as you'd expect from a team responsible for the original Homeworld, Dawn of War, and Company of Heroes series, is amazing. Depending on difficulty, it's only about 10-15 hours though. Anyone who considers themselves a fan of RTS owes it to themselves to play it at some point, but not for this price. I'd suggest waiting for 50% off. The MP community is already fairly dead just a few weeks after release. The MP portion is pretty threadbare - not many maps, no replay system, matches last about 15-30 minutes. The depth of tactics and strategy is not comparable to the games mentioned above. It does have veterancy, unit abilities, and some nice terrain/line of site mechanics but would need a lot of work and expansions to give it more depth and lasting appeal. I suspect that won't happen though.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
												If you're more than 30 years old, you've played this game before.  It was called Earth 20_0 or Ground Control. The latter being a better example, and it is difficult to tease out the difference between the two. There's a mobile base, one sort of special 'champion' unit, and an enemy that tosses mobs after you from time to time, interrupting your resource gathering.  The easily-fooled scripted events make an appearance, too. Everything's here, from the terrible pathfinding and crushing unit limits.  Its place in the Homeworld history seems a little misplaced, too;  the novelty of a third dimension gets crushed down to just a sense of high-ground versus low-ground.To be fair, that aspect of the game -- line of fire and line of sight -- is very well done, and units will tell you with very clear graphics what is blocking their fire and what you could move to get around that.While I'm enjoying the game, the primary feeling I keep having is that I've seen this before. I've played this game before. Really, the only reason I have to recommend this game is that I cannot think of anything else like it that came out this decade.  It's not a great game, but it scratches and itch that's been ignored for a long, long time.  Despite the fact that there's nothing really new, here, there's nothing really wrong with the formula that needs help.  It is keeping me entertained, and that's pretty much what it is supposed to do.  There's no way this is a $60 game, but $30 seems about right.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												Thank you for making this game a reality.  It's everything I've been waiting for since Homeworld 2, 13 years ago. It plays and feels like a Homeworld game, so thank you for bringing me and everyone else back into the Homeworld universe.  Please continue to expand on this IP.Next time though, please bring back unit formations and include a system that allows you to easily position units on top of sand dunes (if we're still going to be in the desert).In the last few years I've been itching for a *real* RTS game with an interesting storyline. Today I got one. Time to play through the campaign again.Oh, and one more thing.  To anyone out there saying that the main campaign is too short and not worth the full price of $60 - Deserts of Kharak was a very well paced game that wasn't dragged out too much.  I found it to be the perfect length. Not every game has to be 200 hours worth of play time and I'm glad this wasn't.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												This prequel installment of the homeworld series breaks from the roots of 3d space operatic RTS to create a strongly hard-counter based land RTS. Balance is slightly asymmetrical- not all options available to one faction are available to others. DLC factions are interesting takes and variations on the core ones and not merely cosmetic. Those familiar with previous homeworld titles will find the interface minimally adjusted with the exception of updates and elimination of 3d movement as this is a ground RTS with limited air units.Combats are quick, brutal, and and based on a mix of micromanagment and unit choice. Reacting to your opponent or opponents with the right units in the right place is critical to success. Spamming one unit type will get you defeated in a hurry, even against the AI. Campaign is good, builds tension, and feels right at home in the lore of homeworld. It might not be the game we asked for, or even realized we could want, but it manages some cool things on simple mechanics and sharp visuals. Ongoing support is hoped for, would like to see some full-scale expansion pack type stuff in addition to the optional but more than window trimming DLC's we've gotten thus far. Those not into dropping additional cash for DLC could likely hold out for the big box pack or a steam sale- game comes in at a fairly low base price to begin with, and on sale, well worth the price of admission.

content:

												I finally got this game on sale, after reading the reviews I was very sceptical about it and was not really expecting much. After playing a few hours, this reminded me so much of Ground Control by. Massive. It just goes to show how advanced GC for its time. Anyway, the game is a solid RTS game, Homeworld on the ground. The only real gripe I have with this game is that you cannot do any custom key binds or squad formations, and it does not really offer anything different or new from any other RTS game out there. number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30
												A worthy successor to the original space operas (themselves having arguably the best RTS campaigns ever made).The scale is obviously smaller, with interceptors and jump drives replaced with dune buggies and trundling from point to point in a hulking carrier on tank tracks, though it retains Homeworld's epic sweep and punchy story beats.You won't be building impenetrable fortresses among the dunes or building huge fleets to overwhelm your enemies - there's no structures and you'll be scraping by each mission with a handful of units (at least on higher difficulties). This makes for a more focused and frantic RTS experience where you'll be concentrating on positioning and using each unit's special abilities to give you the advantage - for example, activating your Light Armored Vehicle's speed boost to charge through an opponent's front lines to take out their hard-hitting railguns, or laying down smokescreens to allow weaker units to escape.The campaign doesn't outstay its welcome and there's surprising variety to be found in the maps given that they're essentially all vast sandpits. It would be fair to say it's pretty light on content, and it feels somewhat of a proof of concept for a more substantial entry in the franchise, but it's clear that the devs understand what makes a Homeworld game tick and I'm excited to see where they go from here. The way light vehicles swarm around bigger targets is very reminiscent of the balletic dogfights in the original two games and the soundtrack and hand-drawn cutscenes are on-point for the series.Great to see HW back and on form!

content:
Posted: January 14
												So close, but some significant annoyances mean that I can't quite bring myself to recommend this.  For the sale price I paid (<£10), I don't regret my purchase, but I'd be upset if I’d paid full price.Starting with the positives, the visuals (units and landscapes), and particularly the sound design are fantastic.  The storyline is good, the missions are varied and well made.  What lets it down is the underlying game, the mechanics.No formations, very poor unit AI, the fact that a mixed group of units given a move order will proceed at their individual top speeds, spreading out and leaving themselves vulnerable.  The bizarre decision to put a cooldown on (for example) the salvagers demolition charge, which means that I can queue up four of them if I’m out of range of the target, but if I’m next to it I have to wait – why?  An Inelegant hack to allow hotkey modification I know is a limitation of the engine used (Unity), but still feels shoddy.  This is a slightly faster moving game than the first two, so the removal of the ability to issue orders while paused is deeply annoying.  I've been an RTS fan since the days off Dune II, Warcraft and TA and it’s enormously frustrating to see UI design that mostly ignores the lessons of the last 25 years.This game is currently the same price as the Homeworld remastered collection, which offers two superior games.  If you haven’t played a Homeworld game before, buy that.  If you’re already a fan, it might be worth picking this one up in a sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Deserts of Kharak has good RTS mechanics, solid controls, good graphics, and an interesting Campaign mode… which is rare for an RTS. Overall it’s a very enjoyable game that I wish I could feel safe recommending. I’m giving this game a thumbs-up because I rate it to be above average, but not truly excellent. Unfortunately the game does have some caveats:-	Campaign is truncated and felt underdeveloped (13 missions)-	Voice acting, while passable, sounds phoned in at times-	Multiplayer has only 5 maps at time of launchIt’s a good game, but the lack of content makes it a concern whether the longevity will be there. Bear that in mind before you go making your purchase. You can see my full review here: 


YouTube™ Video: Is it Worth it? Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak 

			Views: 143		

			SidAlpha battles the wasteland heat and slays the vile religious heretics in order to discover what can be found in the Deserts of Kharak!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3
												I have been a fan of the Homeworld franchise since I picked up Homeworld 2 off the shelf.  These are great games, and Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak did not disappoint.  I will only cover three main points that really stood out to me.The first is RTS controls.  This game has very similar straight forward controls like the the previous games.  If you play RTSs this won't be difficult for you.  I recommend using mixed units when fighting the enemy.  The second thing I want to mention is unit detail.  I love realism, and Homeworld never fails.  I will say that I expected more out of this game.  It does look beautiful, but I was more impressed with Homeworld 2's level of detail than this game.  Explosions really disappointed me.  Still beautiful, but not as impressed as usual.The last thing I will mention is the campaign story.  Multiplayer doesn't really excite me unless I'm playing with a friend or two.  If you are looking for that same style of storyline as the previous games, you will find it here.  I really feel like this is an actual history of this race of people when I'm playing.  The seamless transtion from cinematics to gameplay is just like the old games.  I love playing through the story...which is challenging as usual.I recommend this games to Homeworld fans.  If you haven't played the others, I recommend you play the more recent Homeworld Remastered release.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												Homeworld: DOK is an amazing game. The idea with everything (almost) being mobile, is a nice take on the RTS genre, as is the giant carrier on wheels. Firefights kick up dirt, weapons feels punchy. The background radio chatter is astonishing. Graphics are great too. The game also sports a very nice interface/menu in-game.The best RTS since C&C Generals!I could use a little more zoom-out since many weapons shoot more than a screen length and I would like to do away with deploying logistic modules (which are used to be able to build more units), they are grounded which defeats some of the feel of a mobile army. The same goes for the ability to place fixed turrets. They should be replaced by vehicles.Also, more multiplayer/skirmish options are needed. I would like to be able to have matches without air force for example.Those are minor points, the game has blown me away.

												Deserts of Kharak has good RTS mechanics, solid controls, good graphics, and an interesting Campaign mode… which is rare for an RTS. Overall it’s a very enjoyable game that I wish I could feel safe recommending. I’m giving this game a thumbs-up because I rate it to be above average, but not truly excellent. Unfortunately the game does have some caveats:-	Campaign is truncated and felt underdeveloped (13 missions)-	Voice acting, while passable, sounds phoned in at times-	Multiplayer has only 5 maps at time of launchIt’s a good game, but the lack of content makes it a concern whether the longevity will be there. Bear that in mind before you go making your purchase. You can see my full review here:

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												I've only played a few space - or futuristic - RTS games. Those being Earth 2160 and a bit of Starcraft II. Me being a huge Command and Conquer fan, I thought I'd add another space RTS to my collection, that being this game.I have to admit, I'm a little disappointed in the game since I thought you would be base building but you're not. It reminds me of Command and Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight more than anything but that's alright. I love the concept of this game and I love the gameplay. The maps are absolutely beautiful at max (and my video card is a cheap 2GB one) and the game is challenging. So my disappointment in the lack of base building is irrelevant.I recommend this to anyone who likes RTS games and doesn't like micromanagement (base building) very much. In this game, you command a carrier which deploys units and where you research upgrades and units to build from your carrier. I've only played Skirmish so far so I can learn the systems and whatnot, but plan on trying the campaign very soon. I will update my review then.In the mean time, I recommend this game. From my experience, I don't recommend the two Fleet DLCs as they are basically two retextured fleets of the base ones. I played about 5-10 minutes as Soban and I don't think I noticed anything different from the Coalition. If someone can explain the DLC more in-depth to me, please do so. I will update my review.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												I would only recommend this game on a sale for its singleplayer experience as it has always been Homeworld's foremost strength, it can also be a refreshing RTS playstyle without static base building formula. There is much left to be desired, after completing the campaign and some skirmishes, and if you're not interested in multiplayer, there are no additional side scenarios / Theater of War like CoH2 / Co-op mission modes / Commander progression like in other RTS games. Lack of mod support or a map editor does not help either.Pros:+ Great art style and cutscenes, design of units are awesome.+ Realistic and detailed vehicle animations, you will feel the delay of heavier/slower units.+ Immersive music and absorbing unit battle chatter (configurable).+ Decent expedition story.+ Authentic Homeworld Tactical Map.+ Terrain line of sighting for cover and positioning.+ Unit veterancy and persistant fleet in the story campaign.+ Mobile Carrier (base) that can be upgraded like a powerful tank with offensive/defensive customization.+ Units can be customized, for example: longer range, or upgraded for special useable abilities.+ Carrier showdowns in multiplayer can be close/intense.+ Option to autosave Replays (but no spectator mode).Neutral: = 11 Skirmish maps.= Uninteresting Steam achievements.= Classic difficulty is recommended, it is moderately challenging on some missions but advantage can be taken of by stalling.= Story / characters barely fleshed out despite rich lore.= Fairly 'safe' RTS mechanics and unit differentiation, no stealth/capture units for example.= Carrier annhilation or Artifact Retrieval mode in multiplayer.Cons:- No "Pause/Break" key, nor is it possible to savegame for solo Skirmish against AI.- No unit collision, units should not be able to move/clip through each other. You also can't use your larger/armored units to block missles to shield fragile armor units.- No formations that improve combat efficiency, in Homeworld units of different movement speeds move at the speed of the slowest one, and there are different formations / stances. You can still use Guard to move units together though.- AI still needs work.- Not much progression if not interested in Multiplayer.As a Homeworld player, I feel that DoK as a prequel is a worthy addition to the series and stays authentic in visuals/atmosphere to its predecessor, perhaps a little too much, down to the menus UI. However, one would expect more complex mechanics than what we had in the first Homeworld.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												If you thought Homeworld could not remain true to the original if it wasn't set in space, you were thankfully mistaken.Having played the original Homeworlds years ago, like many I looked at them with rose tinted glasses. But In prearatin for Deserts of Kharak I started up homeworld one, and I have to say, it still holds up. It delivers an atmosphere and an experience of play oonly great games manage. And homeworld shipbreakers Manages both.The aeasthetics are not only sunningly beautiful, but they remain true to the original. Be warned though performance is lower than expected from such a game.The sound design, a known high point of the series also does not disappoint. Not only are the tunes perfectly in sinc with the action and visuals, but the constant unitchatter prowides an undeniable sense of presence. And I haven't heard a piece of repeated dialog for three hours into the game.Mechanically, this is a competent RTS. It brings no great innovation, but what it does it does well. The small number of units may initially seem a drawback, but I've never found myself looking for any functionality that wasn't present in some way. Pathing appears good, and units respond well to orders. The game is set on a series of hard-counters, andthey are mercylessly enforced. So if that's not your thing stay away from it.The multiplayer I didn't explore much, so I can't provide criticism.TL.DR.:Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a game true to it's predecessors. Stunning visuals and superb sound-design support a competent but non-innovative story driven RTS with prominent hard-counter mechanics.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Gameplay video + First Impressions below:


YouTube™ Video: Homeworld: Deserts Of Kharak - Hold The Line 

			Views: 58		

			Game releases on JANUARY 20th, no idea why I said Febuary! Sorry about that! Today we are Playing Homeworld: Deserts Of Kharak from Blackbird Interactive and Gearbox Software.		

A key was provided to me early so I could check out the game before launch. Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak has the feeling of a great RTS. I'm someone who doesn't play as many as I used too but even I found the controls and information on the screen very simple and easy to use. It provides you with great and accurate information and gives you nice quick control over it. Mixed with the voice overs in the campaign the whole experience really did give me a commander feel. Over looking the battle. Terrain plays a big part of combat so I find myself pausing at the start of mission just to have a quick look round the battlefield for areas of higher terrain. Theres 3 terrain types low, medium and high. Any unit on a higher terrain will recieve a bonus over those on a lower terrain. Mix this with unit strengths such as the LAV being better against railgun units and you can really turn a few units into a dangerous force. Combat looks great in the game LAV's being probably the most fun to witness as they circle and swurve there way around each other and the enemy gunning down anything near them. The desert environment looks stunning and when you see a group of units moving with a cloud of dust behind them it gives a great atmosphere to the game. So far though I haven't been able to play it anywhere near as much as it deserves I would highly recommend checking this game out. It performs well even on my not so great system and it plays beautiful. A great RTS game in my opinion and one I'm looking forward to playing even more of.
