												I recommend it. There's definitely some bad to it, but it's very solid. 8/10I am a long time RTS player and as far as game mechanics go, this game is in my top 5. Visually/atmospherically: This game is number 1. The music, the art, the effects, the feel, all of it are amazing.Currently, the game loses a point for the multiplayer having too few maps. There are 13 story missions and I don't see how they couldn't reuse or rework story mission maps into skirmish maps. Perhaps that will happen later. Or even better, we will get player made ones.The game also loses a point for some of the vehicle balance. LAV's are worthless. There is no point in having them except maybe as cannon fodder. You can run around with 4-5 AAV's, 4-5Rail guns, and 3-4 Missile AAV's and never get touched with a support cruiser in tow. All in all, if this is what I can expect from BBI, I hope they continue the homeworld franchise. Very impressed. If you're a fan, you will love this.

Great mechnic of prebuilt armies for each campaign map in case you got wiped out on the map before.Nagatives:  I finished it within 12 hours.There is only one biome - desert (duh) but even so, it can't have been a lot of work to create the maps (compared to games with many biomes) - especially when set over 13 missions. There aren't a great amount of units / there are only 5-6 different unit usages (granted, with a couple of nuances):1. Skirmish Beats Artillery2. Armour beats Skimish3. Artillery beats Armour (and Cruisers)Than you have Cruisers:1. Support Cruiser (Repairs)2. Armoured Cruiser3. number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												It's the videogame equivalent of The Force Awakens. Apparently, the way to revive an old, beloved franchise is to stick close to the originals' plot, sometimes lifting stuff beat-for-beat, and to focus mainly on recapturing the atmosphere. DoK is engineered to make players draw parallels to Homeworld: it has a somber mood, slow pacing, a lone mothership and its crew, a long, harrowing journey over enemy territory, a desperate quest that will make or break an entire civilization, ominous mystical overtones, a fantastic middle-eastern soundtrack, units and resources carrying over from previous missions, rock-paper-scissors balancing that makes units useless most of the time and completely overpowered when used against the right targets at the right distance with the right support, etc. etc.It also has enough new stuff (elevation, air units, carrier upgrades and power-shunting) to not qualify as a retread, which is more than can be said of Homeworld 2 and Cataclysm. Honestly, as much as the desert setting is getting flack, I don't think a fourth Homeworld game set in space with the same old units would really have energized the franchise. And I'm happy we're getting a window into Kharakid society again, since Homeworld 1 had that wonderful Historical and Technical Briefing booklet that greatly expanded the lore of Kharak and its various kiithid... and then did away with the planet and its people in the first few minutes of the campaign.

												Pros- Great storytelling.  Cinematics are different, but have similar tone.  Consistent, engaging gameplay.  Challenging without being obnoxious.Cons- Pathing is a little sketchy.  Formation movement is underdeveloped.  Tutorial kinda throws you into the wind.I'm a huge fan of the Homeworld franchise.  This is similar, but not the same.  This plays much faster.  It is stressful; hectic, even.  Micromanagement is key.  Every unit fits a niche, and bulk production tactics simply don't work.  Homeworld 1 & 2 encouraged force management and tactics.  Deserts of Kharak mandates it.Another difference is resourcing- no large fields here.  You're starving for the first several hops of the campaign, and you're constantly struggling with defending your resourcing operations while accomplishing objectives through the rest of the game.A third difference is your carrier/mothership.  In 1 & 2, it was a large, slow liability until late game.  Here, it is equal parts battleship, aircraft carrier, and factory.  Power management means that often the most effective combat plan is the one that involves running your carrier, guns blazing, right into the middle of the enemy.  The game rewards risk, where my experience with 1 & 2 was that careful, conservative planning was best.Basically, if you love Homeworld lore?  Buy this game.  If you love high-speed, skirmish-style strategy games?  Buy this game.  If you played Command & Conquer 4, and have always wondered what that game would be like if it didn't suck?  Buy this game.If you want a slow, cinematic space opera?  Go play 1 remastered.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Fear not folks, this is a through and through Homeworld game without a doubt.  The feeling of going up against an unrelenting enemy or a lone journey through vast emptiness (only in a desert planet this time, duh) is still there. I love the art direction, the graphics, the sound design (radio chatter between your units is fantastic and very very reminiscent of the Homeworld games of the old). The game is beatifully well done.Apparently the campaign is not that long (albeit crafted masterfully) and the game is very thin on content. Also the AI is pretty much non-existent, and as a result the game is quite easy even on the hardest difficulty setting. Scripted campaign makes a very good job of hiding this and engrosses you completely but that seems like that is all there is for now. I don't think competitive multiplayer will be a thing and skirmish mode in its current state is not satisfying thanks to the AI. The campaign will not disappoint you but whether it is worth the price tag depends on the personal preference. I'd say it is worth the full price for a fan of the series.All in all, I'd recommend Deserts of Kharak to any Homeworld fan.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Overall, Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak serves as an incredible prequel to the franchise, delivers a captivating and satisfying story driven gameplay experience with stunning graphics to boot. The campaign itself is pretty long and comes in at around 15 hours or more depending on your playstyle and difficulty level chosen and is well worth the current asking price on Steam. The multiplayer and skirmish modes just round off the entire package will surely deliver countless hours of fun for those of you that want to sink time into this game. And dare I say, the Multiplayer might even spawn a competitive scene. Only time will tell if that happens though but I certainly would like it to. If there is any RTS game to be purchased and played immediately, Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is right there at the top of the list.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												If you are a Homeworld fan then you will definetly not be left wanting.When I heard they were bringing out a prequel to the amazing homeworld series I was already expecting it to be subpar because Relic wasn't producing it. Thankfully this was the time that I was 1000000% wrong (yes I know 100% is max but bugger off)Now for those of you who are looking at this game and you love your strategy games believe me when I say this.BUY THIS GAME.The eye for detail in this game is amazing especially when it comes to line of sight, you can actually use sand dunes to block line of site and set up ambushes.One tip, always try to hold the highground it will make your like that much easier.Ok the cons, yes all games have them and so does Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak.It has crashed on me a number of times while playing it, though an update to fix alot of the crashing problems was released the following day.The biggest con of all though is that there is an end to the game, I could play this game continuously but I just finished the campaign and I need more. When is the next one coming out.So overall for a game that was released yesterday, with one or two little problems which are being dealt with,BUY THIS GAME already.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												I just finished the game on the highest setting, Classic Difficulty (the name of which amuses me, due to the fact that the 'classic' game only had one difficulty...really freaking hard). The journey took me 12 hours of gameplay at this point. I loved the ambient music of the game, and am seriously considering buying the soundtrack. Now, to put it simply here are my views.Pros:Extremely thematic music.It's a desert, but they keep the terrain interesting.Each unit has its uses, and they keep the number small enough that you don't wonder why they put units in.I've always loved persistent fleets, and the veterancy makes it even better.Excellent story, and quite good voice-acting as well.The power shunt system for your carrier is amazing.Cons:It was too easy to beat on the main difficulty. Your best bet is to get as many resources as you can to build a fleet, and then alpha-strike the main objective in a single massive attack to finish things. Otherwise you just get killed by the death of a thousand cuts due to your opponent not needing resources to produce vehicles.The AI is less than stellar, but makes up for it due to campaign scripting.Leaves lots of questions unanswered. Admittedly, primarily because they were answered in the other Homeworld games, but still.Skirmish maps are lacking in number.Overall:I recommend the game to Homeworld enthusiasts. I recommend others wait for it to go on sale. Unless modding tools come out for it, at which point this is ripe for modders to turn it into something absolutely amazing.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Would totally recommend it,if they would still offer Homeworld: Remastered edition (classic included) as a gift,if you buy this game. Game is not worth the current price tag,since there's nothing much to do in this game right now. When you've done with campaign,you'll proceed to multiplayer and you'll get bored by time,since there's only 5 maps. Game feels like early access,although developers are talking with us and they're saying,they're already working on updates. The real elephant in the room is the lack of content. As of writing this there are only two factions, five official multiplayer maps, barely any AI to speak of, and a campaign that can be polished off easily in under ten hours. Nothing scandalous but it's definitely sparse for the price tag. Doubtless more content is on the way, and once it drops I'll happily flip my recommendation to a yes. Until then you'll have to decide whether fifty dollars is too much for a shiny, flimsy toy like DoK.If you've played SC2 or Company of Heroes,than this game will feel really fresh. There's interesting concept,it just misses a lot of Original functions of Homeworld. At current game state = Not recommended. Get it for discount or with Homeworld remastered included,since this game alone is not worth the 45.99 EUR.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Having played this new game up to the review date, i have to say that is almost perfect out the box. The graphics are really great and give a whole atmosphere to the game, and finally get to learn that city that was seen in the original homeworld cutscene. The audio is really good, the sountrack is top notch and the battles are really something, compared to a few reviews i have read up about the durability of units and the lack of, there are some units that have lasted to the last mission from the first mission and there are other units that can take on a fair sized force by themselves with a support cruiser running back up for healing and defense.The cons unfortunately are unit movements, in that when you click attack with a group of units, some of them do not respond on the first second or third attempt, they fire at the target if it's in range but they fail to move. You have to manually move them and then attack the target to get them to move.Minor sound breaking specifically when you got a number of units parked against a rock, it can actually impact the performance by reducing frame rate as well, even with v-sync on there are some signs of tearing (everything on full and max and i have the rated computer for max settings without issue).The final battle with the main enemy "mothership" if you like, this unit moves in such a strange way that it makes for long range bombardment hard to do. For example i was going to launch a cruise missile at the target and suddenly the target veered right sideways? I have also seen it move in reverse to the right and it had no angle to do that.I have yet to play multiplayer but early signs are positive.Edit: i have discovered the game is region locked, meaning world wide multiplayer is not possible, so for example, if you are in europe, you can only play european players. there is a way around it however which is the switch your region download to another location, but keep in mind you are switching from one region to another. with that stated, the multiplayer part of the game could degenerate quickly due to a varied lack of players from across the planet to play against.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												A prequel to the award-winning Homeworld series, Deserts of Kharak puts the player in charge of the Kapisi; a half kilometer-long landcarrier on a mission to retrieve a curious artifact deep in enemy territory.At your disposal is a small, albeit adaptable, range of vehicles capable of traversing the dunes with ease.While I'm not that deep into the Homeworld lore I still recommend this game as it is simply awesome; every single detail, from the realistic physics to the radio chatter, provides the dead desert environment with a surprising amount of life.Meanwhile the score builds up an incredible atmosphere as you travel deeper into uncharted areas.For a game set on a desert planet it is absolutely gorgeous visually as vehicles kick up dust, projectiles scorch the sand and as missiles cause realistic explosions.All in all this is definietly worth the buy, especially if you are fan of Homeworld. Good work BBI, I never doubted you for a second.

												After many years, this is the 1st review I've posted on Steam.  The things I've always loved about the Homeworld games is that for me they deliver the whole package... top notch story, immersive campaign, gorgeous visuals, and  some of the best music in gaming period. Hands down the best money I've spent on a game in quite some time, so if these sorts of things interest you in a game don't hesitate, dive in.  You'll be glad you did. 10/10

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Homeworld, with all that flavor of space epicness. Add some beautiful Ground Control to make it just more terrain-related and season with Dune. Shake it well and the gorgeous result is Deserts of Kharak.The 10-hour campaign is fantastic. The musics, sound effects, voices, animations are top-notch.It's not a perfect game, but it's one of the best RTS out there. The game is faster than Homeworld 1 and 2 and units are definitely more fragile. During the campaign I missed that pause between skirmishes and battles that allows you to relax and appreciate each single unit deployed on the battlefield (the enemy keeps threading a lot and you have to focus on both strategy and micro management to keep your fleet alive).Anyway, RTS players and Sci-Fi fan: you must try this game. That's an order!WE DEFINITELY NEED HOMEWORLD 3.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
Product received for free
												**** For some reason Steam thinks I had a promo copy of the game - I did not ****It's a beautiful game, it FEELS like homeworld, it's every bit as hard. + Gorgeous graphics throughout+ Good use of realistic terrain advantages in combat+ Keeps you thinking at all times - boredom just doesn't happen- Multiplayer is built around rush tactics - don't expect to have a long match against AI or Players- No resource trading makes teamplay somewhat superficial- Defense oriented players are doomed - mobility is key to survival, you must always be on the attackI loved Homeworld; I once stonewalled a Vagyr invasion for an entire hour while my teammates built up for a win.  This game isn't suited to my playstyle alas. If you can grasp the hit-and-run nature and the constant balancing of resources you'll love this. If you're stuck (like me) in a traditional RTS mindset you'll struggle and rage-quit a lot.It's a great game and I wish I was better at it. Hopefully Blackbird will find a way to balance it so that the less adaptable amongst us can keep up, before too many leave the game behind as a flawed gem in the desert sand.

												"Rock, Paper, Scissors" The enemy has arranged a number of Rail Guns on a ridge, overlooking the approach as your AAV's barrel up to them, desperately trying to close the range. Your enemy puts his fist in his palm, and lays down "Paper." You look down at your own hands..."Rock." Damn, that's right, AAV's suck vs. Rail Guns. But wait! You quickly order your LAV's to boost up the ridge, and the enemy Rail Guns just can't compete with their speed. "Scissors," you smirk, as your enemy curses you. This more or less describes the micromanagement in the tactics of the game. The better you get with the controls, the quicker you will be able to command your forces, which will work in your favor. You'll want to practice this as well, taking advantage of hot keys, as "Veterancy" is awarded to units that survive brutal encounters, and this can make them significantly more powerful.But enough about all of that...the real gem in Deserts of Kharak is the Kapisi. You're introduced to this massive Carrier in the tutorial, a sand crawler/aircraft carrier that slowsly rolls across the sand, pounding enemies with salvos of missiles, cannon fire, strike craft, bombers...and all sorts of other goodies. You'll never be able to build anything as big as it, though the Cruisers you'll eventually construct can hold their own against anything but the Carriers. Even the Kapisi (or just an unnamed Carrier in your Skirmish/Multiplayer games) has micromanagement elements. You utilize a finite amount of Power, which can be upgraded through Research. This Power can be prioritized to Armor, Repair, Firepower and Range systems on the fly, presenting you with a dilemma. This ship, if lost, means your defeat. However, this ship is ridiculously powerful after undergoing some upgrades, so more often than not...you'll find yourself broadsiding enemies like it's "The Black Pearl" and having a blast with it.One last thing here before I sum this up: I had stated that Rail Guns had been aligned on top of a ridge in the opening lines of this. Elevation plays a role in determing advantages between units. This also affects the map design, which has many levels of terrain, cliffsides, rolling dunes, and many different landscaping elements. While one would think a desert would be rather bland, this one is riddled with downed starships, ready to be demolitioned and then harvested for precious resources, as well as various craters and abandoned ruins.In Conclusion: 9/10"What's missing? Where'd that 1 point go?" This game sticks close to the original Homeworld formula. It takes a gamble with the desert terrain and having predominantly land battles, but I would have loved to have seen some kind of "Home City" element, similar to Age of Empires III's. In this case, I obviously wouldn't be talking about a city...I'd be talking about a starship, which would be able to provide orbital bombardment, radar scans, land reinforcements, etc. as you'd level it up. Similar to the "Spirit of Fire" from Halo Wars. If not this, then some element of base-building/base mechanics. The planet has been engulfed by sand, yet there's no ruined cities overcome by sand that you see. The lack of structures got to me a bit, and this makes the game play a bit more like a nomadic one, in which it's impossible to "Turtle" and your base moves across the map, exhausting resources as it goes.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												Well, it's another Homeworld game, and one deserving of the name.The gameplay is great, with hints of Supreme Commander in there and other influences while obviously maintaining that Homeworldy feel. The campaign does a good job (a couple bugs here and there, but nothing that can't be overcome or hopefully patched soon) of showing what the beginning of the Homeworld journey was like. Other game modes show the variety of tweaks and new gameplay features put in to make this game unique. It certainly isn't just Homeworld 1&2 compressed to 2D, but something quite interesting in itself.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												Homeworld: DOK is an amazing game. The idea with everything (almost) being mobile, is a nice take on the RTS genre, as is the giant carrier on wheels. Firefights kick up dirt, weapons feels punchy. The background radio chatter is astonishing. Graphics are great too. The game also sports a very nice interface/menu in-game.The best RTS since C&C Generals!I could use a little more zoom-out since many weapons shoot more than a screen length and I would like to do away with deploying logistic modules (which are used to be able to build more units), they are grounded which defeats some of the feel of a mobile army. The same goes for the ability to place fixed turrets. They should be replaced by vehicles.Also, more multiplayer/skirmish options are needed. I would like to be able to have matches without air force for example.Those are minor points, the game has blown me away.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												Deserts of Kharak is essentially Homeworld on a planet's surface.  That's the best description I can come up with.  Various vehicles act as near-direct counterparts to ships from the previous two space-side games.  You research to upgrade your units, build up your forces by sending out mining teams, and manage your forces to stay under the population cap, same as Homeworld. Terrain offers minor advantages or disadvantages compared to space, but overall the gameplay is more of the same.  The story plays out through movies with a painting-like aesthetic between missions or in-engine cutscenes during the missions.  Without spoilers, it's a decent story, if that sort of thing matters to you, not superior to original Homeworld but still very solid.In short, if you liked Homeworld, you'll probably dig DoK.  If you were looking for more than that, you'll probably be disappointed.  I myself liked it just fine.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												A very good game with a rock-paper-scissors combat system and the classic Homeworld UI that works surprisngly well for a land based RTS game. It focues on the backstory found the in Homeworld instruction manual and expands on it in rather interesting ways. The inclusion of cut-scenes during missions is fairly seamless and works quite well for the story.Unit costs are a bit excessive, I found. It makes you feel every loss as you go (not a bad thing) and that you don't have the option to harvest remaining resources at the end of a mission feels like they want you to drag out each mission as long as possible. The odds increase as you go on, of course, but the high unit prices usually means you're always going to feel like you're on the wrong end of an♥♥♥♥♥kicking in most engagements later on and retreating is a well used tactic.The ending (without spoilers) feels rather jarring and, knowing the Homeworld manual myself, really could have added a bit more onto it to tie it to the first Homeworld game. It reeks of deadline, to me, and expecting you to already know the story ahead of time. Key components of the story are flat out missing at the end.But minor gripes aside, a very entertaining game. Not tried the multiplayer yet.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												*EDIT* The game gets better the longer you play it and the multiplayer is very good despite being barebones. I have upped my non-preorder score. I utimately feel as though I rewarded for rolling the dice and buying a game without reading any reviews. After being burned hard by Gearbox for Aliens: Colonial Marines, the company has regained my loyalty. Thanks Gearbox and Blackbird Interactive.Homeworld​: Deserts of Kharak is the best RTS game since StarCraft 2. Although at $49.99 it's a tough value proposition. As an owner of the Homeworld: Remastered Collection I got 20% off and an interactive encyclopedia worth $5.99. I'm a little miffed that the soundtrack was not included, $7.99, and you need to have the game to download it (DLC model). But hey I like pre-order bonuses.The game is stripped down to a refined RTS core and the unit count represents that. Not quite MOBA simplified, but complex enough not to scare that crowd away. You've got a decent papers, rocks, scissors interplay going and a dedicated airstrike platform, your cruiser. If I compared the game to chess, the cruiser would be a queen/king combo. Lose it, you're dead. Yet properly upgraded it will wreck havoc and coordinated airstrikes with ground forces properly erases the opposition from the map, no matter how overwhelming. Cue me whooping like a falcon diving for the kill and a meal.I really like the cover system where elevation actively blocks direct fire and units firing from higher positions get a damage bonus which makes sense for a vehicle based RTS. Armored vehicles are weakest at their rear and turrets in true Company of Heroes fashion (if you like RTS play CoH). I play the game mostly from the satellite view since I like the interface and how informative it is. Relic and employees that used to work for that Canadian studio have the best audio guys in the business. Unit chatter is appropriately stoic with ironic wit (which I like), but most importantly provides valuable information. If a unit is being attacked instead of getting a ping saying "Yo dude. Your dudes are under attack. Pay attention!"The intel officer or unit itself will simply say "Strike craft taking effective fire." Unit chatter can get layered, but the design is genius. It's almost like listening to sports on the radio and being able to picture the battle unfolding. If I had anything negative to say it'd probably be that the game feels too basic at times, sometimes too slow for its own good, and has inconsistent performance. I also encountered a game breaking bug. Not quite Total War Rome 2's caliber where I actually rage quitted in frustration, but the devs were responsive and helpful. The game uses a lot of scripted sequences so I tend to finish secondary objective out of fear of breaking the primary ones.All in all, a great purchase. 9/10 at $39.99 with pre-order bonus and discount. Wait for a steam sale and if you like RTS you'll fall in love with the game and plus the bugs will be ironed out.8.5/10 at $49.99 without expedition guide DLC. The game has quite the solid foundation and will post-release love it should get some wings and take flight. Like the Kushan people fleeing their dying planet where desert erosion slowly erases top soil. No top soil, no food. No food... well that's a terrible way to go if you have water and that's in short supply too.

												This is what command and qonquer should have been!Besides, the gameplay is much like the previous homeworld games, you go on a mission with your "mothership" ( or in this case a carrier, just like the military ones but than for land ) What i really like in the campaign is that you keep the units and upgrades and everything you had the previous missions!Which makes sense because you're travelling! ( other games are always like, you researched better gear in mission one, oh we have to research it again in mission two! xD makes no sense >.<  )Should you buy it? well if you're dissapointed wit c&c4 you should! If you love Homeworld, you should!Actually you should have preordered because you'd get the homeworld remastered with it as well.. man one hell of a deal!So, i be continuing my search for the artefacts! content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Would i recommend it? Yes! Story, Gameplay, Atmorsphere, it´s all really good. As good as Homeworld 1 or 2? No. But it´s good nonetheless.Buuuut:I have 9,1 hours on record, that includes replaying one of the longer missions just because i wanted to harvest more ressources. And I´m done. On hardest difficulty.This game is really, really easy. And it´s all because of the awful AI, which is, as many others have mentioned aswell, awful. Really really awful. And some of the scripted attacks and movements aren´t that great either. You can win most "destroy that enemy carrier!" Missions by sitting around in your comfy and well defended Base bacause the enemy takes the exact same route all the time and is therefore perfectly predictable, making him an easy target for missiles and bombers.I´ll go and play Homeworld 1 now, the remastered edition looks amazing, and is still better than this in any way, which just shows how good the original is.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												When I first installed the game, I was deeply concerned about the small size of it compared to other modern games. We get used to downloading games at 20gb onwards these days. This is a much smaller sized game which makes sense for it's simplicity - and yet the changing scenario storylines never unhook you for a single mission.+ Fully immersive storyline that leads up to it's predecessors (HM1/HM:C/HM2)+ Excellent unit voice acting including passive chatter+ Very unstressed playing atmosphere+ Very easy to use system+ Advanced waypoint management+ Great RTS research trees, unit upgrades, group management systems+ Units are good graphics (ground detail is oddly lacking)- Only 13 missions- Slightly anti-climatic ending

												Homeworld: Deserts Of Kharak is an RTS where the campaign is steeped in story and the missions are well-crafted with events and cut-scenes breaking up the action and providing new objectives as you go. content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												I wish there was a different choice then Dont Recommend because the game is not bad but its not great either IMO.I feel like if it were 20 bucks i could recommend it.The camera doesnt zoom out far enough when your in non tactical mode, so you spend most of the game just looking at a blue screen with maneuvering green dots around on it.The gameplay is MEH, lets be honest here people there is not much for strategy here, the Strike Aircraft can own all, once you build a full fleet of them I was just sending them out to pretty much EVERYTHING, it was kinda pathetic really, no ground units were really needed other than harvesters.The graphics are nothing great, and the environments are bland, I get it I get it, its a desert but why couldnt there be some cool set pieces or some sort of atmosphere to liven things up.Im not trying to be pedantic I am enjoying the story but the actual game itself is so MEH, made me want to go play Homeworld Remasterd to be honest.  I dont feel like the "homeworld feel" really does well with ground combat.Id give the game a 5 out of 10 and id recommend playing Homeworld Remastered...

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Deserts of Kharak is a love letter to both Homeworld games that came before it.  A beautiful re-imagining of the original games, modernized similar to the HD re-releases Gearbox put out earlier this year.  From its unique art style, rousing music, to its masterful balance of your typical rock paper scissor mechanics found in most RTS games, its about as polished and well made as any RTS game released in the last decade.  The story, while a bit light, which is usual for games in this genre, still manages to hit the right notes and provide some great Sci Fi story telling.  It provides a thrilling backstory to the Homeworld universe, with unique a varied mission objectives.  I didn't mind the desert environments, each map feeling hand crafted.If I had any complaints, it was the length of the campaign.  Similar to the previous homeworlds, it only had 13 missions in total.  There were several late game units that I didn't feel I had time to learn how to use, or bring to bare in an exciting way against my enemies.  Aircraft can also feel like an "I win" button for several early mission, but are balanced later in the game when anti air vehicles become more prevalent.  The land carrier, which takes the place of the mother-ship from previous games, feels a bit too strong.  I did enjoy the overhead mechanics which had me switching between systems, but with a few repair vehicles near by I never felt it was at threat.Over all, one of the best RTS games I've played in years.  More grand strategy, then your typical Star Craft twitch / micromanagement play style.I'm really hoping they continue the Homeworld series.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												I must say, I was frustrated wit the developers on this one. Great product gone bad. Here is an outlook of the first 3 months of release...Initial impression, Engaging campaign, Gorgeous landscape and graphics, overall gameplay and physics pretty spot on.Then came the multiplayer/comp stomp experience... absolutely awful. I look to the maps available and at release I believe it was 4... yes, 4 maps. Games in the 1990's had a better selection of battlegrounds to wage war on (since then they've slowly added but every other game out there has more maps still) .Region locking issues, the worst AI i've ever encountered in a game. I've played starcraft, total annihilation, red alert, warcraft, dawn of war, company of heroes... yes.. this game blows with AI. Some AI units dont respond when being attacked, some games it's the same 5 scout units routinely attacking me in 5min intervals, some games you literally could win with 1 type of unit, the AI is not intelligent.Then came cash grab tactics.. Look at the release date, Jan 20th. In two months after release they release a PAID fleet pack. 2 months after the game came out!! Oh wait, they put another fleet pack out a month after that one too! If you can whip out two fleet packs but take two months to make one AI patch that had a minimal impact on AIIt's ridiculous on how developers are about cash grabs and taking advantage of the faithful like myself who preordered the game and have been a lifelong fan of homeworld.My suggestion, wait til the game comes on sale for about 20 bucks and you can enjoy some pretty visuals, a decent campaign, and lackluster AI.Recap: + Visuals, Gameplay mechanics, Campaign- Annoying Bugs, Unresponsive/Lackluster AI, Greedy Devs, Weak online community/multiplayer, limited map selection

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												I've clocked a little over an hour into the game and completed the first three (of what I believe is around 10-12 missions for the story) and have stopped for now to provide a review and feedback.My initial reaction to playing the game, is that there are some deep seeded homeworld aspects that are missing from the game, this was something I was expecting due to the limited press demo's provided prior to the games release.Homeworld as a series remains my all-time favourite, I am an owner of the Remastered Collectors Edition and have dumped quite a few hours into that now that I can play homeworld on a modern PC. The negative feedback I have is such:Map Texture quality Seems very low, I am running the game on maximum settings and the sand and scenery simply doesn't add the same atmosphere that you see in the pre-rendered footage.No Unit Interactions like Homeworld 1-2Unit interactions are a generation behind the original homeworld games. In Homeworld 1, when your resource harvester collected materials and returned to hand them in, you could actually watch it dock with your resource controller/mothership and transfer the resources back. The resource controller in DoK looks like it was going to have something similar, but they didn't finish implementing it, instead, when your resource collectors reach your collector, the mineral bar vanishes and they move off for their next collection.No DockingAnother cool and fun Sci-fi aspect of Homeworld was docking, the fact that after a run, you could dock your strike craft with your mothership or carriers for more efficient repairs (and in Catacylsm, retro-fitting), there is no docking in DoK, once your carrier spits out a new unit it outside for good, with the extremely shot repair range on the other vessels, repairing large groups of small craft is fiddly and annoying rather than engaging and fun.With your main 'mothership' in DoK being a Carrier, I was expecting the same mechanicCutscene RenderingSeveral of the cut-scenes seem a little poorly rendered, the art-style itself is fantastic, but again on a modern game on a very high-end PC, I expected more crisp visuals than how they are displaying on my PC.Zoom controls These seem way too limited, I find myself constantly wanting to zoom out more, the maximum limit feels very claustraphobic, resulting in an awful lot of scrolling around and quick-tabbing to the sensors manager just to view short distances, unlike again the original homeworld games where you could zoom out to a great degree for unit selection and controlsomfg, why is the main menu on F10 and not ESC like 99% of games?!?!I was taking part in a mission and needed to pause, to my surprise, ESC did nothing, I started spamming every key on the keyboard until suddenly one of them opened the game menu, I was then able to check the key-bindings (which, are fixed btw and cannot be remapped) and discover that mid-game, the main menu is accessed from F10 (whyyyyyyyyyyyyy).SummaryMaybe my expectations are too high, considering that Homeworld 1 + 2 are multi-award, ground breaking titles, but I at least, from my perspective was expecting more, not because it's a homeworld prequal, but but because it was made by the core guys that made the original HW games, I was expecting an evolution of mechanics, not a simplification that in many ways looks like a step-back to me, or, unfinished implementation due to a rushed development and launch.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												This is a portion of a larger review... if you want to read the whole thing, I put a link at the bottom.Deserts of Kharak’s strongest element is assuredly its campaign. The campaign is hauntingly atmospheric, full of starkly vast spaces and lonely stretches of desert, and challenging. I’ll touch on this more in my next section. The multiplayer, at least in the game’s launch state, falls short of the promise of the game’s mechanics.One of the strongest and most interesting elements of the game is the Carrier’s mobility. However, in both the campaign and the multiplayer, this seems oddly de-emphasized. It is as if the developers were being cautious, or were unsure of how to design around this unique feature. In the campaign, the Carrier is often left up on a plateau or stuck down in the dunes, while its armies swarm around the map completing objectives and fighting Gaalsien battlegroups. Similarly, in multiplayer, I seldom found myself moving the Carrier much, if at all, especially when playing Gaalsien.The layout of most multiplayer matches incorporates a somewhat traditional RTS setup, with roughly a third or so of each map sectioned off into a “base sector” or “home turf” for each player, and it is in these that most or all resources on the map are found. The central and contested map area tends to feature the mach objectives: 3 automatically respawning relics Artifacts that must be collected by a player’s Baserunner and deposited at their drop-off zone. The first player to retrieve 5 of these Artifacts (or who destroys their opponent’s Carrier) is the winner.In practice, this setup actually works fairly well for the most part, aside from the negligible mobility requirements for the Carrier (which to me are a crying shame). Conceptually, I have some deep issues with this setup.First of all, despite the attention to detail the rest of the game receives, drop-off areas are just an arbitrarily-placed ring of pylons on the map. There’s no real asset or logically-driven factor behind the placement of these zones: the only goal was apparently to have such a zone and to place it in an area of the map roughly equidistant to each player’s start location. In terms of map design, it’s functional but scarcely supportable. Any existing game asset: structures, dropships, some sort of supply cache etc, would make this design more sensible within the game’s context. I certainly hope that future map designs take into account the story they’re telling. What are they delivering their artifacts to?Also, the Artifacts themselves automatically self-extract at regular intervals. Sensible, to be sure, but again a bit uninspired. Perhaps such a design was tested and turned down, but I can’t help but want my Baserunner to have to manually extract each Artifact, and to defend it while the artifact is extracted, and then defend it (as is currently the case in multiplayer) en route to the drop-off zone. Such a system should seem to feel, to me, more satisfying mechanically as well as in the context of the story. Should they release modding tools for the game, I plan to test such a system myself.The pacing of multiplayer feels appropriate to me, with matches tending to last around 10 minutes if the players are matched well, the player constantly expanding their force and building new units, the choices the player is making being meaningful: tech to air, or focus on railguns, or power through to cruisers? Scouting is difficult, thanks to Carriers coming equipped with weapons of not inconsiderable firepower.Actually, I have found that Carriers are well situated within the context of the game. They’re able to take out small groups of units early on, but midgame armies give them pause, and can wear them down over time. Late-game units pose a serious threat, and if Carriers take them out, it would be with considerable damage to their hulls. So, the Carrier ends up being a powerful supporting unit without devolving into a MOBA-style hero (which would be a tragedy).With access to the full unit lists of both factions, I’ve become more-or-less at peace with the unit design in Deserts of Kharak. Unit abilities are a welcome addition, such as the Gaalsien Missle Cruiser’s ground-targeted area of effect attack, which damages friendly units as well as foes, and is a counter to enemy light attack vehicles only if it manages to hit them. Rail Guns still feel odd to me as an alternative to artillery weapons, but as I mention in my preview, they work well with the game’s line of sight system so I can appreciate the choice.Air units feel quite powerful, but I believe that a recent patch (released shortly before the publication of this article) implemented a balance fix to air units. Additionally, in opposition to my earlier statement, air units can, in fact, be individually controlled, though their default area attack command is a simple way to get some mileage out of them. They are best handled through the sensors manager, by the way.On the topic of air units, the game’s counter system escalates greatly with the addition of Air, and Cruisers, each of which require a deep commitment from the opposing player in order to properly counter. Cruisers have many times the hull integrity of smaller craft, making them require a significant anti-armor investment from opponents, and air units move fast and hit hard, requiring (again) significant preparation from opponents to properly counter.http://waywardstrategist.com/2016/02/02/in-the-dunes-the-carriers-deserts-of-kharak-non-review/

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 4
												Alright, I really wanted to like this game, but in the end everything came together to put a "No" on the review.HW:DoK aims to revitalize the Homeworld series, something the Remastered Collection has already done to be honest...and that did a far better job.In this game, space is obviously no longer an issue, so there are no movements in a three dimensional space. Instead there is elevation, and elevation is pretty dull. Not only is it difficult to position your units, the effects are also difficult to gauge, i.e. you have no clue if your units are now suddenly stronger or not. Units also level up. That's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t imho. This means more damage, more hp, more range, etc., which kills game balance and makes it even more desastrous if you lose one of your fragile units, since those are all you have for the majority of the campaign until you get actual cruisers 2/3rds in.The campaign itself is actually ok and has several interesting missions. Too bad that the presentation got stuck in the late 90s as well. Homeworld worked, because it was in space. If it had not been in space, I doubt people would have liked it much. It was mysterious, intriguing. Kharak is not. Everything is obviously yellow-tinged, because you are on a sand planet. This game would have more to it if it had different tile sets, but of course that is not possible, since we are playing on mo♥♥♥♥ing Kharak, a DESERT planet...you know another game that tried a desert only setting? Dune, repeatedly. Know why it worked every time? Because the factions were inherently different. In Kharak you have 2 main factions, which are pretty much identical. One uses tracked vehicles, the other hover vehicles (which should be far superior in a desert environment), yet they have exactly the same units with some very minor differences (i.e. railgun and assault railgun + heavy railgun for whatever reason). Baseline is: there is nothing for you to care about the world or the factions, since there is very little exposition. If you've played the HW games, good job, you know at least something.There IS a story guide, which they sell separately!!!!You know what they also sell separately? 2 new factions!!!! for 7 bucks each!!!!You know what these factions do differently than the existing ones? I don't. They are reskins with stat tweaks.That alone has prompted me to rate the game negatively. I don't see a point in skirmish, not with 2 or 4 factions. The differences are just too minor. Heck TOTAL ANNIHILATION had more unit variety between the two very similar factions.Then there's the engine. For whatever reason this game (a unity engine game for whatever reason) doesn't run well. I've tried everything I can think of, but since there is no official guide from the devs, or heck even performance patches, the game continues to "stutter" every few seconds, usually every time something blows up, but not every time. I have no idea why, is it the monitor? The graphics card? Sound? Does the game want me to unplug my second monitor even though it is disabled? Would that even help? Not worth the hassle to find out, because it shouldn't be, but I guess I can consider myself lucky, because at least I can somewhat play it at all, and not have frequent crashes or drops to 3 FPS. That's just unacceptable.Of course we also have "bugs" or "features"? Dunno, which. For example, your strike craft (what counts as planes here, so fighters, bombers, etc.) are a hassle to use. You first have to select your carrier (Home button or a control group), then press a button for the appropriate type of craft, to then send them out to a fixed location. If the enemy moved you have to then SELECT those strike craft on the map (have fun) and order them to manually attack that target which is now out of range. Bombers just act weirdly in general and gunships are used for target practice by the enemy. I wish you could tell them to disengage when they get fired upon...naaaaaaah, just let em die *sigh*. When your craft are finally done with striking or dying the return to your carrier...and potentially hover there for 5 minutes before landing, even if you manually order them or press the button on the carrier (which seems to do nothing).Speaking of buttons that do nothing: There seem to be more like this in the game...Units wise the game is also severely lacking in general. There's harvesters obviously, your carrier, which is a weapons platform (actually a good thing), the aircraft, light attack vehicles that are useful only very early on in the game, since a group of them gets oneshot later one (bye bye hundreds of resources in an instant) and do virtually no more damage. The only reason to maybe have a squad would be to chase off railguns. Then there's tanks, which don't deserve the name, since they do almost no damage, are slow and weak against railguns and everything above. Speaking of railguns: these are just the better tanks in the game imho. They have massive range and damage and if you can spot the enemy, you can just dismantle them before they get too close. And when they do, you just retreat your railguns and let your cruisers take over. Cruisers are also weird, they're either low up high speed or the opposite. I wonder why I would ever build slow cruisers with limited range in a world where railguns exist that can kill these things before they even fire once if they have max range. Some cruisers are equipped with mortars. Great. Cool. Too bad when they kill your own units because they fire right into them. Oh "deactivate auto fire then" you say. Sure, but then they won't attack at all anymore.... I've tried. They just sit there. WTF? Meh. I forgot the base runner, which deploys turrets...and there's also AA vehicles. As you've guessed it, all factions have these units. Yay.For a 2015 or 2016 game Deserts of Kharak just doesn't offer enough originality and diversity. The campaign may entertain you a bit for a few hours, but ultimately Kharak annoyed me more than it gave me pleasure. Buy at your own risk. For Homeworld fans I'd say it's also not very important, since the general story of how they got into space is already documented in the HW manuals. If we at least got way more exposition with Rachel...instead she is degraded to heal your units and have a few voice lines in the (not really) animated cutscenes (they're half animated comics). These fit the theme, but in the end...meh. It would have been cooler if we had had 4 distinct factions from the get go, that all played a role in the campaign.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												I am astonished at how this game is rated so highly, especially when most of those buying/playing this game, I suspect, have played homeworld 1 + 2. The is some enjoyment to be found but its short lived and just not worth the price tag or time. The are a number of major issues I have with this game. 1) The game feels rushed and unfinished. For example, the appearance of some unit models doesn't fit with their final game-play implementation e.g. coalition support cruises, which function as armoured mobile resource drop of points for collectors and repair bays for all vehicles, have a large gaping whole in them where presumably collectors were supposed to dock and off-load their resources and/or where vehicles could dock for repairs. Instead resources just magically transfer from collectors to support cruises or the main carrier when the collector gets within a set range, this is similar to the coalition repairing mechanism; instead of docking, your vehicles are healed by magic beams when they are within a set range of a repair vehicle such as the support cruiser. I can understand why the developers might have changed the game-play mechanisms at a late stage; maybe they ran out of time, or it was too difficult to implement them properly, or they were causing problems/balance issues, but if so they should at least alter/re-designed the appearance of the units affected to fit with the new game-play mechanics, not doing so is just lazy. 	Interceptors/strike fighters for all intensive purposes play like bombers even though both factions also have dedicated bomber units as well. Each interceptor (Gaalsien) or strike fighter (Coalition) carries a single "missile" which it can only fire at ground targets so its essentially a small guided bomb, they do not have any other weapons and so can NOT attack other air units. I assume from their names "interceptor" and "fighter" they were originally intended to be primarily air to air fighters and likely a hard counter to bombers and gunships, instead they just work like bombers and are arguable better at bombing than the actual bombers themselves and neither faction has any aircraft capable of fighting other aircraft which just seems silly.	If you order a redundant unit to be decommissioned/recycled/retired and get back a fraction of the resources used to make it, instead of returning into the carrier through the entrance (in an opposite manner to if you had just made the unit), as you would expect, the unit just clips through to the centre of the carrier from any point on the surface of the carrier which just looks stupid and breaks any immersion.  2) Why can I not dock my units!? An integral and incredibly useful feature of the homeworld games was the ability to dock smaller ships with your capital ship(s). With Deserts of Kharak this feature is no more, not even the smallest of vehicles such as resource collectors can be docked. Why this feature was not included is beyond me, it would have been so useful to have been able to dock units like resource collectors and small light vehicles, to protect them during attacks such as air strikes, instead you have to micro babysit them to keep them alive, which becomes a chore and general pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ The only units that are capable of docking with the capital carrier are the aircraft, and this is only because of the way aircraft work in the game.3) The campaign is ridiculously easy (including the "hardest" setting) and showcases a very special A.I. You can quite easily burn through all the missions in quick succession on the "hardest" difficulty (classic) without a challenge; it is also relatively easy to get through the whole campaign, on classic, without loosing a single unit, albeit at a slower pace. One issue is that the computer players, both enemies and allies in the campaign, rely almost exclusively on scripted build routines, scripted patrols and scripted attacks; they have no need for resources and can see the whole map. To be fair the AI was similar in homeworld 1+2 but that is no excuse for not improving it.4) The game feels like a downgrade from Homeworld 1+2. I understand that Deserts of Kharak is suposed to be a different game, with different features and setting (on a planet/2D as opposed to in space/3D), but the developers have deliberately made the game-play extremely similar to the previous homeworld games (which is not a bad thing) so the is no logical reason not to keep in things like the ability to dock smaller vehicles which would have been an extremely useful feature as well as adding to immersion. In actual fact this game is identical gameplay wise to the original homeworld games but missing features and depth (literally); it adds nothing which is a huge shame because I feel that this game could of been very good.	The campaign is very short (as with other homeworld games) and the story is ok but not great and feels fairly bland, I also get the impression that the lead up to the ending was rushed. I've come to expect and accept very generic/bland story's from games in general but because of this games predecessors I expected a bit more.The majority of my issues with the game could have fairly easily of been remedied with patches after launch but the developers instead thought it would be a "better" idea to re-skin a faction and sell it as DLC ><Like I have mentioned the game is not bad as such and it does have some good points, which I will now list. It looks pretty, runs relatively smoothly with only a few bugs (that I have noticed), random radio chatter (good for immersion), units are reasonably scaled.In conclusion, currently I do not recommend this game. if you have not played homeworld 1+2, buy the remastered edition of them, it is cheaper, and you get 2 games, both of which are better than this one. If you have already played homeworld 1+2 and want to play this game, I would still not recommend it, its far better to replay homeworld 1+2 and just read the plot of Deserts of Kharak on-line if you want to know the story. If you just want to play a new RTS then keep looking, the have been a few good and a lot of rubbish RTS games released recently. Personally I found Act of Aggression to be surprisingly enjoyable but I know a lot of people do not like it.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												Pretense this here first, I think this is a good game, but it's not really up to the standards of todays games.We are in an era where we have a blurring number of games, and other forms of entertainment, so we have little time or money to spare on other things, and I really can't suggest Deserts of Kharak as a good option.You can feel the age of the games design in how closely it follows with Homeworld.  Very linear story, not a lot of change of scenary, relatively short campaign, no real closure at the end.Artistically it's an amazingly beautiful game.  The ship/structure designs are top notch, and the visuals and cut scenes are wonderous pieces of art, but it really feels more like an episode of a telltale game more than a fleshed out world.There is not a lot of replayability in the game despite multiplayer but few of my friends even got the game, so it heralds back to an age where massively multiplayer options were just not an option.  Lastly it feels like the difficulty ramps down slowly from the beginning then immediately near the end they dump more power than you'd ever be able to really need or want, so it steals any excitement near the crucial climax of the game.If you have nothing else you'd rather play, or spend your money on, the game is still very homeworld-esque.  Great music score, amazing visuals in mechanical design, and cut scenes, but ultimately it feels like an incomplete story, no denouement almost at all, and odd unveiling of tech progression that holds the best till last stealing a lot of the challenge from early game.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												I'm a diehard Homeworld fan. Playing the original on Windows 98 when I was 7 got me into gaming, and since then I've played hundreds of games, yet none have matched Homeworld's place in my heart. Naturally, expectations were high for this game, perhaps unfairly so.Needless to say I was super excited to hear another Homeworld game was being made, but was equally terrified when it was announced it wouldn't be in space. Here's the impressions I've gotten so far (Mission 7, about 6 hours in)Positives:The story is great, like Homeworld stories always are.Strong voice acting - it's nice to have several people to identify with rather than just Karan S'Jet.Compelling enigmatic enemy - knowing the lore of the subsequent games makes it a lot more fun to learn about the Gaalsien.Soundtrack is classic Homeworld - almost too similar - did they actually use the same sound files?Cinematics are much improved - I loved seeing the interiors of the "ships" and the character's faces.Improved chatter - background chatter when things are slow really helps to build the immersion.Artifacts - although it seems to break with the HW canon, shipbreaking and collecting artifacts to beef up your ships is fun.Alas, despite all that is done well here, there are some things that at least for now have made it tough to recommend this game.Negatives:Unless you have a BRAND NEW beast of a machine, this game won't look good. I have a 4th gen i7, 8GB of RAM, and a 2GB dedicated Nvidia 745m with Windows 10, and it BARELY runs on the lowest settings. As such, my framerate is horrific, and the textures are so bad it reminds me of the 98 version of HW1. This confuses me, as I have beautiful games like Ethan Carter and HW Remastered running at 60fps on ultra. With such a laggy framerate (I'm lucky if I hit 30), immersion is instantly broken. Guess it's time to save up for yet another rig?Space is Homeworld's secret ingredient:I liked the idea of a prequel on Kharak, but space is what Homeworld does best. Watching little trucks dance around each other shooting 50 cals isn't nearly as glorious or boner-inducing as gigantic spaceships blowing the crap out of each other with big lasers. I tried so hard to like the ground fight, but the next HW project REALLY needs to head back out to space! PLEASE!Units die INCREDIBLY fast. I get it - Homeworld is designed to be a challenge by forcing you to discern the correct strategy (that's what makes it fun.) But this game punishes you like other Homeworlds never did. Your fleet will be wiped out in less than 30 seconds if you make one mistake in building your fleet. As such, you have to save OFTEN and reload those checkpoints more than I'd like.No resourcesOn one hand, I like the sense of desperation having little to no resources gives. But when my fleets are being wiped out in an instant and there are no resources left, I'm SOL and have to start again. Worse still, the old HW's had a mechanic that automatically collected any RU's left over at the end of a mission. Not the case here! Your mission will suddenly complete and your mining will be left unfinished, leaving you with nothing to rebuild next mission. While you can use a "default" fleet, that just feels like a cheat to me.Under constant assaultSo far, with the exception of the first mission, I have been under constant attack on multiple fronts, meaning 90% of my time is spent in the map instead of absorbing the beautiful desert world Blackbird worked so hard on building. I have no problem with coming under attack, but let me smell the desert roses a little first!I love the Homeworld universe to death and want to support this game in hopes of a HW3, but be warned - you need a beast PC to run this - and going from 3 dimensions to 2.5 will feel like a step in the wrong direction.

												I am astonished at how this game is rated so highly, especially when most of those buying/playing this game, I suspect, have played homeworld 1 + 2. The is some enjoyment to be found but its short lived and just not worth the price tag or time. The are a number of major issues I have with this game. 1) The game feels rushed and unfinished. For example, the appearance of some unit models doesn't fit with their final game-play implementation e.g. coalition support cruises, which function as armoured mobile resource drop of points for collectors and repair bays for all vehicles, have a large gaping whole in them where presumably collectors were supposed to dock and off-load their resources and/or where vehicles could dock for repairs. Instead resources just magically transfer from collectors to support cruises or the main carrier when the collector gets within a set range, this is similar to the coalition repairing mechanism; instead of docking, your vehicles are healed by magic beams when they are within a set range of a repair vehicle such as the support cruiser. I can understand why the developers might have changed the game-play mechanisms at a late stage; maybe they ran out of time, or it was too difficult to implement them properly, or they were causing problems/balance issues, but if so they should at least alter/re-designed the appearance of the units affected to fit with the new game-play mechanics, not doing so is just lazy. 	Interceptors/strike fighters for all intensive purposes play like bombers even though both factions also have dedicated bomber units as well. Each interceptor (Gaalsien) or strike fighter (Coalition) carries a single "missile" which it can only fire at ground targets so its essentially a small guided bomb, they do not have any other weapons and so can NOT attack other air units. I assume from their names "interceptor" and "fighter" they were originally intended to be primarily air to air fighters and likely a hard counter to bombers and gunships, instead they just work like bombers and are arguable better at bombing than the actual bombers themselves and neither faction has any aircraft capable of fighting other aircraft which just seems silly. With Deserts of Kharak this feature is no more, not even the smallest of vehicles such as resource collectors can be docked. Why this feature was not included is beyond me, it would have been so useful to have been able to dock units like resource collectors and small light vehicles, to protect them during attacks such as air strikes, instead you have to micro babysit them to keep them alive, which becomes a chore and general pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ The only units that are capable of docking with the capital carrier are the aircraft, and this is only because of the way aircraft work in the game.3) The campaign is ridiculously easy (including the "hardest" setting) and showcases a very special A.I. You can quite easily burn through all the missions in quick succession on the "hardest" difficulty (classic) without a challenge; it is also relatively easy to get through the whole campaign, on classic, without loosing a single unit, albeit at a slower pace. One issue is that the computer players, both enemies and allies in the campaign, rely almost exclusively on scripted build routines, scripted patrols and scripted attacks; they have no need for resources and can see the whole map. To be fair the AI was similar in homeworld 1+2 but that is no excuse for not improving it.4) The game feels like a downgrade from Homeworld 1+2. I understand that Deserts of Kharak is suposed to be a different game, with different features and setting (on a planet/2D as opposed to in space/3D), but the developers have deliberately made the game-play extremely similar to the previous homeworld games (which is not a bad thing) so the is no logical reason not to keep in things like the ability to dock smaller vehicles which would have been an extremely useful feature as well as adding to immersion. In actual fact this game is identical gameplay wise to the original homeworld games but missing features and depth (literally); it adds nothing which is a huge shame because I feel that this game could of been very good.	The campaign is very short (as with other homeworld games) and the story is ok but not great and feels fairly bland, I also get the impression that the lead up to the ending was rushed. I've come to expect and accept very generic/bland story's from games in general but because of this games predecessors I expected a bit more.The majority of my issues with the game could have fairly easily of been remedied with patches after launch but the developers instead thought it would be a "better" idea to re-skin a faction and sell it as DLC ><Like I have mentioned the game is not bad as such and it does have some good points, which I will now list. It looks pretty, runs relatively smoothly with only a few bugs (that I have noticed), random radio chatter (good for immersion), units are reasonably scaled.In conclusion, currently I do not recommend this game. if you have not played homeworld 1+2, buy the remastered edition of them, it is cheaper, and you get 2 games, both of which are better than this one. If you have already played homeworld 1+2 and want to play this game, I would still not recommend it, its far better to replay homeworld 1+2 and just read the plot of Deserts of Kharak on-line if you want to know the story. If you just want to play a new RTS then keep looking, the have been a few good and a lot of rubbish RTS games released recently. Personally I found Act of Aggression to be surprisingly enjoyable but I know a lot of people do not like it.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												As a long time fan of the Homeworld franchise (I remember getting the original for Christmas when I was in high school) I am sadly wishing I could get a refund... but unfortunately I have spent 5 hours with the game and can no longer do that.The good:-Interesting story- just like the other Homeworld games.-Very strong art direction (looks and feels like Homeworld)-Good visuals (it can sometimes be hard to discern what units are what when not in overlay mode though)-Good UI and game mechanics feel solid.The bad:-Laughably weak AI for skirmish. The devs should be embarassed by how incompetent the Normal AI is. The only reason the Hard AI is "hard" is because it is given a resource advantage and just kind of throws units at you. -Only 5 skirmish maps (2 2-player maps, 2 4-player maps, and 1 6-player map)-Very condensed game space and very small fleet cap. The one place this game does not feel like Homeworld is in its scope- battles tend to be much smaller tactical affairs. Honestly, I don't even know if I will finish the campaign. I would almost rather just play HW: Remastered or Planetary Annihilation: Titans.Since I already had HW: Remastered the game was $40 instead of $50.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												campaign was quite nice and enjoyable but lets face it with games these days its all about the multiplayer so how does that go? well if you like games like starcraft and you can build up ultra fast resources and pump out units like nobodies business then your gonna love this. if however your like me and find starcraft a bit too spammy and in all honesty just too damned fast then prepare to love literally EVERY game as your lovely little workers slowly toil away and they get utterly wrecked by what seems to be 10 thousand units, and if you manage to fend them off dont relax because ine xactly 5 seconds an even bigger army is coming your way. The matchmaking completly sucks because of region locking so you wait ages (ive seen the queue timer hit 30 minutes then i gave up) and when you finally get a game you get stomped because the person your matched against is simply FAR better than you and its not even close to a contest. The only way to have fun online is public games but of course this means no rank gained etc. I wouldnt mind this but i feel im at very least a silver player but being matched against players who should be diamond rank is just insane. So for the campaign yes i liked it, kinda worth the money but now its going to sit in my steam library unplayed because the multiplayer is so unbalanced its unreal

												First off, for a DirectX 9c game, this is very impressive and runs on older hardware for how nice it actually looks.Sure I've noticed a few people complaining about nvidia cards not really working with the game, go add it to your control panel and turn off your extra gpus...The gameplay, if you Bull rush every objective, like any homeworld game series can be incredibly short. Don't knock it before you try it you know.Lastly, if your not a Homeworld fan, well maybe you should go watch a youtube review about this first instead of read up on other peoples twisted views, including mine.-Edit: Will point out this, they really need to go about getting us some more skirmish maps.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												A lot of people say this is absolutely a Homeworld game... despite not being in space and set on a desert planet. Well, they're right. The music, the art, the story, the design of the units, the vast emptiness of the environments... it's all here. Do not be put off by the fact that it's set on the ground... because Blackbird Interactive definitely know what made the Homeworld games tick (and so they should - many of those guys worked on the originals) and they've served it up in spades.If you've never played a Homeworld game before, then imagine Supreme Commander set on a desert planet with Frank Herbert's Dune running on repeat in the background with your drunk mate mistaking it for Stargate every few minutes. It's that kind of scale - there are no human infantry here (your smallest unit - an attack buggy that is little more than a speck when zoomed out - is the size of a Monster Truck when considering scale to a person). This is all powered by the Unity 5 engine... and it looks spectacular. You'd think being set on a desert planet would make it look a bit samey but yikes, does this engine shine.The game itself is divided into a campaign, a skirmish, and multiplayer. The campaign is simply awesome. A prequel campaign set prior to (and covering) the discovery that kicked off the Mothership project in Homeworld 1, it's interesting to see the nods it makes to the future. I'd say it's closer to Homeworld 2 than 1, but has the same kind of themes in both - discovering the past of the Kushan, all the while fighting a war of seemingly insurmountable odds. Your 'Mothership' in this one is no colony vessel - the Kapisi is basically the USS Nimitz on tank treads and serves as a battleship, aircraft carrier, nuke platform, factory and research facility. Your fleet is persistent - units that survive one mission carry over into the next - and really makes it feel like you're running a fleet of craft just like the older Homeworld games - only you're exploring the vast desert instead of the stars. It's great.Skirmish is a bit more by the numbers. While the overall presentation and campaign is great, the actual factions are a bit dry - with only really the Gaalsien (imagine if ISIS and the Brotherhood of Nod had a lovechild and you're not far off) showing any real futuristic flair. The other base game faction - the Coalition - is about as bland as you can get (tanks, buggies, artillery, big tanks, big artillery and so on). This, mixed with patchy AI, make the skirmish a bit 'serviceable' rather than amazing. If you get the deluxe edition then you get a pair of DLC factions - Soban (Coalition who've kind of realised that they need to up their tech and use more railguns) and Kaaneph (Mad Max guys who nick their stuff from the Gaalsien). They're a bit better, but there is no deep tactical differences going on here. Everyone has rough variations of the same units.Multiplayer appears to be dead. Kaput. According to the forums there is still a small community out there, but tbh there are better RTSs if you want MP.The deluxe edition comes with the aforementioned DLC, an expedition guide (think Wikiapp with everything you ever wanted to know about Homeworld prior to the Homeworld 1) and the excellent soundtrack from the same guy who did the first two soundtracks. Personally, I got it in the Steam sale and I consider it easily worth that price... but at full price? You'd need to think about that.Regardless though... if you like sci-fi RTS, or you like Homeworld, you honestly can't go wrong here. The major complaint I've got with it is that it made me want to replay Homeworld 1 again, right when I was gearing up for an XCOM2 re-run. Damn it.EDIT: Updating this review to justify my nomination of this game for the  'I've got something in my eye' award. If you've played the campaign and seen the last few missions in particular.... yep.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												I could go on and on about what's awesome and what is just flat out wrong with this game for hours. I might even make a review about it on youtube, since there's a lot to discuss. In the end however, to do that here would end up in a TL:DR for most people. So I will simply say this:  when compared to Command and Conquer (C&C) 3, arguably the greatest land-based RTS game ever created (and from where I think this game got a lot of its inspiration from), this newest title of the beloved Homeworld franchise falls short of the RTS genre standard in its current state. In truth the game, without all of the bugs it has right now (and they are Legion, even causing my game to crash while in a skirmish here and there), comes off a lot more like C&C 4--what with the whole mobile base and hardly any fixed structures thing.Don't get me wrong. I like this game. I think it has massive potential. But the gameplay is restrictive, nothing on the villain's side I've played seems to work, In fact the Gaalsiens seem very rushed. And overall there seems to be an insufficient amount of asymmetrical gameplay between the two factions. It is there, but there could be more, WAY more. That all briefly said, I cannot recommend this game where it is now. Although, I do trust that there will be patches and definite DLC content added to this game. Being a student of business and the entrainment industry, I know what the developers have done with this title. It's a thing that's happening all over film, television, and gaming right now. It's this idea that "less is more." And in the case of Homeworld:  Deserts of Kharak, delivering LESS very much equals the fans wanting MORE. Gearbox, Blackbird, I WANT MORE! So they've done their jobs. What I'm asking for NOW is that this game receives the love, through patching, that it deserves. Get it working, place more unit variety in the game with more unique abilities, and it will be great! I just know it.*And for godsakes! Please remove the Gaalsien assualt cruiser as a coalition build option! It's utterly immersion breaking! And get a third faction in there! One with a flying carrier that's heavily reliant on support/assualt aircraft! As I said, MORE!Good job.
