content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak definitely lives up to its lineage, and while it doesn't drastically improve on any single aspect, it definitely shows that the Homeworld formula still has a great deal of life in it.(Information based on a Preview Press Copy provided to press prior to release)Pros:- Continues the solid gameplay of the Homeworld Universe- Cinematics are an upgrade from the old game, taking on an almost painterly feel- Interfaces are much more streamlines, and almost every unit has a "use" in the journey- Story so far is quite compelling (I haven't completed it as of this review, but would avoid spoilers anyways)- Music maintains the Homeworld Atmosphere, as does the unit art style- The voice acting is greatly improved over previous gamesCons:- Retained the "Units continue acting during in-mission cutscenes" (which can result in loss of units you don't have control over)- The models are slightly less detailed than the Remastered version's models (they're not ugly, they're just not as intricate)- Price Point is a little high, though this game is still worth a solid $30-35 USD or your regional equivalent.- Movement is very similar to the old Homeworld Games, but on a 2D plane, "good" control, but still a little more awkward feeling than other RTS's (the amount of control is a bit higher, it just makes micro management a bit more difficult)Notes: I have not gotten to test the multiplayer aspect of this game, nor have I beaten the story - some aspects of this could change, but I am happy with the game so far.The game favors a strong micro-management game when it comes to combat, which works well with the nice mix of unit abilities and strengths/weaknesses - it's more than rock/paper/scissors since different units can take advantage of the battlefield in differing ways (no units directly outclass others)A video review demonstrating gameplay and movement can be found here:


GamerFi - Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak [ First Impression | Gameplay | Review ] 
A Video of Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak
By: Alzorath

			I was a big fan of the Homeworld series back in the day, and was definitely looking forward to the Homeworld Prelude - Deserts of Kharak - it definitely lives up to its lineage, though it still has some of the less...

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Before DoK, I knew nothing of the Homeworld franchise.  The only reason I bought this was because it reminded me of Dune II all those years ago.  The pre-order came with Homeworld 1 & 2 remastered editions.  Knowing nothing of Homeworld, I played through those campaigns before starting the DoK prequel.  Solid and fun campaigns, reminded me of Battlestar Galactica.  Open space combat kind of felt like a giant submarine battle.  Interesting twist on RTS.  Remastered multiplayer could be fun but I prefer the polished balance of SC2 for competitive play.  I feared DoK would be a C&C4 abomination with the mobile carrier/construction yard.  It was not an abomination, it was excellent, a modern Dune II without the spice.  DoK has been widely criticized for multiplayer balance issues, a general lack of content, and easy campaign upgrades.  The balance is fine, I can win with either faction on all difficulty settings on skirmish mode.  Content is solid, but I did get 3 games for the price of one.  If you think the campaign is too easy then raise the difficulty and you won't have the resources to upgrade everything until maybe the later missions if you managed to keep your persistent fleet alive.  I enjoyed fleet persistence between missions on all 3 games.  The stories amount to a short comic book per game with little character development, and that's ok, it's still on par with or superior to most offerings.  DoK multiplayer could use some more maps, but there's plenty to get started with.  Now that the campaigns are done I might keep DoK installed to challenge my brothers on multiplayer when the price comes down.  I used the Steam Controller for all 3 campaigns.  Community templates get you started, might take an hour or two to customize for yourself.  After this I think the Steam Controller might improve my SC2 APM's.  If anymore DoK DLC comes out I'll probably play it too.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												First off I have always loved the homeworld series. Played them since they came out when i was a kid. And, i think this game and its background story as told in the expadition guide are incredible and i want more. There is a serious feel and connection to the old homeworld games that is distict. Ground Homeworld I feel is an AMAZING idea which needs to be repeated. That being said, there are many points about this game i like...Pros- Guard Command in this game is one of the most useful tools in this game. Allowing automatic battlegrounds that work really well.- The line of sight tool in this game works very well and that combined with the move command allows for simple and intresting game play- LAND CARRIERS HOW FREAKING COOL IS THAT!!!- Units look like they should work in real life and i havent noticed any clipping in the models themselves- The Battle Chatter is AMAZING!- Music is PERFECT. Its something thats many times over looked but it sets the scene and this games music does it well.- The Deserts themselves are very well done. The rolling dunes look real and the desert walls look so realistic.- Vehicles move very well as far as ive noticed.- waypoint setting is very intuitive- Once again if you read the expedition guide you find the story is SOOO rich its incredible. Very much worth touching on againThere are however a few big things that i dont likeCons - - TEXTURES ARE HORRIBLE and ill tell you why... if this where any other game id say what ever its an RTS. However this game is trying to focus on massive scales (not to mention being a series which always pushed the bounderies of graphics potential). As i play this game i find it very hard to realize the sence of scale because when i zoom as close as i can get to get a good scenic view the SAND LOOKS FUZZY AND UNDEFINED. This combined with the vehicles own textures being rather blurry results in making all the units look smaller. - SCALE COMPARISIONS are few and far between. with the sand and units hull detail lacking there is not much else to help you visualize the true scale being represented by the units under your command. Id like to see more human sized representations if not in some cases humans standing on the units walkways.- Terrain Shadows are not crisp even on Ultra which also separates me from the world immersion. - Weapons Fire seems very random. It would seem the units movement across the dunes means nothing. They could hit the target while on the move or miss by a mile while standing still. If your trying to sell the units as having future tech I don't see how you could miss by as much as some of these units do while they aren't moving.- Both teams units are basically the same exact things. As Ive heard it put so well, one teams units hover the other teams dont. Other then that they might as well be the same thing. Gotta switch it up. Every good RTS game ive ever played has done something to make the two teams really stand apart. Ground Control 2, all C&C games, War Craft and Star Craft are all examples of this. Also, all Total War games inately have this as well (because they seek to emulate real life)All and all dispite my gripes, I really like what this game is trying to do and its original concepts and story are fresh and inovative. I dont nessisarally think this game recaptures what i felt when i played homeworld & homeworld 2 for the first time as a kid. However, although i may not find it to be the best made Homeworld game its still a good game if your just looking to play a game. I think maybe if they kept up on this path and didnt abandon it this titles predesessors will be truely amazing. For that reason i have to vote this game up.

												This is a great RTS. It is shocking to see a reboot of an old series done so imaginatively and successfully. The gameplay is significantly improved compared to the old homeworld games, while the elements that made it good have been faithfully retained. It makes me so happy to see this happen for once.Thank you!!! Now please do Master of Orion and Baldur's Gate!

												Blackbird Interactive have really come through with this game, their first release ! In short the game has:Great soundtrack.Excellent voice acting with detailed and interesting "idle and background" chatter betweewn the players units.Engaging and interesting story, that keeps you playing the campaign till the very end, just like in Homeworld 1 !Even cooler animated cutscenes than HW1 and HW2's but true to their style.Nice multiplayer options, including a ladder ranking stystem (somewhat simmilar to Starcraft2 matchmaking), and why better lobby and MP support than in HW:RE.The somwhat less good sides are:Very long load times, im guessing its an Unity engine issue, rather than the games programmers fault.Somewhat mediocre graphics for a 2016 game "A" game.Overall a must have for any RTS and Homeworld fan ! content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												(Some spoilers for those who haven't played Homeworld)If you enjoyed the original Homeworld game, then you'll enjoy this sandy romp through the desert.You've got the familiar structure of units and strategy built around a central mobile base, you've got a heirarchy of units that each have that rock vs paper vs scissors tactical system at the low end, and a moving story about people fighting against the odds in the pursuit of truth + salvation in the face of tyranny.Everything a good Homeworld game needs.My only complaints are that the pacing of the game is forcibly fast, and the ending is a bit too succint in my opinion.(Spoilers for Deserts of Kharak, don't read on unless you don't mind the risk )Don't get me wrong, I enjoy all that is here, I just wish that the game wouldn't force certain conflicts that'll end the map, I can count 3~4 instances where a final battle on a map is forced because the enemy is rushing at me and I pretty much have little choice but to bring the hammer down.  I think this sort of tactic should be reserved for the classic difficulty, or add another mid boss type enemy that'll chase you down, but maybe save a final objective for when the player wishes to end it, for easy and / or normal difficulty anyhoo.Again my complaint is when the final objective that will end a map happens to be a boss type character that is chasing the Kapisi down, forcing an early end of a map, I don't mind if the enemy is throwing other groups of enemies or challenges at the kapisi, I just don't like having the map end so fast because the final objective is chasing the kapisi, this just shortens the game overall, I'm sure I would've gleefully enjoyed a few more hours recovering any and all artifacts and resources on each of the maps, and my overall playtime would've been closer to 15 ~ 20 hrs at least, and I would've been happier for it.The impatient players can always go force that final fight themselves, if they REALLY want to, what I liked about Homeworld was being able to strategize how I would win.As for the ending, yes all of us who played homeworld know what will be found deep in the great banded desert, BUT it would be nice to add more of that lore and story, I don't even remember seeing the galactic map etched on stone being found in 'Deserts of Kharak'.I mean sure, you see that in Homeworld proper in the intro, but that intro summarizes what happened after, told in the future.  I would have loved to see the S'jets exposition the discovery, maybe even discussion between the people who worked the expedition react, posit theory etc.  and then at least have a 5 minute + exposition about the next 100+ years:  The tribes again becoming the Kuushan, the world embracing unity and discovery, the design and building of the Great Mothership.Hopefully some decently priced DLC could cover this?  The greatest moving aspect of this franchise is the story, don't give it too short a shrift.  ;)Some other minor complaints I have include Rachel's Hack ability, why does it require RUs to use it? Why aren't hacked units special abilities researchable to add to your own units?Also why does Rachel habitually drive in front of the Kapisi if she is assigned to it?  shouldn't as a support unit naturally stay to the rear of the Kapisi?Why do direct fire units (like the railgun units) not get their shots eclipsed by terrain?  I'm pretty sure they shouldn't be able to shoot through hills / dunes accurately with ZERO line of sight.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												This game looks and feels like homeworld. Im not good with the lore of the series so I don't know how well of a prequel this is. There isn't much difference in units but it is enough to see different strategies between the factions. Multiplayer is a blast when you arent getting dsync.  I haven't seen any gamebreaking bugs. The only bug i have seen is the physics of unit animations bouncing around at times but it doesnt hurt the gameplay. Overall i really enjoy this game. If your an rts fan you'll love this game. I would write about the absolutely amazing unit feedback audio, but i think rock paper shotgun said it best:"The stand-out element, however, is the sound design. Over long years, we’ve miserably adjusted to the idea that all you can do with unit chatter is have each guy say something funny or militaryesque when you click on them, but Kharak casually rewrites the rules. Either by selecting units or by just hanging around and listening, you’ll hear the units talk amongst themselves. Select a unit and while sometimes they’ll just give an ‘acknowledged’, other times a more involved, context-sensitive reaction to whatever you’ve ordered them to do. An endangered unit might thank you for sending in air support. A ship which has spotted incoming enemies will tell you what type of craft they are. Idle units will chatter amongst themselves at length about faults and tactics. As well as successfully giving you a general sense of what’s going via audio alone, it sounds natural and responsive, rather than mechanical and repetitive – all adding to that sense that this is a large and well-oiled military machine, not just some cute little guys who popped out of a magic factory. Kharak might not otherwise be a landmark moment for the genre, but its unit audio does set new standards. It’s going to be so disappointing to play a strategy game filled with tinned quips after this." (Alec Meer, 2016, https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2016/01/21/homeworld-deserts-of-kharak-review/ )

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												I have always loved the Homeworld series when I first played it over 10 years ago.  Sadly I only played Homeworld 2 and didn't get to play the Homeworld 1 until the recent "remastered" edition came to steam.  With that said, I also enjoy playing games like Supreme Commander, Total War series, Distant World, etc.  A lot of 4x games and strategy games.  So when I saw this game about to be released five days ago (15 January 2016), I thought it would be interesting to get the game and follow the lore which I have enjoyed.  When I finally got to play the game, I was pleasantly surprised.Gameplay: 10/10As a standard RTS, there is resource gathering. but no base management.  Everything is mobile, just like Homeworld's motherships.  The UI is well structured and easy to navigate, those who say otherwise simply have not used control groups before.  With that said, Ctrl commands is something new to me.  It allows you to order selected units to target a selected enemy group through selection and pursue until all units of this selected group (designated by you) is destroyed, or you issue another order.  Depending on how you play, you might spend most of the match building up your force for a single and final confrontation, I will address this in detail at the combat section.Combat: 10/10(Unit Types)I will start with unit types.  The diversity in units between the two nations is moderately diverse, with one nation being more superior than the other on a few aspects.  However, the two nations generally have the same units that fulfill the same roles.  With that said, every single unit is different, since Gaalsian uses hover technology, while Coalition uses treads.  It was designed so that each nation will have more specialized units for a certain task.(Tactics/Strategy)With the limited number of units (10 + 3 air craft), it would be common for commanders to approach each other with similar forces.  However, because of this, there is not a single unit in the game that is useless.  Just because I can create battlecruisers, doesn't mean I will stop making the first unit.  Each unit fulfills its role adamantly.  The Carrier is also very combat efficient, so its not like a damsel in distress.  Terrain advantages and choke points can be utilized to maximum effectiveness.  If you are pressed, there is always a way out.  Enemy is harassing you with air?  Get missiles.  Raiding you with light vehicles?  Get armored vehicles to defend.  Their rails are destroying your armored vehicles?  Send your light vehicles in.(Aesthetics)This game is beautiful.  The battles are awesome to watch and very fluid.  The environment is very well crafted and actually plays a part in combat.  Sometimes it can actually be more important to secure a strategic position rather than resources.  Combat damages and wrecks remain for the remainder of the match as a "trophy" of the battlefield.  The explosions are gratifying, especially when you timed it perfectly to wreck havoc on the enemy.  Resulting a decisive victory. Sound/Music: 10/10The music is nice, and plays well as ambience.  The unit chatter is as needed and is not annoying.  The constant notifications received from these chatter is actually helpful and if you prefer listening to music rather than unit chatter then you might miss out on some vital information.  Every now and then, you will hear additional chatter between two radio lines and its interesting to listen on to their conversations.Replayability: 6/10Right now it only has 5 multiplayer maps.  However, the battles are always exhilirating.  The campaign is good, but also good for one play only.  So replayability right now is low for campaign, but moderate for multiplayer.  So please get this game and join the fun!Also, I have not encountered a single bug and plays very well at max.i7-4790 3.6 ghz Quad2x GTX 97016 GB ramSSD46/50 or 92% rating from me!  In some states, 92% is actually an A (talk about lowered standards).STEAM PLEASE FIX REVIEW SETTINGS!  I couldn't post this review until I only posted my first paragraph, then edited it to add the rest!

The only bug i have seen is the physics of unit animations bouncing around at times but it doesnt hurt the gameplay. Overall i really enjoy this game. If your an rts fan you'll love this game. I would write about the absolutely amazing unit feedback audio, but i think rock paper shotgun said it best:"The stand-out element, however, is the sound design. Over long years, we’ve miserably adjusted to the idea that all you can do with unit chatter is have each guy say something funny or militaryesque when you click on them, but Kharak casually rewrites the rules. Either by selecting units or by just hanging around and listening, you’ll hear the units talk amongst themselves. Select a unit and while sometimes they’ll just give an ‘acknowledged’, other times a more involved, context-sensitive reaction to whatever you’ve ordered them to do. An endangered unit might thank you for sending in air support. A ship which has spotted incoming enemies will tell you what type of craft they are. Idle units will chatter amongst themselves at length about faults and tactics. As well as successfully giving you a general sense of what’s going via audio alone, it sounds natural and responsive, rather than mechanical and repetitive – all adding to that sense that this is a large and well-oiled military machine, not just some cute little guys who popped out of a magic factory. Kharak might not otherwise be a landmark moment for the genre, but its unit audio does set new standards. It’s going to be so disappointing to play a strategy game filled with tinned quips after this." (Alec Meer, 2016, https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2016/01/21/homeworld-deserts-of-kharak-review/ )

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												I have always loved the Homeworld series when I first played it over 10 years ago.  Sadly I only played Homeworld 2 and didn't get to play the Homeworld 1 until the recent "remastered" edition came to steam.  With that said, I also enjoy playing games like Supreme Commander, Total War series, Distant World, etc.  A lot of 4x games and strategy games.  So when I saw this game about to be released five days ago (15 January 2016), I thought it would be interesting to get the game and follow the lore which I have enjoyed.  When I finally got to play the game, I was pleasantly surprised.Gameplay: 10/10As a standard RTS, there is resource gathering. but no base management.  Everything is mobile, just like Homeworld's motherships.  The UI is well structured and easy to navigate, those who say otherwise simply have not used control groups before.  With that said, Ctrl commands is something new to me.  It allows you to order selected units to target a selected enemy group through selection and pursue until all units of this selected group (designated by you) is destroyed, or you issue another order.  Depending on how you play, you might spend most of the match building up your force for a single and final confrontation, I will address this in detail at the combat section.Combat: 10/10(Unit Types)I will start with unit types.  The diversity in units between the two nations is moderately diverse, with one nation being more superior than the other on a few aspects.  However, the two nations generally have the same units that fulfill the same roles.  With that said, every single unit is different, since Gaalsian uses hover technology, while Coalition uses treads.  It was designed so that each nation will have more specialized units for a certain task.(Tactics/Strategy)With the limited number of units (10 + 3 air craft), it would be common for commanders to approach each other with similar forces.  However, because of this, there is not a single unit in the game that is useless.  Just because I can create battlecruisers, doesn't mean I will stop making the first unit.  Each unit fulfills its role adamantly.  The Carrier is also very combat efficient, so its not like a damsel in distress.  Terrain advantages and choke points can be utilized to maximum effectiveness.  If you are pressed, there is always a way out.  Enemy is harassing you with air?  Get missiles.  Raiding you with light vehicles?  Get armored vehicles to defend.  Their rails are destroying your armored vehicles?  Send your light vehicles in.(Aesthetics)This game is beautiful.  The battles are awesome to watch and very fluid.  The environment is very well crafted and actually plays a part in combat.  Sometimes it can actually be more important to secure a strategic position rather than resources.  Combat damages and wrecks remain for the remainder of the match as a "trophy" of the battlefield.  The explosions are gratifying, especially when you timed it perfectly to wreck havoc on the enemy.  Resulting a decisive victory. Sound/Music: 10/10The music is nice, and plays well as ambience.  The unit chatter is as needed and is not annoying.  The constant notifications received from these chatter is actually helpful and if you prefer listening to music rather than unit chatter then you might miss out on some vital information.  Every now and then, you will hear additional chatter between two radio lines and its interesting to listen on to their conversations.Replayability: 6/10Right now it only has 5 multiplayer maps.  However, the battles are always exhilirating.  The campaign is good, but also good for one play only.  So replayability right now is low for campaign, but moderate for multiplayer.  So please get this game and join the fun!Also, I have not encountered a single bug and plays very well at max.i7-4790 3.6 ghz Quad2x GTX 97016 GB ramSSD46/50 or 92% rating from me!  In some states, 92% is actually an A (talk about lowered standards).STEAM PLEASE FIX REVIEW SETTINGS!  I couldn't post this review until I only posted my first paragraph, then edited it to add the rest!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												Honestly, I was totally excited when I saw Hardware: Shipbreakers, cause I knew right off the bat that it was a prequel to HW1.  Me and my bro used to play these games all the time even though I was too young to understand the story at the time, eventual re-runs solved that as I got older.  In my opinion, the story is the best part in the HW series, and is the overall contribution to the positive review.  There are some minor things that could have been improved on but I believe HW: DK holds true to the previous games as being story rich.  My only real disappointment was after the first mission when the stats of the fleet showed up and it showed the water and fuel levels.  I was really hoping for there to be some side missions where you had to re-supply and half-way hoping that the units in the game had a fuel meter that had to be managed or risk leaving a craft a sitting duck while waiting for fuel rats.  I know it kinda sounds like a pain but this would have had a moderate impact on how the game would have been played, as the last thing any sane person would have done was attack an excavation site running on fumes and it would have added a great deal to the desperate mood of the game.Now, I was reading through some of the other reviews and I have to admit, the graphics, camera controls, and unit diversity was a bit subpar.  Although I am more concerned about the camera controls than the graphics.  It was sometimes very difficult to get a good view of what was going on around you but popping into the strategy view helps with that at the loss of viewing the actual crafts.  I think that the ships could have been more detailed upon closer inspection and some of the in-mission cutscenes really pointed this out.  Finally the unit diversity, which was pretty small, but in my honest opinion, was a good choice to go with as the story line revolves around a fleet with limited supplies (again, not as stressed as I was hoping it to be) going from point A to point B fighting enemies along the way.  Having multipurpose crafts such as the Baserunner would have been the economical choice.  Also I can't think of any other way to diversify the fleet that wouldn't have to have been re-discovered in HW1, such as beam weapons and the like.  Would be kind of silly to have a beam weapon craft in HW: DK and then play HW1 and have to buy Beam Tech from the Bentusi in order to build one :SI have yet to play MP, but I looked at it briefly and noticed there are very few maps.  I fear that DLC will add more maps and content for the price of 30 dollars...

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												This is a good take on an excellent classic. It's a RTS, but it's not in the same vein as the frenzied click-fest style of so many modern RTS's. For the most part, you have time to plan moves, co-ordinate attacks with ground and air assets, long range and repair craft all contributing towards a sucessful maneuver.There are times when it does turn into a panic, and you have to move fast and click even faster, but that's not the norm, and I think it only serves to add tension to an otherwise slower paced RTS.Significient tactical choices are few, but vital. For exmaple, some terrain will not allow the passage of your carrier, so do you leave it unguarded and send the rest of your units off, or split them, losing the punch?I haven't tried mlultiplayer yet, but I can imagine that is a bit more of a click-fest, but still not overwhelmingly so, due to the way the game works. I think that it will be played better on the tactical map for MP than in the close u p pretty view though, so you can keep an eye on what your opponent is up to.The game looks and sounds very good indeed, and although that's not why you buy a strategy game, it does add a lot towards the value of it.Overall, I'd recommend this game as rewarding and fun to play, but not a serious challange, at least in SP mode.

												It has nothing to do with the old homeworld games.None of the atmosphere,the cutscenes etc are banal boring feely woman researcher point of view.The story is weak,no developments,i thought the game was gonna really kick off when it ended instead.This was not so in homeworld.It is almost an intro for a story.I don't know what everybody is going on giving this positive reviews but it has a 8 hour sp campaign,nothing special about it.I guess people are supporting for old time's sake and another homeworld game.But it is plain old strategy game on par with old command and conquer games.Yeah the only difference is the base is moving.It's graphics are good,gameplay is not boring.It could have been better with a better story,But the elements incorporated are weak.The dev's should have seen it on the board that they were lacking,but alas.Honestly hire a few new graduates out of the school and let them go for it.It's a very bland story,it just doesn't work.Haven't tried multi yet,but I wouldn't buy it at sales prices,not suggested.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
												If, like me, before you bought this game you'd heard that the game didn't match the standard of the other Homeworld games, that it didn't fit the "Homeworld family" and that put you off buying the game, let me tell you something. Whoever said that, they were wrong. I will spoil some plot points later, but I will warn in advanceHomeworld: Deserts of Kharak is very much a member of the Homeworld family, and not just a formal it exists way. It's story is strong, with surprise turn arounds and unexpected events, it still carries the "lone fleet" feeling of the Homeworld 1 and 2, in fact I'd say that feeling is stronger in this game than it is in Homeworld 2, the constant news of Coalition (the player faction) outposts under attack and Gaalsien force movements creates the feeling of isolation more so than any of HW2 plot. This is further reinforced by the fact that your sole ally in your journey isn't a member of Coalition forces, instead they are Sidiim, another faction on Kharak.One of the most powerful moments of this is the start of a mission, when to come to the aid of stranded fleet units the Carrier overloads it's engines to reach the mission site while they're still intact, the cutscene of the gigantic vessel bouncing over a dune was one of the most powerful moments of the campaign, giving strength to the feeling of the fleet being on it's own with no cavalry comming. This is what Homeworld really is about, the perservation of a single fleet through immense odds.I'll break away from the talk about how HW:DOK plot and story earn it it's rightful place in the Homeworld series to talk about gameplay. It's good, there's nothing quite as enjoyable as launching a cruise missile at the enemy, or ordering all of your fighter wings to bombard enemies that are giving your ground forces a hard time. The rank system where units gain eperience and gain promotions gives you a reason to preserve your units and to care when their destroyed, unlike in the original Homeworlds where the only thing you cared about losing was capital ships due to the extreme cost in replacing them. The rank system doesn't make units OP, for example you aren't going to be facing down a battlecruiser with a single high rank Light Attack Vehicle, but having high ranked units does give you the edge, and it's nice to see a reward for smart tactics than just "You saved some RP!".Spoilers from here!Back to the plot and story, again I feel it delivers better, and not in ways that can't be explained by better technology. The main adversary I can understand as to why he declared holy war, his faith felt real, mostly supported by the cutscene for his death, pleading for the players faction to request forgiveness from Sajuuk. The Sidiims betrayal came as a surprise, despite the captain of the Carrier expressing concerns about them in his personal log, but I expected my ally to push to far and get themselves killed in battle in a cutscene, so the shock of watching them blow the aircraft bringing my resupply out of the sky after I'd protected the rock being used as a landing strip for both of us was genuine. The voice acting, while my laptop was constantly garbling half of the spoken audio, what came out ungarbled was a level of quality higher than old homeworld games, not in a higher quality of sound way, but in terms of performance. Concern in the characters voices is common place, theres bitterness in the captains personal log after the Sidiim's betrayal, things that were again missing in the original homeworld games.Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak to me is very much a Homeworld game. It worked hard to get there, but it is one. It's plot powerful, like the old games, it has ways to jump the enemy and embrace power fantasy, similar to how jumping a battlecruiser into the enemy production fleet felt in HW2.Finally, it blends the high speed duels of light craft (LAVs and fighers) with the slow combat of the larger vessels in the Homeworld way, so that while there may be one battle going on, but in that battle there'll be multiple battles going on, each one affecting the overall outcome. At least until you steamroll everything with the OP artillery cruisers, similar to how being the first with battlecruisers in a HW2 match felt.It's pretty much all I can ask for in a Homeworld game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												So I played all the way through, and i Want to reccomend it, but I just cant.I completed the game because, well, i'm persistent. Dont look at the hours and take anything from that, I spent a lot of time sitting defending while pillaging the maps resources. You will too, since beating a map does not reward you with the resources and you need to get them manually or lose them at mission end. Not my idea of a good time.Lets add to that some serisouly missing feature in any RTS of this style. There are no formations. So here I am with a bunch of mixed units that move at various speeds and literally the only way i can find to get them to move at the same speed is to have all the units guard one of the slowest units and tell that to move. This does not work out well on tight maps i can tell you, because the AI is beyond stupid when it comes to navigation. Aircraft: Enjoy launching your sorties and either A: Watching it blow something up and waiting forever for it to be available again and forgetting about it or B: watching it blow something up and immediately die from AA since it never prioritizes AA unless you tell it to. It is kind of fun to watch 12 fighters cricle the carrier wating to land though. A question: If they can land with VTOL, why dont they take off that way? And my favorite of the day: Cutscenes during the action that dont stop the action. If you're going to wrest control from my micromanaging hands in the middle of a battle, at least have the decency to pause the action. But alas, no dice. You will watch the a sinking heart as the border closes in and you lose unit control just as you needed to take some kind of action and sit through somethng either brutally obvious forced tactical view or a (admittedly nice) visual cutscene while your units are slaughtered and calling out for orders. Did i mention you can't seem to skip most of these? Pros: Its pretty. And the story is nice, if a bit predictable. They tried to do too many Homeworld things, and implemented them really poorly. Give it a pass unless its Really cheap. Then prepare for nail biting resource gathering unless you want to start missions with nothing.

It's plot powerful, like the old games, it has ways to jump the enemy and embrace power fantasy, similar to how jumping a battlecruiser into the enemy production fleet felt in HW2.Finally, it blends the high speed duels of light craft (LAVs and fighers) with the slow combat of the larger vessels in the Homeworld way, so that while there may be one battle going on, but in that battle there'll be multiple battles going on, each one affecting the overall outcome. At least until you steamroll everything with the OP artillery cruisers, similar to how being the first with battlecruisers in a HW2 match felt.It's pretty much all I can ask for in a Homeworld game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
												If, like me, before you bought this game you'd heard that the game didn't match the standard of the other Homeworld games, that it didn't fit the "Homeworld family" and that put you off buying the game, let me tell you something. Whoever said that, they were wrong. I will spoil some plot points later, but I will warn in advanceHomeworld: Deserts of Kharak is very much a member of the Homeworld family, and not just a formal it exists way. It's story is strong, with surprise turn arounds and unexpected events, it still carries the "lone fleet" feeling of the Homeworld 1 and 2, in fact I'd say that feeling is stronger in this game than it is in Homeworld 2, the constant news of Coalition (the player faction) outposts under attack and Gaalsien force movements creates the feeling of isolation more so than any of HW2 plot. This is further reinforced by the fact that your sole ally in your journey isn't a member of Coalition forces, instead they are Sidiim, another faction on Kharak.One of the most powerful moments of this is the start of a mission, when to come to the aid of stranded fleet units the Carrier overloads it's engines to reach the mission site while they're still intact, the cutscene of the gigantic vessel bouncing over a dune was one of the most powerful moments of the campaign, giving strength to the feeling of the fleet being on it's own with no cavalry comming. This is what Homeworld really is about, the perservation of a single fleet through immense odds.I'll break away from the talk about how HW:DOK plot and story earn it it's rightful place in the Homeworld series to talk about gameplay. It's good, there's nothing quite as enjoyable as launching a cruise missile at the enemy, or ordering all of your fighter wings to bombard enemies that are giving your ground forces a hard time. The rank system where units gain eperience and gain promotions gives you a reason to preserve your units and to care when their destroyed, unlike in the original Homeworlds where the only thing you cared about losing was capital ships due to the extreme cost in replacing them. The rank system doesn't make units OP, for example you aren't going to be facing down a battlecruiser with a single high rank Light Attack Vehicle, but having high ranked units does give you the edge, and it's nice to see a reward for smart tactics than just "You saved some RP!".Spoilers from here!Back to the plot and story, again I feel it delivers better, and not in ways that can't be explained by better technology. The main adversary I can understand as to why he declared holy war, his faith felt real, mostly supported by the cutscene for his death, pleading for the players faction to request forgiveness from Sajuuk. The Sidiims betrayal came as a surprise, despite the captain of the Carrier expressing concerns about them in his personal log, but I expected my ally to push to far and get themselves killed in battle in a cutscene, so the shock of watching them blow the aircraft bringing my resupply out of the sky after I'd protected the rock being used as a landing strip for both of us was genuine. The voice acting, while my laptop was constantly garbling half of the spoken audio, what came out ungarbled was a level of quality higher than old homeworld games, not in a higher quality of sound way, but in terms of performance. Concern in the characters voices is common place, theres bitterness in the captains personal log after the Sidiim's betrayal, things that were again missing in the original homeworld games.Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak to me is very much a Homeworld game. It worked hard to get there, but it is one. It's plot powerful, like the old games, it has ways to jump the enemy and embrace power fantasy, similar to how jumping a battlecruiser into the enemy production fleet felt in HW2.Finally, it blends the high speed duels of light craft (LAVs and fighers) with the slow combat of the larger vessels in the Homeworld way, so that while there may be one battle going on, but in that battle there'll be multiple battles going on, each one affecting the overall outcome. At least until you steamroll everything with the OP artillery cruisers, similar to how being the first with battlecruisers in a HW2 match felt.It's pretty much all I can ask for in a Homeworld game.

												Pretty, polished, has a sense of good production value. It will provide nostalgia for Homeworld fans, and possibly even for fans of games like Emperor Battle for Dune. Multiplayer died a while ago, skirmish is monotonous and features AI from yester-decade, and there doesn't appear to be any new content coming down the pipe... which is probably a good thing since the DLC we did get was apparently reskins. Impossible to recommend at anything above the used bargain bin prices.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Review will be updated as I go through it.Huge fan of Homeworld franchise and I am having a blast with Deserts of Kharak!Played only the campaign but it is amazing so far. The entire game feels like Homeworld. Amazing sound design, hearing the chatter of the nearby units is a truly immersive experience. Chatter is not active only durring battles, when units are idle there are a lot of talking going on. Amazing stuff. I didn't expect the UI design to be this good, the navigation is simple and no need to juggle between numerous screens. The only negative here is the rebinding. It is not possible to do it, it should be a standard when it comes to PC gaming. But the presets are very well done so not a huge issue for me there. But I agree that there is no excuse for leaving it out.Graphic quality is on par with the entire HW feel, someone might argue that the AA and shadow quality could have been better, but it is unnoticable when you are having a good time with the game. The entire feel, atmosphere, combat sounds, the movement and physics of the vehicles.....simply amazing. The detail on the units is uncanny, with a lot of personal touches, makes all those vehicle look believable and real. The game also runs very well on my system, I was a bit worried since I saw some people have issues with 980TI  ( I have i5 8gb RAM GTX 970). All on ULTRA, no  issues at all, even during huge battles.Gameplay is also top notch. I see a lot of people worried about the number of units and I have to ask you: What happened to quality over quantity? I agree, on paper it looks meager, but when you take the reins of the game it is obvious that each unit has it's purpose. Every unit has it's weakness and it's strength and they support each other marvelously. The feeling of sending your LAV's to charge the long range artilery, while your tanks provide smoke cover is simply amazing. You activate the boosts for LAV's while they fly over the dunes while firework spectacle around them begins to unravel....Air support kicks in just in time to help the assault.....You harass the enemy and start "boosting" your retreat to the nearest Support vehicle for repairs, dust coulds all around you.....Another succesfull attack....Simply AMAZING! More units =/= more tactical option. It is much more important (for me at least) to have units that have it's purpose. The situation reminds me of Shogun 2 and the backlash that it caused with the info that unit number will be small (compared to other TW) and factions will be very similar. It turned out great for TW, much better then adding a bunch of very similar units with no real purpose on the battlefield. As I said: Quality over Quantity.Now for some negatives: No formations...This hurts me the most it seems, the game really needs it. Ordering units to move or to attack is a nightmare if it is a mixed group, each unit moves at their own max speed. It is a tactical disaster, it can be bypased by micromanaging each unit group separately but it can be a pain.The game has some cliping issues. It is an RTS but it really looks ugly sometimes when Kapisi just rolls over S'jet, without S'jet moving an inch. There is also an issue when you group some units together. It can look ugly and it can ruin the immersion. But sometimes, when the collision works like it should, units can get stuck. My resource collectors got stuck in a loop and I didn't even notice, the lack of resources almost costed me a battle. It is not often but it can happen.AI has it's flaws. I haven't tried skirmish yet, but I have seen a lot of proof that it is not the best. I haven't noticed it too much during campaign, it was actually suprisingly good there (they are retreating heavy artillery and tanks if they don't have light unit support etc.) but you can see some signs of "stupidity" (rushing positions etc.)The above mentioned rebinding issue.Only 5 skirmish maps. This is a rather small number, HW never had an abundance of maps, but land RTS should have some more variety.All in all I am having a blast. Fun game, great campaign, just as I expected. Some might argue that the price is a bit high. For now, I am having my moneys worth, people are also forgetting that you could get 3 amazing games for that price or an discount as an owner of Remastered.  For the fun I am having, it is a fair price. Could have been better when it comes to MP content, but I am sure that we will have a lot of content down the road (BBI confirmed new maps, all for free with additional DLC/Expansion plans)Great game :)

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Do you love Homeworld ?Do you want more Homeworld ?If yes then this is more Homeworld...-The game feels like Homeworld, it sounds like Homeworld, looks ,feels ,everything you loved and enjoyed about Homeworld...-Instead of endless space in glorious 3d environment with nebulas,asteroids ect.-You now fight on an arid world with a more traditional 2d environment.(Still have anomalies like tornado's and sandstorms)-Controls are pretty much the same = you have your 10 designated group slots.-Attack move orders with multiple move orders holding shift just like any RTS and my personal favourite the ctrl drag box over enemy order (very handy when engaging weak units with your stronger units and their slow larger units with your more agile smaller units)-A new feature is the air units and how you command them.Instead of individuel units your carrier launches squadrons at a time at a designated target area, attacking enemy in the area. (Command & Conquer Generals style)-Another immersive aspect i noticed was a lot more chatter between units (when not engaged in combat) often calling in on the radio about sensor readings bugging out on their monitor or they forgot to change their vehicles filter ect.(A really nice touch)-Graphical fidelity on 4K ultra looks amazing. (Only noticed some shadow distortion)-Decent campaign and story as per Homeworld tradition (Im not going to talk about the AI,so many other reviews mention this)-Also i haven't played mutliplayer or skirmish yet.Great Homeworld game get it Most poeple rate this at 8/10 I think it deserves more 9/10 at least

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												I love this game because it is a Homeworld game. As in that way that its feels like it was meant to fill out the Lore of the series. To that end I feel it as faithful to those intentions as they are to presenting the wastes of Kharak. There is still alot of potential for the game and a lot of things it needs to open to the steam gaming community if it is to be as wildly successful as the confidence the game exudes over itself which would be fine, if it did not feel unfinnished. perhaps released too early even. The multi player map selection is limited the game modes offered feel limited. This newer "sequel prequel" lacks features that the actual Homeworld 1 released back in 1999 had such as Tactical Pause. Granted it is a feature that is meant for single player really but its still a very basic feature and has been since the series introduction. The game also has no workshop support in its present form, this does not bode well to the long term sale of the game its self and says volumes about its sustainability over time. Would I recommend others buy this game? Yes I would. To be of Note** I think it needs our support and encouragement to reach its full potential but until it fixes the lack of workshop support and all that which implies therein I will say that its not going to be for everybody

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												A high-quality modern RTS, but very short singleplayer campaign.The story takes a while to get going - they don't give you reason to be invested in this expedition until it's been going awhile, unlike the older Homeworlds, where the singular nature of the mothership provides immediate weight.  Here, it mostly feels like a plot designed purely to shove you into the combat in a way consistent with established lore - it's not until most of the way through the campaign that it starts to feel like more than a perfunctory/excuse plot and starts explaining its own internal logic.  By the end though, it does feel like a Homeworld game in tone, if not in length or depth.  The lore seems to mostly follow Homeworld 2, while the gameplay more draws from Homeworld 1.The campaign seems a bit on the easy side.  For much of the campaign, the unit mix is relatively modern (ie small set of rock-paper-scissors units) - the unit diversity only comes in rather late, which is unfortunate, since the late missions are often much *shorter* since you have such a strong, veteran force (and numerous tools & utilities) by then.  Air units are treated more like special attacks than units, and are incredibly powerful, seeming to negate much of the potential difficulty.  The brevity means much of compounding economic decisions Homeworld usually has you make are vastly milder here.  It's like the game is filled with Homeworld's great macro-mechanics, but the campaign fails to utilize them well.The brevity of the campaign is unfortunate, and makes it a questionable purchase at full launch price if that's your main interest.  But the quality means that if you can get over the lack of content by one means or another, Shipbreakers Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a solid offering.  Certainly the best RTS I've encountered in many years.

												I've never played any of the "Homeworld" games but have been a long-time RTS fan.  I just finished the campaign and while the story seemed full it was a bit short and at the end I didn't really feel any closure.  The unit makup was diverse enough to keep me interested as they were introduced.  My only frustration was that the carrier functionality proved so critical, yet it takes a decade for aircraft to re-arm/repair etc.  I felt like several hours of gameplay was basically waiting for my next round of fighters to be available. All that said, did I get $50 of enjoyment out of it?  Absolutely, I'm only this critical because I love RTS games in general.  I anticipate some DLC in the future to continue the story!

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												I love this game because it is a Homeworld game. As in that way that its feels like it was meant to fill out the Lore of the series. To that end I feel it as faithful to those intentions as they are to presenting the wastes of Kharak. There is still alot of potential for the game and a lot of things it needs to open to the steam gaming community if it is to be as wildly successful as the confidence the game exudes over itself which would be fine, if it did not feel unfinnished. perhaps released too early even. The multi player map selection is limited the game modes offered feel limited. This newer "sequel prequel" lacks features that the actual Homeworld 1 released back in 1999 had such as Tactical Pause. Granted it is a feature that is meant for single player really but its still a very basic feature and has been since the series introduction. The game also has no workshop support in its present form, this does not bode well to the long term sale of the game its self and says volumes about its sustainability over time. Would I recommend others buy this game? Yes I would. To be of Note** I think it needs our support and encouragement to reach its full potential but until it fixes the lack of workshop support and all that which implies therein I will say that its not going to be for everybody

The overarching fleet you bring mission to mission accross the campaign gains experience, and if you find yourself in a failure spiral midway through the campaign you have the option of either changing difficulty or gaining a default fleet for that stage in the game. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												Love all the Homeworld games.Wanted to love this.Didn't happen.Graphics - Great, top-notchSound - Also very nice. No complaints.UI - Mediochre. Needs work.Gameplay - Fail.So here's how every mission will go.The game will most likely drop you into a senario where you have about 5 seconds to react and setup your forces before you start getting pounded or have to go meet some timed objective. Oh and remember, there's NO PAUSE feature so forget about doing any planning or strategy. You will then proceed to move into a defensive formation around your carrier. That is pretty much the last you will move your ground forces for the remainder of mission (with the exception of maybe sending out scavs). They will just sit there turtled and defending.Why? Well a number of reasons.Computer has infinite resourses and units. You do not. sending out your units is pointless since even if they win a skirmish, the enemy will get new units in 5 seconds for free. Eventually you will lose all your units and will have accomplished little to nothing. Ground forces are just defensive turrets for your carrier.Also the game does not allow a high enough unit cound to field and offensive and a defensive team. If you use your units on offense, your carrier will be undefended.The only real offensive units are your aircraft. They will do ALL the work and they will do it better and more efficiently than any of your ground units.Another thing....your units in this game are WAY too fragile. It's absolutely stuipid how fast units die.Another downside to the game is mission design. Whoever was in charge of this, you really need to go back to flipping burgers.Almost every mission is exactly the same. They pretend to be different, but in the end I played almost every mission exactly the same, had the same triggers, had the same outcomes.Only variety to this was when the game would randomly take units away from you for ....reasons.My favorite occurance of this being when you carrier arrives to a misson BEFORE all you other units/crusiers/etc. Um ok, your carrier, which is basically the slowest, lumbering beast in your entire task force, by some miracle, managed to arrive at the combat site a full half day before all these other units which are faster.Sure makes perfect sense.Another gripe...Research.So for the first handful of missions you get to research a few things at a time. Than at one point in the game you suddenly get like 50 things to research (basically all of the tech left in the game). Even though you are really only about half way through the game.There's a veterancy system in the game but good luck with that. I acutally went through the trouble to farm units for a LONG time to build up veterancy in many of my forces. Only to have these forces instantly obliterated later by...oh any host of things. It doesn't matter. Your units pretty much die if anything larger than a gnat hits them.For a game that claims to be an RTS, it is by far the worst RTS I've played in a LONG time.But quite frankly, it's really not an RTS.So there's my rant. Sorry if it's a bit random but I tend to just spew thoughts.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												A high-quality modern RTS, but very short singleplayer campaign.The story takes a while to get going - they don't give you reason to be invested in this expedition until it's been going awhile, unlike the older Homeworlds, where the singular nature of the mothership provides immediate weight.  Here, it mostly feels like a plot designed purely to shove you into the combat in a way consistent with established lore - it's not until most of the way through the campaign that it starts to feel like more than a perfunctory/excuse plot and starts explaining its own internal logic.  By the end though, it does feel like a Homeworld game in tone, if not in length or depth.  The lore seems to mostly follow Homeworld 2, while the gameplay more draws from Homeworld 1.The campaign seems a bit on the easy side.  For much of the campaign, the unit mix is relatively modern (ie small set of rock-paper-scissors units) - the unit diversity only comes in rather late, which is unfortunate, since the late missions are often much *shorter* since you have such a strong, veteran force (and numerous tools & utilities) by then.  Air units are treated more like special attacks than units, and are incredibly powerful, seeming to negate much of the potential difficulty.  The brevity means much of compounding economic decisions Homeworld usually has you make are vastly milder here.  It's like the game is filled with Homeworld's great macro-mechanics, but the campaign fails to utilize them well.The brevity of the campaign is unfortunate, and makes it a questionable purchase at full launch price if that's your main interest.  But the quality means that if you can get over the lack of content by one means or another, Shipbreakers Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a solid offering.  Certainly the best RTS I've encountered in many years.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												I sort of recommend this game. For the price, there's little content to keep you going long term (5 maps??), and the unit type and population cap limit the scope of the game. Much like Homeworld though, there's something a bit special about this game. The low unit cap and mix means that the game is a micromanager's dream come true. Launching a gunship is a real event, if only because you have access to so few, while that isolated handful of tanks on the perimiter becomes increasingly precious as damage is taken from waves of enemy units. It's a little like Dawn of War 2 in many ways, though no where near as developed.I've heard the game called a Beta, and I'd agree with this. The resource wrecks are all copy/paste efforts for the same model, for example. Work needs to be done on the skirmish AI, though it's not quite as bad as some say. Personally, I find the carrier base to be slightly ridiculous and far too derivitive of an actual aircraft carrier. The design feels lazy and uninspired. It's unfortunate that it's got Ashes of the Singularity's lovely capital ships to be compared to at the moment. All in all, this feels like a game that needed a few more months of design and polishing.Despite these negatives, the game is a lot fun. The effects and sound have real oomph to them, and combat is very rewarding.  There's still a lot of work to be done before the game justifies its high price tag, and I'd expect to see a lot of free content to go in before we start on paid DLC, but this is one of the better RTS games to come out recently.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												I am an old Homeworld fan, so this may influence my review somewhat.Having awaited for the next HW installment for a long time, I was positively surprised when I saw HW DoK up for pre-order a few days before release, and since I enjoyed the first games I decided to give it a go. Already having the remastered edition I got a discount on the buy. And since I pre-ordered I got the DoK Expedition Guide as well.HW DoK certainly brings you back into the franchise - there is no Mothership nor space 3D tactics, but HW DoK has the same feel to it as the other games had - same type of mission videos, well told story line, music. The game evolves much like the original games - steady upgrading of your Carrier (Mothership) and units with research, while scaveninging as much resources as you can out of every map. Basicly, for the same reasons I liked the original games so much I also like DoK.As others have mentioned the multiplayer maps are few - yet for me, this doesn't matter all that much, as I mostly stick to single player. Otherwise, the main drawback of HW DoK, for me, is like the other HW games - It's so enjoyable it simply isn't enough of it and you keep wishing for more. (Perhaps that is why we like the franchise so much ?)The Expedition guide adds a bit of history to Kharak and the Kushan people. Enjoyable read which expands a bit on the HW universe.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												While no means perfect, Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is an amazing game.Having been a player of the Homeworld series since it first came out in 1999, Deserts of Kharak fills the Homeworld universe with more large scale battles set against epic vista's.The game has enough variety in the terrain for me that it doesn't get boring or repetitive. Vehicles are well detailed and it has different types to keep things interesting. I do have several things I disliked. The campaign I feel could have been a bit longer. While I am satisfied with what we got, I feel that a few more missions would have helped. I do feel the mission variety did help a bit though. Several other users have made comments of the low textures. I feel I must partialy agree. While zoomed out and moving around the map it really isnt that noticeable, when zoomed in, it does become apparent. All in all, I was happy with the game and the way it turned out. Hopefully BBI will improve upon this and work with Gearbox to create new space-based Homeworld games that we all have been dreaming for.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Initial thoughts with follow up below:This is a preliminary review, but I have to say, I'm addicted to this game. I've always been more of single player fan, avoiding multiplayer until I've finished the story. And Homeword: DoK has a great story. I'm a little further than halfway through and I'm enjoying it greatly. I'd highly recommend experienced strategy fans play it on the hardest difficulty as it gives the feeling of the original Homeworld. I'd even go so far as to say H:DoK is a better game than Homeworld 2. HW2 left a feeling of disappointment for me, as parts of the original that I loved were smoothed over, and the story was made slightly more basic. For instance, strike craft and corvettes were forced into squads, formations were dumbed down, and the brilliant ballistic model was replaced with a dumbed down RNG system.While some of these things are irrelevant in H:Dok, the story is much better than HW2, the missions are generally more interesting, the veterancy system is better, and the balancing is better.The inevitable comparison to HW1 comes into play however, and in that respect the game compares favorably, but isn't superior. The story of HW1 was amazing, the score was perfect, the (original, not the remastered RNG system) ballistic model was revolutionary. It didn't have much in terms of unit variety, which helped with balance, so H:Dok has an advantage there.The aircraft/ground craft model is great in H:Dok. It's something like a mix between Wargame: Airland Battle and Supreme Commander. I love the feeling of lethality that Airland Battle gave ground attack aircraft, and H:Dok has it. Lastly, I love the art design in this game. The cinematics are top notch Homeworld style, the unit and terrain design is beautiful as well.So, well done Blackbird. I'm officially a fan. You've made this old Homeworld fan very happy.Edit:Now that I've completed the campaign on "Classic" or hardest, I agree with others that it is a bit short, especially compared to HW1. I enjoyed the campaign and found that the difficulty ramped up quickly in the last 3 missions. Up to that point, it really wasn't that difficult unless you are trying to save every single unit.I ended the game with an absurd amount of resources that I'm never hope to spend. I suppose you aren't expected to gather them all?Anyway, I'm going to give the Skirmish mode a try to see how it stacks up. I'm sure it'll be fun. I'm not really a multiplayer fan, but I hear it's fast paced and has a loyal community.All in all, I don't think the game could possibly have the staying power of Homeworld, because HW was so modable. HW2 ended up in the same basket. By virtue of the land based engine, it'll likely remain niche, but still well worth playing for the single player alone.So after completing the game, I give it 4/5.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Initial thoughts with follow up below:This is a preliminary review, but I have to say, I'm addicted to this game. I've always been more of single player fan, avoiding multiplayer until I've finished the story. And Homeword: DoK has a great story. I'm a little further than halfway through and I'm enjoying it greatly. I'd highly recommend experienced strategy fans play it on the hardest difficulty as it gives the feeling of the original Homeworld. I'd even go so far as to say H:DoK is a better game than Homeworld 2. HW2 left a feeling of disappointment for me, as parts of the original that I loved were smoothed over, and the story was made slightly more basic. For instance, strike craft and corvettes were forced into squads, formations were dumbed down, and the brilliant ballistic model was replaced with a dumbed down RNG system.While some of these things are irrelevant in H:Dok, the story is much better than HW2, the missions are generally more interesting, the veterancy system is better, and the balancing is better.The inevitable comparison to HW1 comes into play however, and in that respect the game compares favorably, but isn't superior. The story of HW1 was amazing, the score was perfect, the (original, not the remastered RNG system) ballistic model was revolutionary. It didn't have much in terms of unit variety, which helped with balance, so H:Dok has an advantage there.The aircraft/ground craft model is great in H:Dok. It's something like a mix between Wargame: Airland Battle and Supreme Commander. I love the feeling of lethality that Airland Battle gave ground attack aircraft, and H:Dok has it. Lastly, I love the art design in this game. The cinematics are top notch Homeworld style, the unit and terrain design is beautiful as well.So, well done Blackbird. I'm officially a fan. You've made this old Homeworld fan very happy.Edit:Now that I've completed the campaign on "Classic" or hardest, I agree with others that it is a bit short, especially compared to HW1. I enjoyed the campaign and found that the difficulty ramped up quickly in the last 3 missions. Up to that point, it really wasn't that difficult unless you are trying to save every single unit.I ended the game with an absurd amount of resources that I'm never hope to spend. I suppose you aren't expected to gather them all?Anyway, I'm going to give the Skirmish mode a try to see how it stacks up. I'm sure it'll be fun. I'm not really a multiplayer fan, but I hear it's fast paced and has a loyal community.All in all, I don't think the game could possibly have the staying power of Homeworld, because HW was so modable. HW2 ended up in the same basket. By virtue of the land based engine, it'll likely remain niche, but still well worth playing for the single player alone.So after completing the game, I give it 4/5.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												I sort of recommend this game. For the price, there's little content to keep you going long term (5 maps??), and the unit type and population cap limit the scope of the game. Much like Homeworld though, there's something a bit special about this game. The low unit cap and mix means that the game is a micromanager's dream come true. Launching a gunship is a real event, if only because you have access to so few, while that isolated handful of tanks on the perimiter becomes increasingly precious as damage is taken from waves of enemy units. It's a little like Dawn of War 2 in many ways, though no where near as developed.I've heard the game called a Beta, and I'd agree with this. The resource wrecks are all copy/paste efforts for the same model, for example. Work needs to be done on the skirmish AI, though it's not quite as bad as some say. Personally, I find the carrier base to be slightly ridiculous and far too derivitive of an actual aircraft carrier. The design feels lazy and uninspired. It's unfortunate that it's got Ashes of the Singularity's lovely capital ships to be compared to at the moment. All in all, this feels like a game that needed a few more months of design and polishing.Despite these negatives, the game is a lot fun. The effects and sound have real oomph to them, and combat is very rewarding.  There's still a lot of work to be done before the game justifies its high price tag, and I'd expect to see a lot of free content to go in before we start on paid DLC, but this is one of the better RTS games to come out recently.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												I am an old Homeworld fan, so this may influence my review somewhat.Having awaited for the next HW installment for a long time, I was positively surprised when I saw HW DoK up for pre-order a few days before release, and since I enjoyed the first games I decided to give it a go. Already having the remastered edition I got a discount on the buy. And since I pre-ordered I got the DoK Expedition Guide as well.HW DoK certainly brings you back into the franchise - there is no Mothership nor space 3D tactics, but HW DoK has the same feel to it as the other games had - same type of mission videos, well told story line, music. The game evolves much like the original games - steady upgrading of your Carrier (Mothership) and units with research, while scaveninging as much resources as you can out of every map. Basicly, for the same reasons I liked the original games so much I also like DoK.As others have mentioned the multiplayer maps are few - yet for me, this doesn't matter all that much, as I mostly stick to single player. Otherwise, the main drawback of HW DoK, for me, is like the other HW games - It's so enjoyable it simply isn't enough of it and you keep wishing for more. (Perhaps that is why we like the franchise so much ?)The Expedition guide adds a bit of history to Kharak and the Kushan people. Enjoyable read which expands a bit on the HW universe.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												While no means perfect, Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is an amazing game.Having been a player of the Homeworld series since it first came out in 1999, Deserts of Kharak fills the Homeworld universe with more large scale battles set against epic vista's.The game has enough variety in the terrain for me that it doesn't get boring or repetitive. Vehicles are well detailed and it has different types to keep things interesting. I do have several things I disliked. The campaign I feel could have been a bit longer. While I am satisfied with what we got, I feel that a few more missions would have helped. I do feel the mission variety did help a bit though. Several other users have made comments of the low textures. I feel I must partialy agree. While zoomed out and moving around the map it really isnt that noticeable, when zoomed in, it does become apparent. All in all, I was happy with the game and the way it turned out. Hopefully BBI will improve upon this and work with Gearbox to create new space-based Homeworld games that we all have been dreaming for.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Feels like Homeworld. Looks like Homeworld. Sounds like Homeworld. Doesn't play like Homeworld. Units are bland and boring. Maps are incredibly small.  Campaign is depressingly short and leaves a great deal of gaps in what was supposed to be a telling of the times between the clan infighting on Kharak to when the Kushan left their dead behind in search of Hiigara.Combat is oversimplified with basic rock, paper, scissors tactics and virtually all multiplayer matches are decided by the first  two minutes of gameplay (whether your workers survive the rush or not). Offense being king isn't a bad design choice in itself however it makes the learning curve that much steeper with no way to observe matches nor host custom maps. (basic features for most RTS fans)5/10 - Campaign was interesting enough to finish. Multiplayer is lackluster.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Player: "Support carrier, go to position x". Game. "Uuuh, no, you know actually I could go to y, the view is nicer. Hey, are these enemies?"Player: "Armored unit, attack that target".Game: "Sure, lets turn in the right direction. Uh, is that a wall, lets drive into it. Oh, that was not the right direction, lets turn again. Wait, what was my order?"+ The game looks really nice+ Good music and sound- Multiplayer is basically dead. Or maybe its just region locked and noone plays in my region.- Singleplayer is boring, the most effective "strategy" is doing the missions very, very slowly, gathering resources, and being super cautious.- Endless amount of cut scenes taking away control of your units are super annoying.- Half the single player is a tutorial. While tutorials are not bad, not giving the player any options to experiment is bad.This game has much potential, but wastes it with bad mission design.

												I cannot, in good faith, recommend this game in its current state.It's not that it's boring or difficult, it's just dissapointing. As a Homeworld (1 and 2) player there is a certain level of polish that feels like it's missing. It's not even like it's big things either, but the little things add up to create a sense of a game that's been rushed out. Things like the tracks, on tracked vehicles, not even moving. And the suspensions on said tracks not moving. Some of the textures look very low resolution too. The UI feels quite clunky, even compared to Homeworld! Add to that, the game crashed to desktop during the third campaign mission and it seems like there's a way to go for this game to be recommendable. Perhaps the developers can put some more effort into polishing and improving on the little things...

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak is a decent Homeworld game. It's surprising how the general flavour of Homeworld is represented in this game, despite the move from a space-based setting to the surface of the desert world of Kharak. The various units are visually similar to the space ships of the earlier games. The cut scenes are made in the same style. The voice acting is as good as in the earlier games. A central mechanic in the game is line of sight. You won't be able to target enemy units that are hidden behind a sand dune, for example, until you actually crest the dune and bear down on them. This adds some interesting stuff to the action, where you can also hide from enemy units' fire by staying behind obstacles. Some minor micromanagement is added to the mobile base that forms the heart of your land-based fleet in that you have to allocate power to different systems. For the rest, though, the game plays essentially like the earlier Homeworld games: protect your mobile base, harvest resources, pump out new units, and purchase upgrades. The problem is that it hasn't manage to really grab me. I'm partway through the campaign and I don't really care about what's going on. The environment never dramatically changes: you're always in the desert, and you're essentially fighting the same enemy in every mission. There's a steady trickle of new friendly and enemy units, but they're essentially varieties of things you already have: another quick light vehicle, another type of tank. It looks good and it sounds fantastic, but in the end all it really makes me want to do is fire up Homeworld or Homeworld 2 again. The remastered versions of those are great, especially with the recent patches. Deserts of Kharak is certainly well made, even if I had quite a few crashes (especially after I finished a mission and am shown the menu again). Stylistically it's entirely in keeping with the other games in the franchise, but it simply hasn't gripped me in the same way. In Homeworld and its sequel, the campaign continually pushes you on and throws new things at you. Here, I just can't be bothered. I'll recommend the game anyway, but it's more 50/50 than anything, and don't buy it unless it's for sale. It's well made, but there's simply not much here. The skirmish mode and multiplayer are afterthoughts, which is not surprising: Homeworld is one of the few RTS games where you play basically for the campaign. So don't buy the (overpriced) DLC; it's multiplayer/skirmish only. Maybe at some point in the future I'll try the campaign again and I'll be gripped by it. You might be entertained by it from the get-go.
