content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												Deserts of Kharak manages to "get" what made the first Homeworld and Homeworld: Catactlysm great and gives us another story in that universe. Even though it's grounded, it still gives the same excellent sound and visual design coupled with great voice acting that we haven't seen in a long time. Also the RTS structure has been moved away from the frantic clicking of Starcraft making a great modern RTS well worth playing.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												As a non homeworld fan and someone who hasnt played the originals, id have to say its a pretty decent game. Its a good RTS. I like campaign so far and the different gameplay from having a mobile base. But, its not worth 50 bucks. There are only 2 factions and each faction has only a few units. No rebindable keys for some strange reason. The camera is a little unintuative. Example: camera doesnt zoom where the mouse is pointed unlike in supcom, sins, ashes and many other RTS games. I do find the camera controls a bit weird to use but you can get used to them. Oh and dont expect to pan and zoom at the zoom time. You can only do one thing at a time. The 50 dollar price tag is super steep for the amount of content. However, this game is a good deal about the 35-40 dollar mark. So dont pay full price. Its not worth it. It is worth a sale price tho.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												I'd give it a 7/10.  It could be a 9/10 if there were more game here than a short, single-path, single-faction, single-environment campaign.  Homeworld could get away with this in 1999, but not in 2016. Good:-Writing and art combine with the atmospheric soundtrack and good voice-acting to deliver a well-crafted setting-Balanced units-Gameplay and Pacing-Controls-Style is very true to the franchise, scratching all the right itches for a die-hard fan like myselfBad:-Lack of content (short campaign, no variety in environments, small cast, no replayability)-Graphics (low res textures, jagged shadows, lack of polish)-Multiplayer feels tacked on-Simple enemy AI-Lacks useful features from previous games (pausing to issue orders, formations, docking, full distance zoom without using tactical overlay)-Carries over all the little bugs and quirks from the first games.  You'd think they'd try to fix some of this stuff.One can tell that H:DoK borrows heavily from the code in the first games.  It seems like they took the original code and just added new textures, maps, objects, and some terse dialogue with brief cut-scenes.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												I am a HW fan and I like this game. Before I started, I wondered whether the team can tranlate the core of the universe battle into fights on the ground. After about 100 minutes play, I am concieved they did. This is a game fabricated with sincerity, deep understanding to the old HW games and creative thinking, which I have found lost in so many old frachises. It is hularious to see it. Some games, bearing the same name of the series and doing good job of keeping superficial things all along, have lost their core on the way. In contrast, this game keeps the core of homeworld, what makes fan like it, while has been creatively done in a very different way. A smart and enjoyable piece of work for me.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												I must admit when I first heard about this game I thought:    "how could you make a Homeworld game that is planet-based?"Well the answer simply is by how HW: DoK is designed and executed.  It's a ground-based RTS sure but unlike any you have played.The vehicles look gorgeous zipping along; zooming off sand dunes only to bounce on their bouncy-bouncy tires followed by hair-raising hand-brake turns so that they can get close to their prey to finish them off with their high caliber, high powered kinetic weapons.Obliterate your enemy form the air by dispatching an air squad or gunship (the equivalent to an AC-130); finally turning them to molten slag by raining death from your bombers.Feel envious of the enemy's shiny railgun capital ship floating in the air in the same way that bricks don't?  Well just appropriate it with Rachel's groovy "obedience whip" (well hacking ray anyway) and its all yours!  Arrr! That be pirates in this 'ere dunes now!Send out your salvagers to gather much needed resources; go defend your allies carrier; defend against incoming units.  Oh no incoming ordinance!  Potential information overload!  Thank goodness for the real-time tactical map (better than HW's) which is surely the best thing since pop-tarts.  With this map you can be sure you can remain in complete control even you can hear the lambs screaming.

It will probably replace C&C Generals as my 'play every now and then' skirmish RTS game.Thumbs up!

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												This is not a fun game.You're supposed to do real-time strategy with a persistent fleet, but your units die in seconds to enemies that pop out of nowhere to kill them. They lampshade this by saying your enemies have hover technology which makes all their units faster? That doesn't make it less frustrating.To have any situational awareness at all (including 'what is this unit I'm looking at') you have to spend the entire game in sensor mode which is blue + wireframe symbols, so any screenshots of a desert world with 3d models is a trick. You never see that. This also means you don't get some basic things like health bars on units, and the elevation is really hard to read in sensor mode so you're going to screw that up a lot too.Resources are very finite for you, but infinite for your enemies as far as I can tell. And there doesn't seem to be any rhyme or reason to anything that happens. You'll spend an hour slogging methodically through the mission with everything mostly working out fine, and then BOOM. Suddenly all your units are dead and it's time to start over.#$%^ this game.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												I really like RTS's as a genre, but this is a disappointment on many levels.- The graphics are bad. I play in 1920x1200, as I have for over a decade. Settings are on ultra. The video looks terrible, definitely low res up-sample. Ok, but who needs video, it's purely cosmetic. The UI is upsampled, this is unforgivable. The UI for an RTS needs to be 1:1, functional, efficient and utilitarian. It is the most important part of the game. The map itself is not very good looking, but now I'm just complaining. I can get over this.- There is no mini-map!?! There is no way to hop the camera around from part of the map to another. All you have is pan/scan which is too slow and inefficient. There is "sensor mode" which is not a good substitute.- The AI doesn't seem to be very smart at all, it simply seems to rely on scripts and overwhelming force. It appears hard the first play, but then you learn the script and you prepare a defense. Really not that insightful. - The controls aren't very good, I can spend some time remapping, but honestly I expect at least a little effort to properly utilize my left hand (KB) and my right hand (mouse) for the actions I am going to be taking most often. I have to do this myself, for a large majority of the controls. Worst I have to waste keys for pan/scan that i would ordinarily never use. - I can't seem to access settings from in game, I have to drop to the main menu.- The voice acting is kind of weak. Rachel S'Jet doesn't have the kind of voice that projects either "strong soldier" or "savvy scientist". She sounds kind of like that girl you sat next to in algebra that thought math was hard. And you remember 10 years layer sitting in linear algebra with the professor droning about eigenstuff and wondering "Huh, I wonder what she'd think of this?"- The units have a lot of special abilities that seem very challenging to effectively use given the limitations of the UI. I expect I will spend 90% of my time with the arrow keys moving my camera around. I plan to return this game. I'm sorry, but either this was intended to be a dumbed down RTS for consoles, or it just was not well conceived by people who understand RTSs. Play one of the later Dunes, play Command & Conquer, play Warcraft or StarCraft (pre activision). Learn what an RTS should look and feel like first, then make it Homeworldized. Do not set us back to 1995.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												Edit:SPOILERS AHEAD!Completed the campaign, Skirmish has 5 maps on launch.I got feed up when i unlocked cruise missiles for my Carrier, the game got to easy. Come level 13 (last level) they gave me a ♥♥♥♥ing orbital ion cannon that killed the last boss in 5 hits (took me 4-5 minutes to kill him). Worst boss fight ever in a homeworld game, story was okay but the ending sucked (last move was about 20 seconds long), from playing homeworld 1 i already knew the story and knew BBI had a challenge infront of them, they had to create something that put the fans on edge. The biggest plot twist was when the sister carrier, Sakala turned on you in mission 11. Suprise suprise, did not see that coming at all *cough*. She only hanged around for half the game ofcourse it was bound that she would betray your cause.Ending credit says that they want to thank all homeworld fans, Diden't know they wanted to thank us by spitting us in the face with this halfassed title of a game. It is to short, it has zero replayability, the AI is a ♥♥♥♥ing joke... But hey atleast the game looks pretty (and outdated).Original Review below.Was looking forward for this game, being such a Homeworld fan.The story is good, even if its predictable for people who played Homeworld 1 (first schematic of the game pretty much spoils this game).Being 13 mission long it's a bit on the short side, you can easily complete the game in 6-7 hours, and there isen't much of repliablity. Seing that most strategy games let you play the "story" from diffrent factions and this game only lets you play the game in the eyes of the "good guys", not like say Red Alert where you can play the campaign as both Allies and Soviets with diffrent missions.The unit roster dosen't bring much to the table, and uses the traditional rock, paper, scissor. Where late game cruisers (battle cruisers/assault cruisers) being all around.The game also feels unpolished, when i came to mission 8-9 the game unlocked like all research options at once, letting me research about 15 projects at once, in earlier missions you got like 1-2 research projects. So it felt kinda rushed, as soon as you get near end game, they unlock everything at once instead of having a progressive research tree.  Can't remember Homeworld ever did this. From what i can recall you get the Heavy Cruiser/Battle Cruiser research on the last 2 missions.Also they added "nukes" in the form of cruise missiles. They are OP as hell and cost like 500 CU (Construction Units) to build and thats it. I had near 25000 CU's on the eight missions, so i could easily stand on standoff ranges and nuke the oppenents carriers without any skills whatsoever. Fun stuff! Right? No?Game also crashed 5-6 times durning campaing, Being a new release i'd figure that much so can't complain to much.It looks great, sounds great, i love the detail, units contacting the carrier to get information as background noise, that immersion! Love it.However compared to Homeworld 1 and 2, this game falls short.I'd recommend it, barely if compared to Homeworld 1 and 2. As a standalone game without any comparison its short and overpriced, Fells like a DLC for any Command and conquer game of some sort.Edit: As of writing this, 57% of the people who rated my review like to play games that hold your hand and is way to easy. This isen't a strategy game people, its a tutorial for... i don't even know what to call it.Rest in peace Homeworld. I miss Homeworld 1 and Cataclysm so bad.

												Beautiful garbage.Lack of pause button removes strategy from this game.  You can't analyze the battle, and figure out the right commands.  There's no time for that.  You can either flounder around, losing way too many vehicles, or you can play a mission enough times that you have the coreography memorized.  That's not RTS.  It's essentially no different than dance dance revolution.A good RTS gives you time to thihnk.  Sometimes that means a PAUSE feature, other times it means how the battle is paced.Time to think isn't facilitated by ape-ing the beginning levels of the OTHER 3 homewolrd games, where you're frantically escaping from something.  What makes it brainless apeing,  and not "payiing homage"...?  In the other Homeworld games, running out of tme was a clever illusion you're meant to see through.   In Deserts of Kharak, you are ACTUALLY running out of time, ticking clock and all.  DEVS.  MISSED. THE.  POINT.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												[     ] Buy now[ ✔ ] Wait for patches[ ✔ ] Wait for sale[     ] AvoidGeneral GameplayIn terms of performance and integrity, the game is rock solid. I've yet to encounter any bugs or crashes, a huge contrast from playing Fallout 4's infestation of (mostly non-breaking) bugs. The developers did well doing QA on this game.Response time is excellent and pathing is mostly fantastic. I've yet to witness any issues with units being stuck or causing unwanted collisions. With that said, all the maps are open deserts with minimal obstructions so not much can go wrong. There's only about a dozen units per faction and the other faction has a mirroring unit with minor differences. This is far from being comparable to Starcraft 2 nor Company of Heroes 2. You can dumb it down to being a two dimensional plane version of Homeworld but it's much more refreshing to play.Single Player CampaignOverall, I enjoyed the single player campaign experience but it was lucklustre. I just wish there was more going on, be it in the background or actively part of the campaign. There's no "critters" or random environment props and units disappear after being destroyed. To be fair, there were sand storms in one of the missions.I don't consider myself to be an RTS expert and I don't think my APM is high enough to brag about, but I managed to complete the campaign on the hardest difficulty and was only defeated twice - once on two seperate missions. The campaign is also linear and you only get to play as one of the two factions in the game. I was actually hoping that I get to play another 13 missions as the opposing faction. However, the amount of detail and production to produce the cutscenes and dialogue was fantastic! There's no ingame mechanic to compel you to replay the campaign again, once you finish it on hardest mode, you get 3 out of a maximum of 3 stars. It'd be fantastic to see how well you did on different runs of the campaign, particularly stats that show how much resources/time/etc were made during that run. Would also be fun to see how you fare against your friends!Multiplayer / SkirmishThere's only 5 maps. No joke.The only challenge you find here is if you play multiplayer against real players, the AI, for the time being, is way too easy than it should be. There's two modes that you can choose to play, artefact retrieval and annihilation. Artefact retrieval is an interesting idea, artefacts are spawned based off a timer mechanic and the first player/team to meet the target amount wins.There is also a unit cap of 125 in multiplayer, which feels unusual and I suspect there is a reason to this other than fps performance or balance. Considering the abysmal amount of maps included, if they had additional multiplayer modes such as King of the Hill or Company of Heroes' Capture the Flag/Points, that would at least give players more options to play with.The developers have included skins/theme mechanic for players to customise their army colours but I wasn't able to pick a different theme other than the default. You can change the primary and secondary paint scheme though, so that's something I guess.Final ThoughtsWhile I appreciate the amount of work that has been put into this game, particularly the single player campaign, I simply cannot justify the price.I just finished a comp stomp in Company of Heroes 2 and I definately enjoyed that more than the skirmish experience in this game.Wishlist: An additional single player campaign. DLC for the Gaalsian? Additional faction to differentiate between the existing two Needs more units and/or secondary active abilities. (Carrier with docking capabilities?) Additional multiplayer modes and winning condition options Harder AI Reasons to replay the campaign  More multiplayer maps $15-$30 expansionUltimately, I think the game is great and the developers are incredibly talented. At this point of time I cannot recommend this game to others, despite my enjoyment. I am, however, extremely confident that any additional content, be it patch, DLC or expansion by this team will be well polished and content rich!

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												No, I can't recommend this game until a significant patch comes out. Lots of crashing, lots of lag, do I not have enough playtime to judge? Well you can thank DoK for that.Seems to be lacking in content, and mostly sadly of all, character. All cutscenes I've seen feel about 10-20 seconds too short, everything seems very clipped and concise. Leaves a jarring feeling when an epic homeworld opera starts playing during a cutscene which then immediately ends, cutting the music off. No fade to silence or you know... appropriate music choices for a cutscene that they know is only about 5-10 seconds long, nooo, just let it cut right out in the middle of a crescendo, fine, whatever. There really just hasn't been enough exposition and cutscene usage in general so far, and don't point me to the expedition guide, because I didn't buy an interactive game to read an encyclopedia.When I can play the game, I'm flying through missions with 0 losses on classic difficulty, which makes me seriously concerned about the brief 13 missions I'll get for my money. Nothing has any sense of importance or grandeur, most mission briefings, what there are of them, tell me how difficult a slog it's to be to get to X and then the mission becomes "well here we are at X, tally ho". Yeah, well done BBI, a modern day epic. "Oh hey, build this unit" is the only description of a new unit I receive, along with two arbitrary upgrades, again with no introduction and just "oh hey we can immediately make everything better whenever we decide you can build something". Everything just feels rushed and sloppy. Some part of the desert visuals look nice, other parts look quite poor, not a great deal of consistency despite it being the one terrain they had to do. A single terrain and it doesn't even look that great lots of the time.Generally I'm just underwhelmed entirely by the level of attention to detail and storytelling ability displayed. There's no real interaction between units and where there is it's done in a very joyless fashion. Harvesters just bob back and forth between resources and resource controller, no docking and unloading, just "boop" and it's all unloaded and back to work once it gets close enough. No docking of your land units with your land carrier, only fighters can and they're really more of just an additional carrier special ability. There's none of the nice interactions of units like in Homeworld.Maybe I'm just tired and grouchy, sick of constant crashes. I'll revisit this review as and when there is a patch, though I doubt anything will be done to fix any of my main gripes so far. Don't worry though, I hear some paid DLC will be coming soon, woopdidoo, have some more nostalgia money.Edit: So two patches in and there have been minor balance changes... no bug fixes. Wonderful.And BBI seem to just be letting the Steam forums fester instead of maintaining or posting information in them. I feel this game is just going to fizzle out.Edit 2: I played through bugs and crashes and 13 missions for a 10 second outro? Are you kidding me? This game is worth about £10 at most. Terrible story telling and a waste of the franchise and the good ideas it used up pointlessly.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Pros: expedition guide, cinematics/story, visualsCons: everything elseI really want to like this game, I kept giving it a chance, and I will probably continue to do so becasue im a sentimental idiot about homeworld 1 and 2. But there are too many little things keeping it from being good. As it is, it can be enjoyable at times, but it is no homeworld.The unit control is terrible. Airstrikes are easily wasted at no fault of the player - they almost made air units work in a cool way, but they didnt pull it off by what I can only assume is laziness. You can't even save groups for air units - once they dock to reload, any grouping is gone, so you either have to waste a lot of time whenever you launch something, or let the ai waste their single shot on whatever they see first. Units get stuck on each other. Units have to be babied or else they will get stuck behind hills, potentially not contributing to a fight at all. There is no way to control what formation your units take, and there is no way to move a formation to face the way you want it, meaning your guys will run in one at a time in a line rather than as a wall unless you take a ton of time to set them up manually every single time you want them to move together correctly. Also, if you have units of different speeds in a formation (so more than one type of unit at all), they dont match the slowest speed, but instead rush in one unit type at a time rather than as a full force. Combat often boils down to an ugly point blank mess within seconds regardless of what you do, usually resulting in the bigger force winning. There is a way to make it feel like combat is random and frantic and unpredictable, and I doubt that is what they were going for here but regardless it doesnt work.Also everything is extremely rock-paper-scissorsy, and not in a good subtle way like the previous homeworlds. The way damge is handled and how this-unit-ALWAYS-beats-that-unit feels more like starcraft or command and conquer, or some old 2d rts. That type of game may have its place, but I dont feel that place should be in the homeworld series.The camera sucks. You can't rotate or zoom at the same time, or rotate and move, etc. When you rotate, it doesnt keep your mouse position where you left it, so if you rotate ~45 degrees, youll be on the edge of the screen when you let off, making you pan, which gets really annoying really fast. Also, as far as im concerned, the camera doesnt zoom out far enough without going into the sensor overlay mode. The entire game feels too close nomatter what is happening. It feels like someone copy-pasted some crap code off a unity rts camera tutorial and said "good enough" becasue suckers like me would buy it, and paid youtube dumbasses would sell it to people who have never heard of homeworld.There is no mod support as far as I can tell, though I havent looked into it much. Considering how well Gearbox did with the remasted version of Homeworld 1 and 2 and implimented the steam workshop, its kind of lame they didnt do the same here. Multiplayer is extremely limited, and the AI is horrendous so dont even worry about skirmish.Unlike the rest of the game, the story and cinematics are very well done and are what you'd expect from a homeworld title. The visuals give a feeling remnicent of homeworld 1 and 2 despite being in a desert and on the ground, and were often the only reason I remembered I was playing a homeworld title at times. Also a big plus is the expedition guide, which goes into detail about the history of Kharak, and its really nicely set up. Despite all the problems, it can be fun at times, but it's the same enjoyment that can come from any generic game. There is way too much getting in the way of it living up to its title, which is a shame becasue the potential is there.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												UPDATE: Well, I have tried now several times unsucessfully to contact Steam regarding the possibility of a refund for this game. According to their (more than likely automated) response;"Requests are considered on a case by case basis and are not typically issued for purchases of released products that are more than 14 days old, or if the purchased product has more than 2 hours of playtime. For in-game items the refund period is 48 hours and the item must not have been consumed, modified, or transferred."The reason given is that I've played more than 2 hours. I'm sorry, but a blanket 2 hour window to request a refund for a game will never cover the multitude of possible reasons someone might request a refund, and it is potentially a massive problem for games that don't even last 2 hours. I've made it clear in subsequent requests that I would like a non-automated response to my concerns as the spiel indicates can and should happen, and yet again, did not receive one.  Furthermore, there is no way to directly contact Customer Service (if in fact such a thing does even exist) about my issues. I don't even want a full refund. I want acknowledgement of my concerns and a real person to communicate with me. I have only ever requested a refund once before (for something that I've never even installed) and I wouldn't make such a request if I didn't feel strongly about this. I would be happy for Steam to keep their % of the sale and give me something back out of what's left. Something that I can use for a product that isn't advertised to be something that it's not. The game itself is not terrible, but it's certainly not worth the price of admission compared to any somewhat equivalent product. Final Verdict: AmbivalenceIf money is not an issue, and/or you love slightly slower paced multiplayer RTSs, and/or anything Homeworld is simply your "jam", get it, get it right now. If you're looking for something single player, well;  - For a number of reasons, the gameplay isn't the least bit challenging, even on "hard" difficulty. I finished the campaign on hard, barely losing a single unit, with enough spare resources to rebuild my fleet several times over. - It's ridiculously short. I think I've logged around 12 hours at this point, and that's including a few skirmish maps. Add to that the fact that if you spend time mining, it'll slow down your gameplay significantly, and that is something I did. - The scenarios desperately lack imagination. Researching and developing new units and abilities is interesting and all, but there was never any particular tactics or strategies necessary to succeed, and only a few story-related mechanics. I love Homeworld, and aesthetically and thematically, Deserts of Kharak does a grand number of things right. If that's all you need for a good time, grab it and look past it's faults. Just bear in mind that unless you're looking to blast your mates apart time and time again, there just won't be much to it. Gonna have to go with a Not Recommended for now.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												I can't recommend this game at full price - which is a HUGE shame. On discount (50%) it is much better value. My whole issue with this game is its depth; it just feels rushed.  Pros 	 Explosions look great and feel satisfying - the way lightning arcs through the plumes of black sandy smoke looks awsome. Carrier explosions are unfortunatly the other side of this coin and are pretty lackluster. The in mission atmosphere, generated by the ambient unit chatter ect, can feel amazing especially when combat gets going.  The game feels like a homeworld game which is nostalgic. The units that are there, are fun to use. I enjoyed the story, even if it does feel a bit rushed towards the end. The music fits will into the game and brings a lot of life to some of the duller missions.  The game runs pretty well on highest settings on 4k despite my rig ageing a bit.(2500k @ 4.5, 24GB ram, 290x 4GB, SSD, Win10) Cons The minor stuff (which could get fixed by patches) The game crashes. I had 4 .exe has stopped working on my 10 hours play through the campaign. Buggy unit targeting priority - rail guns which are basically incapable of hitting the sandskirmishers (lighter vehicles) but will consistently target them despite other targets being available. More buggy unit behavior - Bombers will often fly over their targets and simply not drop any bombs. Visual bugs - aircraft are often invisible until they have left the end of the carrier ramp and cruise missiles will clip through vehicles and terrain before hitting their target.  Unit clipping - light ground vehicles will drive through structures they are targeting.The major stuff which really hurts the game. Very poor unit diversity - Where are the dreadnoughts ect?! This feels like Homeworld 1/2 with everything above a destroyer removed.  The Galsean (or however you spell the name) feel really underbaked in Multiplayer - they even have less units than the  Coalition! I find it odd that the Coalition get a fast battleship style ship which hovers (when all the rest of their units are tracked) and the Galsean feel like they are missing just such a unit. Was the side swapped because of poor unit diversity in the campaign for the Coalition?  No more resource ships docking like in Homeworld :(. Had this game has more units and a couple more single player missions with more variety this would have been a huge thumbs up. In the state it's in, with crashes and abysmal unit diversity I have to say don't buy! Hopefully BBI can patch in some diversity and make this game what it could have been!

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Firstly, the game itself feels great, it looks great and so far plays well. It's at once familiar and fresh and really invokes Homeworld effectively, the story so far is compelling.It's a great shame then, that I cannot progress through the story to experience it all as I've encountered a bug that many people are also encountering that halts progress at mission 4.Restarting the mission three times hasn't fixed it, the twenty other mystical solutions offered by equally frustrated players hasn't fixed it.I really want to give this game a positive review but the trend of Gearbox allowing glaring bugs through to retail release is inexcusable, their general inability or unwillingness to perform proper QA shows utter contempt for the people who buy their games. If the bug is fixed in a timely fashion I'll consider changing my review for the benefit of BBS and the hard work they've poured into this game.Even if I do alter my review rest assured I'll be continuing my general avoidance of Gearbox products - if it wasn't for my love of Homeworld I wouldn't have spent another penny at Gearbox - not that I'll be missing much, Battleborn looks like garbage and Broderlands has been milked drier than the deserts of Kharak harhar.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												I loved hw1 and hw2. Hw2 being one of my favourite games of all time if not number 1. This game is very rushed. Almost every mission looks like there were some mechanic or art ideas but they trashed them, unit AI is very bad, ships constalntly overlaping themselves, especially harvesters. Graphics are disappoining, music is kind of meh. Pace of the game is sometimes ok but most of the time way too fast. This game screams 'i want to be homeworld 2 but I dont know how'. Reviewers said something about twists, I didn't see anything surprising. Also controls are way worse than in h2, how is it possible? But art style is super nice, and some of the maps with crashed ships are very cool looking, but way too small. I regret buying...

content:

												This game gave me a bit of mixed feelings. It has good fastpaced RTS combat. I really do like the combat, the carrier actually feels a good platform for combat and is not only meant for production like in the other HW games. If you don't take HW Complex mods into account. Campaign and lore is up to the legacy of homeworld games.For this "review", I would give it a side thumb if I could. For now I will give it a thumbs down once they fix the issues below.Primary things that really made me do a refund:- Only a very few multiplayer maps. I mean it.- You cannot rebind hotkeys. Using arrow keys for map movement instead of WASD isn't optimal. In Wargame: Red Dragon WASD map movement is a must for me.- Region lock in multiplayer. This way you will kill the multiplayer.I will consider getting this game in the future, once it's at the 20 euro price tag and when they actually patch the game to the state where it should've been at the release. Gearbox Software doing the rushed releases as always.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												I have always been a fan of RTS/strategy games, but this one doesn't do it for me. I tried very hard to like it, and push past the boring/annoying bits, but I just can't bring myself to do it.The campaign feels like a chore, and varies wildly from being ridiculously easy to a seemingly invulnerable enemy force. The economy system, with its finite rescources, doesn't allow for big clashes of massive armies. This mean that most battles are limited to small packs of 10-20 units. Despite the small army size, there is little benefit in microing units. I would call this game a "slow RTS" as far as build-up time, but it lacks everything that makes the late-game fun in an RTS.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												As of 1/25/2016 the game constatly crashes. Unplayable. Many fixes and workarounds were attempted to no avail. Refunded. i7 6700kr9 280x16GB RAM Update : I repurchased the game from a key site for $25 sometime in march, and I am VERY glad I waited for it to go on sale. The crashing issue is nothing like it was before, although it did crash in the middle of a mission 2 times during my campaing play through causing me to restart. Beat the campaign with every objective on every mission compleated in less than 8 hours (on normal). I also hoarded resources, and ended the game with many left over... so if I hadn't have wasted so much time collecting un-needed resources, the campaign would have been over in less than 6 hours. Very disappointing. Allthough extremely short, the campaign was equipped with a very engaging and thrilling story. However, the AI didn't really have any intelligence what so ever. No strategies other than "move a small number of units straight at you repeatedly". I did play on normal, but I doubt the hard difficulty would add any AI stratigies other than increasing the number of mindless waves. Skirmish was rather boring... nothing about it made me want to play it again. Multiplayer is dead, couldn't even find a match.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2016
												A satisfying RTS that feels situated within the Homeworld universe. I enjoyed being exposed to the fully-fleshed out world of Kharak as previously only found in the companion guide to the original Homeworld. The art, sound effects, and graphics are all excellent and very reminiscent of the original Homeworld; the campain is fast-paced, fluid, and fair; and the writing dovetails into the plot of the first Homeworld. There are several Easter Eggs for old-school Homeworld fans, which are great. Unfortunately, issues with the writing keep this from being a masterpiece: key plot points are glossed over, the characters aren't as absorbing as the writers intended, and the latter third of the campaign feels rushed and incomplete. Additionally, the DLC's so far have focused on introducing units for multiplayer, rather than fill in more plot for the single-player campaign. The Expedition Guide is nice, but a PDF version would be nicer, so that I wouldn't need to launch a standalone app to read its contents. Finally, a few bugs persist (such as camera zoom occasionaly getting stuck on a unit until the camera is panned), but I didn't encounter anything that distracted too much from the experience.Overall, this is a solid single-player experience - I would pass on the DLC's except the Expedition Guide - and hopefully the devs release a DLC that fills in more of the campaign. A sequel would also be great!

												Given that I haven't played much homeworld before, though I've played RTS games for decades. Graphics are a bit underwhelming. The levels look ok-ish, the units and FX just look bland. There's zero sense of theatrics, for the actual gameplay. Gameplay, I can see myself eventually getting used to the interface. I like the grand veiwpoint and the great sense of scale,  but the gameplay gives no sense of gratification. An enemy unit is there, you select your units, click on the enemy, wait a bit and it's gone. They should've taken a lesson from Company of Heroes 2, SC2 or Warhammer; destroying an enemy unit should have a sense of occasion, you see debris exploding into the sky.Audio, what a mess. Especially for someone new to Homeworld, nobody shuts up for a second.Conclussion, I'm tired and I haven't smiled or raised my eyebrows once, in the hour and a bit playing this game, which is a problem, especially for a game that's this expensive. I MIGHT give it another go, when it goes on sale, but there's no way I'm paying 50 bucks for something this 'meh'.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												So far the game is a mixed bag for me.  I find the story pretty interesting and like the look of it but I am already bored of the old-school RTS gameplay in the campaign.I had the same issue with Starcraft2.  After playing Supreme Commander FA for hundreds of games and the Warhammer RTSs I just don't find much fun in spamming units, ramming some health bars into some enemy health bars and waiting for my inevitable win.  I want more strategic and tactical depth.  There is a rock-paper-scissors thing but it's extremely obvious when to use what unit so the only real challenge is in putting up with a bit of tedium and moving quickly.Also, I DESPERATELY want to scroll the camera back more in non-sensor mode.  It feels super claustrophobic and I wrestle with the camera to get it pointed at the action in time to see anything.  Which makes me want to stay in sensor mode, which seems like a waste. SupCom solved this problem years ago, but in the name of old-school we gotta ignore that?And yes, even though I loved homeworld back in the day I had the same feeling of boredom when I replayed the recent remastered version.  That old school RTS thing was just played to death and does not entertain me anymore.I hate to thumbs it down because it does what it says on the tin.  But I am sad that I probably won't finish the interesting story because the gameplay is not very engaging.  I would only reccomend it to someone with a nostalgic love of retro or who is new to RTSs in general.

												This game reminds me of RTS in the 90s and early 2000s.Not in the good way.Unskippable cutscenes, that you're going to have to watch repeatedly because the game bugs out and you have to load earlier games.Missions designed around a "special ability" that is completely useless outside of that special ability.UI choices that make no sense (esc should always close open menus and the focus for the save file name should be the text entry).The game cynically cashes in on the name of the Homeworld franchise while producing little to none of the gameplay or feel that the original games had. 												-No editor of any kind, a big no for any rts title.-No workshop support.-Multiplayer maps are the smallest I've ever seen in a rts.-No developer presence on steam forums.-Faulty AI after 30 minutes.-DLC is a cash grab scheme that had immediate post production release.-Prepare to be shouted down by people when you critique this mess.            ^(Multiplayer)^-Amazing ambience, beautiful gfx, except many have optimization issues.-A rip from C&C 4, except done well.-Intelligent mission design, persistent fleets, easy interface.-Good voice acting.-Mechanical execution is sound.-Short but sweet campaign, comparable to original homeworlds.                ^(single player)^With a great campaign and horrible Multiplayer scene this game should only be bought when on sale. The way Multiplayer deviates from the spirit of the rest of the franchise is confusing and a major let down, and with the utter lack of content it is being cemented as a arbitrary addition to an amazing IP. 9 hour campaign if you try hard, but most walk away after according to the stats. Dying game with no community collaboration, so much lost potential.Tldr: wasted potential, buy on sale, play campaign and walk away.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												So disappointed, was really looking forward to this. This game was not ready for release and does not live up to its heritage. Have requested a refund.As other reviewers have said, and in no particular order:- shoddy animations- shoddy physics- selecting units can sometimes be difficult and behaves inconsistently- inconsistent texturing (though some of it is beautiful)- a carrier that doesn't carry anything- resource harvesters that don't actually visibly return resources, just pull up 100m away from the carrier, pause and then continue.- pathing management with large vehicles and somewhat enclosed spaces is clumsy- backstory isn't particularly well presented, more implicit than anything else- semi-adoption of Homeworld keyboard shortcuts, but pressing 'f' to focus doesn't really work, double tapping it does nothing- no alt-select for focus- camera controls don't seem intuitive- camera can not be zoomed out far enough, forced into the sensor view 90% of the time, even though the maps aren't that large- only a handful of skirmish maps- AI is lacking in the campaignThe biggest problem though is one of the games core mechanics, the effect that elevation has on combat:- an overlay is displayed with elevation hints when you are issuing move or attack-move commands but this info is unavailable if you're simply right clicking to issue move commands. A keyboard key to toggle the overlay would have been more useful.- positioning units, particularly large groups of units, to take advantage of elevation is virtually impossible as there are:- no formations for units- no way of specifying the orientation of units or groups of units- despite LOS being such an important mechanic, you will often find half your units have none, and there's little you can do about it.I love the concept and art design. The UI is fine. Music is spot on and the Story is OK, just under presented.I think most punters were surprised when this was announced. Almost seems like the release date was a little bit of a surprise for the developers - seems as if they were rushed into getting this out the door well before it was ready, otherwise I would be DEEPLY surprised if all these game dev vets who were supposedly working on the title would have been content shipping it.If development continues post release and some of the above gets fixed, I would gladly change my review. Would love to this title shine.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												TLDR: At $30usd I’d recommend this, $50 feels pretty steep. Add it to your list and wait for the price to drop a bit. I’m gonna go on the record and say I loved Homeworld. In fact, I even made a Babylon 5 themed mod years back for the original (Conflicts of Interest), so I was super excited for this game. Spoiler free review.Positives Art direction  - Continuing the unique homeworld aesthetic, it’s almost minimalist letting silhouette and contrast describe things rather than piling on armour plate after plate. Its visually a breath of fresh air especially today when a lot of sci-fi these days is just over blinged crap (I’m looking at you Halo, StarCraft). The endless dunes in conjunction with massive machines is genuinely cool. The cut scenes are also fantastic, it’s a sublime mixture of 2.5d animation with in game cinematics.  Homeworld feel  – The game is a prequel so naturally it’s going to borrow things but it really does recreate that feeling of the original. Unit icons, radio chatter, upgrading functionality of your fleet is all very reminiscent of the original. Music, sound and voice acting  – Everything again feels spot on. From explosions to the urgency of dialogue in the middle of a battle, it’s extremely well produced.NegativesThe game is really short for a $50 title. I know I got the remastered editions of HW1 and 2 with it, originally I thought this was a plus, but now I almost wish I didn’t, did the price get pumped up to justify this? The missions themselves offer very little in diversity compared to SC2. Many missed opportunities here. Factional mirror matchup. Well one has tracks and moves a bit slower and the other has hover engines and moves a bit faster. It’s cool visually but gameplay wise after 6ish hours it really just feels visual. Disappointing. Homeworld feel  – The original came out eons ago, and while it was mind blowing at the time, I can’t help but feel like some things should change by now. No minimap. Yes, there’s a sensor manager but I just feel it’s a holdover from when you needed a fully 3d map(for homeworld). It’s too much toggling. It feels unnatural these days to be toggling on a mode that is essentially an oversized minimap. You can’t appreciate the art of the game while doing this, and you can’t properly manage any large scale battle without resorting to looking at light blue on darker blue boxes to decide the outcome of things. It’s kind of like how pro StarCraft players turn the settings all way down but to the nth degree. It’s cool for a mission briefing but I’ve grown to despise it for in game usage. Some units are also criminally forgettable  and look the same at a distance. Resource collectors and light units. Gotta use that sensor manager to select resourcers properly. But then Cruisers, all of them just blend into each other. In the sensor manager, battlecruisers, artillery cruisers and support cruisers share the same damn icon. But as they have vastly different functions, you have to zoom in or listen to the radio feedback when selecting them. But then you can’t see what’s happening on to your other units because you aren’t using the sensor manager to look at things, ugh. It’s just annoying. I’m forced to look at stupid light blue on blue boxes to issue orders and have map awareness, but it just hurts the experience. I can’t appreciate the little firing animations or the little clouds of dust they kick up when moving. Stop taking me out of the experience While the story is cool it’s also a bit naff. What do I mean? Well it drops you right in the middle of things and sets you up for an epic ride, and it just doesn’t quite get there. The motivations of your foes are quite flimsy, it feels a bit rushed or cut short. It basically left me feeling a lot of why and what and then just ok whatever towards the end.   UI annoyances - Burying build units under icons. I found it rather irritating that building units you have to select your carrier, then select a box, an arrow shaped box, a diamond shaped box or a slightly askew box to then build light medium air or heavy units. The icon differences are just crap and it feels unnecessary given that there really aren’t that many units total to justify the categorization. The game focuses on quick decision making while managing your entire fleet and their abilities, this is something that takes away from your concentration in a big fight.  Basically the game definitely is a step back from the control and finesse system of SC2.I honestly did enjoy the game, and won’t be asking for a refund or anything but since steam only allows for positive or negative and not something in between, I’m going to have to go with negative mainly due to the current price. I was also kind of a superfan of homeworld, so for a newcomer I think at around $30(USD) would’ve been a good price (turn the recommendation to yes) for this title. I’ve been harsh on the game but only because of how I had such high hopes. My negatives really aren’t show stopping in any way, but I feel like the current price point the game just doesn’t offer enough to justify things. I both love the homeworld feel but also feel like BBI hamstrung themselves adhering to it so closely. They wanted genre defining but I feel like this will simply stand as a good game, not as the standout title that Homeworld was.

content:
Posted: January 23
												i bought this game for the nostalgia factor after i played the original Homeworld and Homeworld2 in early 2000s.. since then, there has been a number of better RTS games than Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak.. games such as Starcraft2 and the Red Alert series, that i would recommend over Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak ..without the nostalgia factor, i guess i would be more disappointed and more critical with Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak..the graphics is great and the zoom close-up during battles, is definitely impressive.. but the story is very very minimalistic following the style of the previous 2 games.. however, the previous 2 games came-out in a time when PC gaming was in its early infancy.. maybe early childhood.. the technology of the time did not allow Homeworld and Homeworld2 to have complicated game-play and top-notch cinematics.. so the style of the game had to be as minimal as possible to work in most computers in early 2000..but Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak, came in a time when there is so much more that could have been done to the game..   just look at Starcraft2.. i dunno.. Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak just feels "lazy" to me, compared to what Starcraft and Command and Conquer had become.. and compared to the original Homeworld and Homeworld2..FURTHERMORE.. and this is a BIG one!.. the reason why i loved Homeworld and Homeworld2 so much, is because the battles took place in outer-space, where you had to navigate in a 3D space and you had to move your units along with x, y and z axis.. at the time (in early 2000) Homeworld and Homeworld2 were the best space RTS game in a truly 3D enviroment..no other game came close to what the original developers of Homeworld and Homeworld2 have achieved..Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak, did not add anything new that felt groundbreaking.. so ok.. I AM A SCI-FI JUNKY.. AND I WANT TO SEE MORE SPACE BATTLES!! and i find my fix with Starwars, StarTrek, StarGate, BattleStar Galactica.. and the Expanse.. those sort of things..Homeworld and Homeworld2 gave me MY FIX.. furthermore, the workshop allows you to transform some of Homeworld units into BattleStar Galactica and StarWars units.. that is simply fantastic..but Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak, it takes place on the surface of a planet, on the ground and in the desert.. YAWN!! this is a big let-down for me.. if i wanted a better game that has battles taking place in the desert, there are many many RTS games out there that provide better story-line and better gameplay..i give Homeworld: Deserts of Kharak.. a 3/5.. or a B-..without the nostalgia factor.. maybe a 2/5 or a C-..by comparison, i give the original 'Homeworld' (remastered) and 'Homeworld2' (remastered) a 4 out of 5.. or a B+.. do check them out..

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Me only being at Mission 6 out of 13 right now, seems a bit early to write a review, but for me personally, its not. I've always been afraid of strategy games, they always seemed full of different systems and features, hard to understand. This game however, looked very easy to understand and so it is. Its great fun and it makes me finally like a strategy game for the first time in my 25 year old life. Rachel is great as your protagonist the story is the "lets fight for resources" standard in the genre, but they still tell the story very nicely with good movielike cutscenes before each mission, which draws me into the universe every time after putting it down for a while. The game has a great learning curve. When I fail, its because I did not understand the features of a unit from the get go, and not because the game failed to tell me but because I just am so fresh and new in the genre. I never liked a gearbox-published game, this is the first one that I fell in love with. Please let the studio do the franchise from now on, and don't make it as complicated as the competitors. For me this was an amazing experience already and I'm only almost half-way through. I can only speak of single player, since I dont dare to try face off against other people. Just wanna get the basics straight for now.Technically it seems very polished and clean, it has this "plastic" look that Portal invented. Some people call bad fps on this title, I never dropped below 60, but then again I only face off against AI in single player missions. Voice over work is also amazing. Please make Homeworld 3 now!

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												While Deserts of Kharak certainly was inspired by the Homeworld series, and the touchstones fans are looking for are present, the execution of the game demonstrates a bewildering naïveté by the developers who never seemed to get their arms around what they were writing.First, let me say this game is beautiful.  The artists did a top-notch job, and the cinematics feel like a more evolved form of Homeworld's black-and-white, simply animated cut scenes.  The new characters, the models, and the interface all compare favorably with modern RTS's.The main problem I had with Deserts of Kharak actually had to do with the way the setting, the mission design, the visual design, and world never seem to meet, and indeed, actively clash in numerous places.Let's start with the visual design.  Deserts of Kharak, as the name suggests, takes place almost exclusively on enormous, tan dunes of sand.  There's very little visual distinction between terrain rises, falls, and textures.  If the game were in VR or otherwise provided steroscopic vision to the user, this might be less of a problem, but as it stands, just reading the terrain you're looking at can be surprisingly difficult.Secondly, there's the units.  They're the same color as the terrain they're sitting on.  While that would probably make sense for a desert fighting force, from a gameplay perspective, it makes interacting with your units from the main game view very tricky.  Even with the overlays that provide different shapes for different types of units, it can be a challenge even to see a unit, let along distinguish what kind of unit it is.The sensor manager from Homeworld is back, and provides the shape-based overlays for both friendly and enemy units.  Unlike Homeworld, though, terrain plays a major role in the micromanagement-heavy gameplay of Deserts, as does unit orientation.  Neither bit of information is clearly expressed in the sensor manager, and as a result attempting to control the battle from the sensor manager can be something of an exercise in surprise and frustration.The sensor manager also gives me an opportunity to segue into the issues with the mission design.  Especially early in the game, the missions introduce challenge by having enemy units attack simultaneously from multiple different directions.  In principle, that's fine, and it makes sense in the context of the story, but that type of mission is singularly poorly-suited to the interface of Deserts.  Because the game encourages, to the point of requiring, micromanagement of units, and because you can only get a view of the battle as a whole from the sensor manager (which is an entirely separate screen), it is very easy for a player to simply be unaware of a new attack force or front moving in from a different position.To put it in more technical terms, the other games in the Homeworld franchise could get away with their UI choices because the missions always made it clear there was a defined axis of attack.  Deserts of Kharak does away with that choice, and while it is unlikely to cause a player to fail a mission outright (although certainly possible), it feeds a feeling not that the enemy is outsmarting you, but that the interface you're using isn't up to the task you've been set to.Finally, the story is... strange.  It moves in fits and jerks, asks a lot of questions, and answers few.  Long-time fans of the Homeworld universe will undoubtedly be left scratching their heads at a number of the retcons that were introduced to support the new story.  The end of the campaign comes suddenly, and the few seconds we're spared of denounement do nothing to resolve any of the questions raised to that point, or hint at the fate of the characters between the end of this game and the beginning of Homeworld 1.Ultimately, and in spite of the Making Of content, this game feels like a game written about a science fiction desert society, that was crowbarred into the Homeworld franchise by adjusting the interface and story, but ignoring the game design lessons of its predecessors.  Deserts of Kharak would've been much better served to have simply remained Shipbreakers and stood on its own.  By becoming a Homeworld game, both the franchise and this product have been diminished.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Imagine your favorite movie. The opening scene comes, your hero comes into view and... you can't hear a word he/she's saying because the music is too loud! Why would anyone in any part of the gaming industry choose to have just one volume slider for both music and cinematics? There's also no key rebinding (can cause issues for anyone that has ever gotten used to other game's controls or for some other reason wants/needs to rebind the controls). I've had constant screen tearing no matter what settings I used.Usualy I'd like to talk about the story, but the initial issues I've had made it hard to focus on the story. The only thing I can say about the gameplay is it feels cramped and a bit outdated.If you're looking for a good AAA game, then keep looking, because this isn't it. If you're looking for a cheap indie game, then keep looking, because this isn't cheap.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Having been a long time fan of the franchise and reading some of the inital reviews from "professional" reviewers I was excited and broke my rule of not buying full price games when they just come out. That feels like a bit of a mistake now. While I enjoyed the story and had fun playing the game I completed it on normal difficulty in under eight hours. That was taking my time too, I was a little too cautious on several missions which in hindsight I could have beat with a small force. Once you got a decent fleet put together you can own everything pretty easily.For $50 I just feel like there is not enough meat here to justify that cost. I would recommend this game at $20-$25 but it is not up to the standards of most of the other games you can get in this price range. For me to recommend it at $50 I would like to see a much more envolved campaign more, different more challenging missions. More of a flushed out story, while I enjoyed the general story line it feels like the cliff notes version and could do with having more details flushed out.

												The game itself was quite good. I played it whenever I had some free time. All in all, I managed to finish the game on the highest difficulty setting within ... 18 hrs. No. Definately not. Would I recommend buying it with at least a 50% discount? Yes. A price range of up to 25 EUR would be fine. As a 49 EUR title the game is much too short. Less than 20 hours of play for such money should not happen.My recommendation - wait until the game is much cheaper or on sale and then buy. Not before.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												Ill say up front, I want to love this game.The multiplayer is quick, fun yet still tactical. (Though could use plenty more maps and better AI for skirmish mode)The single player mode is atmospheric, in depth and gives me that same sense of wonder and being alone as the original did.The graphics are amazing, full of little detailed, nothing like seeing the dust clouds as a group of AAVs nearly jump over the crest of the sand dune, hit the ground with a satisfying thunk, and open fire into the flank of an enemy attack group.That all being said,Its buggy as hell at timesI have a consistent repeatble complete system crash at the end of mission 5 during the unskippable cutscene. I run the game maxed out on my 980ti, the temps never get high and i dont see FPS drop.But a game shoudl not SHUT OFF my video card when crashing.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
												Don't buy it, plain and simple.I've been playing the game for some time, and even to the day of this review. The game is still unoptimized. There is a reason to why they caped the unit counts to very low. Each unit in the game is being constantly checked by the CPU, so unless you have a 24+core CPU your game will hit in the mid 40-30fps on maxed unit counts. The game also skips and stutters even during in game movies. I've been playing DOOM2016 and I never seen it dip below 60fps. Even played SquareEnix Supreme Commander with hundreds of units on screen and again it never dip below 60fps. So unless it's free don't get this game. My rig btw is a Win7 Pro, 3770k, Gtx980, 16gbRam

												I highly recommend against getting this game.It is boring, easy, has the most basic uninteresting gameplay.  The controls are absolutely terrible and constantly get in the way. The game feels exactly like an RTS made in 1999, and not in a good way. There is just so much more they could have done, and so many concepts they could have borrowed from games that came later.  I'd say the only good thing about it is the music.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												This is what an unfinished B-grade video game looks like. And yet, you've got DLC advertised on the main menu of the game. They didn't finish the game, but they are selling DLC for it.It's not appropriate to list all of the little things that are not finished or polished. The game just wasn't done. There are minor bugs all over the place. Animations and cut scenes were hastily assembled. They just said, "F it! Ship that s**t!"Controls are frustrating in the same way they were for Homeworld 2.You can't skip cut scenes.There is no mid-mission save.There is no pause.Press esc all you want, because nothing will happen.You can't even stop the mission without alt-F4ing the game, if for some reason you need to quit.Combat is goofy. I managed to beat the end level and the boss unit almost by accident. Now I really don't have any desire to play anymore. Uninstalled.If you must, wait until it's on sale for less than $5.

content:
Posted: February 18
												Initially a great game, the campaign was in line with the homeworld feel and a great story but it was short and very simple. I was expecting there would be another ark of story in the campaign with another race of enemy but sadly no.After that there was no point in playing anymore. The multiplayer/skirmish has no replayability after a couple of games because; the cap limit is 125, no mod support, barely any configuration of game settings/units etc, you cant capture enemy units anymore and the units have been changed for the worse over the campaign. Such an downward turn after the caimpaign it was very dissapointing.This is a good game and campaign for $15-20 but no more as all you really get is a good but short campaign. Not recommended unless it comes down a lot in price or gets mod support or updated significantly.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												I enjoyed this game, but if you are new to the series, I can't recommend given the price-to-content ratio.Definately captures the feel of Homeworld... The graphics, UI and cutscenes are true to HW. The game also makes good use of the 2D aspect. Introduces carrier-borne aircraft to add more dimension as well.Campaign is good and sizeable (10hrs?), although being a prequel you should know whats going to happen, and there really aren't any surprises. Even the 'big twist' is completely obvious if you've been paying any attention to the dialogue.Unfortunately has little content upon release... Only 5 maps. 2x2-player, 2x4-player and 1x6-player. Unit selection feels a little small, and even the heaviest non-carrier units die very quickly if properly countered.The game also has completely braindead AI that is only capable of throwing endless waves of units into your meatgrinder. It can't even build up a significant force, it just spams you with small groups of units.I hope they add more FREE content to this game. They have created a good base game here, but it has no longevity. If they are simply going to leave it to the modders to extend its lifespan, then the asking price should not be nearly so high.

number of helpful: 20 of 46 people (43%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												I requested a refund on it allready. It is very lacking in features and full of bugs. Only thing that felt complete is the campaign, and that alone is not worth the 40-50 dollar price. It really saddens me to see such a good series in the past do so poor now. The camera controls were buggy, units lacking, ai just dumb as bricks, and the amount of skirmish maps I can count on my hand is pathetic. Individual unit behavior is pretty bad too. The entire high ground feature is more of a gimmick and ends up hindering your units are they are too dumb to move half a foot to crest a hill to shoot enemies and instead stare at the small hill while the rest of the selected units get shot up. I don't know if they were rushed from gearbox or the ip transition was too difficult for a small team, or what happened, but this game is bad. 4/10 just for the good cut scenes and campaign. 2/10 for actual gameplay.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												DO NOT BUY THIS GAME...yet. Or maybe do. But read this first.There are some serious performance issues.I have a 3.6 quad, GTX 970, and 16 gb of ram and after hours of tweaks and "fixes" I am still getting 10 - 20 fps on lowest settings. My rig should be crushing this game.This issue only pops up when battles start getting larger. So if you buy this game and start playing the campaign, you won’t run into this until it is too late to return it.Alot of people are having this problem and the "fixes" are not working.I recommend waiting to see if these issues are resolved.ORBuying it, firing up a big skirmish right away to see if you are affected by the unplayable FPS issues plaguing some people. That way you can still return it and buy it again later if the issues are fixed.Seems like devs are starting to catch wise to this issue, hoping they come out with a fix.Before the game♥♥♥♥♥♥itself, its was pretty cool.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												After playing 3 missions in campaign and also a skirmish mission, i must say i am very very disappointed. 1. Very little different troop types, i mean really about 14 units in game.2. Unit limit of 125 and then you have to build these stupid pods to give you more troops up to 125 which the enemy keeps on destroying. 3. You can only harvest with 2 harversters at a time on a harvest spot.4. 5 skirmish maps, reallly??? i mean come on and then the biggest one is 6 player and small at that as well.5. Not a lot of research and not even enough money on map to even research everything.6. Choppy graphics especially in the cutscenes, i mean really, i have a GTX970 G1 Gaming card and choppy. I play Witcher III on full graphics and not choppy.7. Controls are crap and when units close together it keeps on selecting just the one and you have to select all just to select the one you really wanted. Not good at all.8. Cannot even save in a skirmish, so if i must go after playing for hours in a skirmish, then i must either leave the pc on or just abandon the game. What a crap scaled down version from what Homeworld used to be.This is a scaled down version of what Homeworld was and then at $50 price tag as well. This is maybe worth $25.Go play Homeworld Remastered or buy something else.I am really not happy and was waiting for this game hoping to be as homeworld. This whole game feels scaled down with so few troop variety and unit limit. In Homeworld i did not really feel the unit limit because there was so many diffirent troop types and just felt bigger.Wait for a bargain.I feel like refunding this game.

number of helpful: 21 of 57 people (37%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Having played a lot of Homeworld with its finelly tuned control scheme, H:DoK control scheme surely is not. Right clicking puts the mouse in view mode rather than interpreting it as a move order. Control-dragging often results in a selection rather than an attack box. The alt-click and alt-drag to focus from HW is sorely missed, instead click F to focus on selected unit(s) together with a hit-and-miss selection function (it is more difficult to select units than one should expect from an RTS.- Story is fine so far. - Graphics (except the lo-res stuttering cut scenes used sometimes instead of game engine cutscenes) is what I expected and wanted from the HW devs and art directors.- Sounds and music are as good as HW.- Controls are so irky, quirky and sub par, I don't want to ruin my experience by continuing until the game has been patched. I hope it's not a Unity engine issue but only an unfinished, untuned release.In the state the game is now and for the current asking price I unfortunately cannot recommend the game. I got everything I expected except from the control scheme that is neither up to HW nor RTS standards.Will come back after a patch or two though and promise to change my No to a Yes. I wan't to believe ;)
